BACKSTORY:

I'm on a 2-week break from university with time to kill and in the week I've owned this game, I've put almost 70 hours into it.

THE GOOD:

- A lot of freedom to run your businesses and set up intricate supply chains how you see fit.

- All building types can be customised with a vast array of furniture and equipment and if you want to put a salad bar in a clothes store then you do you.

- Uncle Fred sets you up with a clear progression path from running around doing everything, to kicking back and running your empire from your phone with a well-set-up head office.

- You get to manage EVERYTHING from warehouse imports to shop deliveries, to sale price, etc.

THE BAD: (note that the game is in Early Access)

- In the late game things start to get a little unmanageable because a lot of the UIs lack much-needed QoL features.

- Large stores can cause long load times on entering and exiting them and suffer low FPS inside (probably due to the amount of stock calculations that need to be made).

- UI can sometimes suffer momentary freezes while doing things like setting a store to open/closed in the late game.

- Occassionaly all my owned vehicles including ones assigned to a warehouse will disappear and I'll have to rebuy all the vans and take them 1 at a time to the warehouses. It's a pain but didn't appear to be a problem until late game.

CONCLUSION:

This game is honestly awesome and I've had a lot of fun playing it over the last week. But due to among others the issues listed above, the game becomes tedious in the late game when most of these issues seem to appear. I'll say that I like the direction the game is going in and the dev is still active in the game's community and seems to be taking on the feedback given so I'm confident that Big Ambitions will only become even more feature rich and fun to play further down the line.

Man, this game is awesome.

Are you someone who’s always had grand aspirations? Perhaps you remember your childhood days, playing football with friends, engaging in games of cops and robbers, or even pretending to run your own shop, trading shiny rocks for leaves from nearby bushes. If the latter sounds familiar, then you might just find the Big Ambitions game intriguing, where you can build your very own retail empire.

Let’s delve a bit deeper into what this game offers without diving too deeply into its narrative or campaign elements, as my approach typically involves jumping straight into sandbox mode with difficulty settings cranked to the max. If you’re curious about the story aspect, I’ll have to point you towards other sources. However, if you’re interested in a bit of personal insight, read on.

Firstly, it’s essential to note that the game is still in its early access phase, much like many titles these days. However, it’s evident that Big Ambitions is in its fledgling stages, with players eagerly awaiting teasers for the next update. Despite its unfinished state and the need for polish, the game still manages to offer plenty of fun, especially for those with an entrepreneurial spirit.

You begin the game as essentially a nobody, albeit with the freedom to craft your own background and personality within the virtual world, limited only by the bounds of your imagination, right? However, nothing changes the fact that you’re broke. I’m particularly fond of such zero-to-hero storylines, as I always relish the challenge they present. So, one of your initial tasks is to secure a job at a local grocery store to cover your basic expenses. Once you have some cash in hand, you can venture to the nearby bank to secure a small loan and kickstart your journey to becoming the town’s biggest tycoon.

The town is ripe with various buildings available for rent, each serving different purposes, from retail stores to warehouses. But before you rush into leasing your first space, take a moment to strategize. What will your business focus on? Will you sell flowers, jewelry, or perhaps dive into the fast-food or grocery market? Or maybe you’re keen on launching an office for a team of web developers? The choice is yours, but careful planning is essential.

Consider the competition and demand in your chosen location. Will there be a demand for your products or services, is there a even a small gap in the business around waiting to be filled, or are you entering an oversaturated market? Is the nearest warehouse conveniently located for restocking, or will you spend hours traversing the city for supplies?

Once you’ve secured your dream location, it’s time to invest in furniture and inventory. Shelves, desks, counters, and shopping baskets don’t come cheap, nor do the goods you intend to sell. And remember, as your business grows, so too will the need for additional staff and services. Will you hire employees to assist with day-to-day operations, or perhaps outsource delivery services to streamline your logistics?

But the journey doesn’t end there — far from it. As your empire expands, so too will the opportunities for growth and innovation. From opening additional storefronts to establishing your own warehouse and headquarters with hiring managers and tax consultants, the sky’s the limit. But do not forget about the ever-looming specter of taxes — a necessary evil in the world of business. Taxes are a real concern, and setting them in your sandbox settings too high or too low can have significant repercussions. But fear not, for with careful planning and strategic decision-making, you’ll navigate these challenges with ease.

In terms of visuals and technical aspects, Big Ambitions doesn’t boast cutting-edge graphics, but it doesn’t necessarily need to. It evokes a nostalgic charm reminiscent of early GTA games, which adds to its appeal. Despite being in early access, the game runs smoothly with minimal bugs or crashes, making for an enjoyable experience overall.

Big Ambitions is shaping up to be a fantastic game, albeit niche, with the potential for deeper features as updates roll out. So, if you’ve ever dreamt of running your own retail empire, this game might just be your ticket to success.

So, are you ready to embark on the journey from rags to riches? Have you ever dreamt of building your own retail empire from the ground up? Do you want to start planning your strategies, scouting locations, and stocking up on inventory? The retail world awaits, and with determination and savvy business acumen, you can turn your Big Ambitions into a reality!

( This review was originally published on my Medium profile  )

***THIS IS NOT A BAD GAME. I ENJOY PLAYING. I CANNOT RECOMMEND IT, AND HOPE THE DEVELOPERS REALLY PUT MORE TIME AND EFFORT INTO THE MECHANICS***

I'm having a good time playing this game so far, it has captivated me and at times feels very addictive, but as a few reviews have stated the game really still feel like a prototype that has some decent working components. 

As I started the game, it seemed to have a giant ocean of content and mechanics to master and understand, but about 10 hours in I feel like I see the same mechanics getting replicated in a more tedious fashion as you grow. There is tons of opportunity to improve this, many on the forums have made excellent observations on what could be done to make each type of retail business you operate unique from any of the others, but the gameplay loop is go to a wholesaler, buy products, rent a space, and then just stock the shelves/grills/displays with the product appropriate for that type of industry with the same mechanics for all industries. 

Logic also seems to be very absent from many of the mechanics, or the mechanics simply haven't been programmed/built into the engine yet; for example: you don't have to refrigerate food for restaurants, you just stock it on a shelf and even what doesn't get sold stays on the grill and can be sold the exact next time the business is open; employees don't call out sick or throw any wrenches into the schedules you provide, there is absolutely no element of randomness built into anything in this game, so it gets very easy once you understand the numbers behind everything.

This game could be great, and I would love to turn this into a recommended, but in it's current state I would only recommend if it is discounted and you are in between games and happen to really like time/resource management games.

This game has really great potential. I can play this for tens of hours more.
HUGE IMPROVEMENT SUGGESTION FOR DEVELOPERS:
1- More building interior kinds and offices like with full glass outer walls (plazas offices) and penthouses maybe. 
2- There should be an option in interior design to build and destroy walls, adding glass walls for better offices etc. like sims. 
3- MORE RPG ELEMENTS: Like we should have some skills and be able to improve our skills with some sets of skill trees as well. For maybe negotiating with sellers and importers ourselves and when an employer asks for something maybe convincing him.
4- boost morale with events for employers and giving a day off
5- I know it is hard but being able to build our own factories or producing somethings and being able to export ourselves, maybe just being able to export ourselves from local producers.
6- There can be an online version to play with friends in the future cuz making a whole market with online players might be hard for a game like this.
I Really hope this game improves further and ready to support if developers don't stop improving the game

I was surprised. This is pretty fun if you're into starting life as a 67 year old hobo sleeping on park benches. This is more for tycoon game and business fans. Minor bugs aside, I can see putting in more hours. I'm already at 20+ hours as of this review and I'm just getting started. I did a custom game starting with only $500 and no tutorials, so I had to learn the hard way. But my old man is now a two-hundred thousandnaire.

UPDATE: After 50+ hours, I can definitely say this game was worth the price. However, I've now reached the point where my rich hobo is bored of making money. There are some minor bug and annoyances that I won't spoil for you, but the game is still pretty fun overall if you're into tycoon style games. I would describe this as a Sims 1-2 style tycoon game based loosely on a mini-clone of NYC, where a hobo like myself can rise from pocket change to multimillionaire. I stopped as a millionaire, because there isn't anything else money can buy beyond the millions to make it worth the grind. Overall, it was a good run for 50+ hours of fun.

In the future, I'd like to see major overhaul and improvements around investing, e.g. an actual stock market tied to businesses from the game, the option to list and sell stock yourself (go public), or to buy out public businesses. In addition, just the trading of stocks itself might be a fun minigame.

This game is a lot of fun for me. I unfortunately do feel like you hit a wall sort of once you get the feel for the game and start getting to that $100,000,000 range. Buying buildings doesnt really provide anything. Revenue from a building is minuscule, so once you start investing, just leave the money there until you want it.  

A lot of potential for building designs, incorporating a sims-type building community to this game could be really fun and make your businesses more fun to design. (i am aware of the option to see others designs, but  because of the games early production, there is not a lot of opportunity for unique designs that also max out your businesses popularity)

i also was a fan of the market prices fluctuating with supply of goods. Not really sure why that was taken out of the game with the recent update as it made the game feel much more realistic. 

I am a fan of random games, this type of game specifically spoke to me in a way that i really enjoyed. Building a business and fighting the computer for retail space while balancing the real life needs of a person was way more fun than i expected.

Looking forward to the future full release of this game

First off, I LOVE this game. If you enjoy tycoon/business management games, then just download this game - do it! You won't regret it.

I can't believe how good this game is, considering it is only in Early Access. It makes me so excited for what's to come in future updates!

In future, I'd love to see hotels added as a business type, along with proper restaurants. It could also be fun to have some kind of tourist site... a museum maybe? Purchasing expensive pieces of art and antiques to fill up your gallery. 

From the life sim side of things, I'd love to see more options at home, like actually cooking meals (for bigger happiness buffs) and other options, like reading a book perhaps. I'd also like to see a lot more furniture and decorations added in various styles.

Anyway, enough from me... Back to the game!! :)

Rating: 5/5 Stars

Big Ambitions isn't just a game; it's a strategic tour de force that sets a new standard for excellence in the gaming world. With its immersive gameplay, stunning visuals, and rich narrative depth, it's a title that leaves a lasting impression on players of all skill levels.

From the outset, Big Ambitions captivates with its attention to detail and dynamic gameplay mechanics. Every decision feels consequential, challenging players to think strategically and adapt to ever-changing circumstances. Whether you're managing resources, forging alliances, or confronting adversaries, the depth of gameplay ensures that every moment is engaging and rewarding.

Moreover, Big Ambitions excels in its portrayal of complex socio-economic systems, offering a realistic simulation that mirrors real-world challenges. The game's adaptability allows for a customizable experience, catering to both casual players and seasoned strategists alike. Whether you prefer solo play or multiplayer showdowns, Big Ambitions offers endless opportunities for exploration and mastery.

Beyond its gameplay mechanics, Big Ambitions boasts a captivating narrative that adds depth and immersion to the overall experience. Each scenario is expertly crafted, drawing players into a world filled with intrigue, drama, and possibility.

In conclusion, Big Ambitions is a must-play for anyone seeking a challenging and immersive gaming experience. With its blend of strategic depth, stunning visuals, and rich storytelling, it's a game that will keep you coming back for more. Whether you're a fan of strategy games or simply looking for your next gaming obsession, Big Ambitions delivers in every way imaginable.

Take a break from the Socialist uprising to play a game in which you pretend to be a member of the Employer Class.

I might say this game is more akin to an automation game than a business management sim.  You'll quickly automate your retail shops so much you'll no longer have to step foot inside your own business.

There are a large number of other types of businesses you can start.  Finding ways to make the most money with your expanding business empire is the mid-game I suppose.  End-game you take all the cash and find ways to invest it to maximize capital gains.  Real estate and stuff I guess.  I'm in the early-mid game right now.  Uncle Fred is taking off the training wheels and letting me take more control over my empire.

Let's talk about gameplay.

Think Sims controls over a Grand Theft Auto setting.  Driving does feel more like a GTA game, but while on foot it feels more Sims.

You will manage both your business empire as well as your personal life.  Buy groceries for your fridge or eat for free at your own fast food restaurant.  Maintain your happiness meter by watching TV, playing video games, and maybe enjoying a walk in the park.  Some of your employees need a "Peaceful Work Environment" which means you, their boss, must have over 50% happiness index.

Let's talk about quality.

There is some jankiness, but all in all I am impressed with how polished the game is considering the small dev team.  None of the glitches are so serious as to threaten my ability to enjoy the game.  The systems and UI are well designed enough to be intuitive and fun.  Like I said, I'm impressed.

Conclusion:

This is a good game.  It shows considerable promise as it is developed, but it is already in good shape for you to buy and enjoy it now.

I'm really fond of this game genre, and I feel that this particular game stands out. Expanding the city and adding more businesses could enhance it further, but as it stands, it's already quite impressive and more entertaining than many other business simulation games I've played. The 0.4 update significantly improved the driving aspect, addressing one of my primary concerns, along with the dynamics of office-based businesses. These improvements have made the game more captivating and enjoyable. The ability to develop various businesses, headquarters, and distribution networks offers a deeply satisfying experience.

Here are some tips for players:

The flow of pedestrians near a store is crucial. A large store is pointless if it can't attract enough customers.
Always equip your stores with enough furniture to accommodate the customer capacity you desire, as a higher capacity can increase customer inflow.
After establishing your headquarters, employ headhunters and hire employees at the lower end of the salary range. They don't demand pay raises, so training them in-house is a cost-effective strategy. This approach also helps avoid additional employee needs that complicate scheduling, like specific shift preferences. Most of my retail stores operate around the clock with a team of customer service staff and cleaners. Managing full-time hours cleverly ensures a dedicated, low-maintenance workforce.
Assign staff to Human Resources for passive skill development (adjust the training slider to 100% for maximum efficiency). Initial manual training is advisable for quicker skill acquisition, which directly influences revenue through customer satisfaction.
Retail ventures are highly profitable. In contrast, office jobs have become less rewarding. Electronics, jewelry, clothing, and gift/flower shops are particularly lucrative.
However, there are areas that still need improvement:

The property market's current valuation system is unrealistic but is scheduled for a rebalance.
User interface enhancements are needed, especially for mouseover menus in shelf setup.
The employee management interface could be more efficient. A feature to select unassigned employees for bulk uniform assignments and training would be highly beneficial, especially in the game's later stages where managing a large workforce becomes tedious.

Well, 11h at the time of the writing and I'm having a blast.
Game is well detailed, has a lot of features and fills a gap of real state management in the simulation genre. The total ammount of reviews and positive review ratio (6,932 and 93% as of now) for an early access game also speaks volumes of the quality.

I also expected far less from an early access title of this scope, but this one is pretty solid for a 0.4. Devs are communicative, there's a countdown/estimative of next big update, plus in the 0.3 and 0.4 updates there were 3 bugfixes a few days after each, so it does seem like a dutiful team.

p.s.: I didn't abbreviate early access to EA on purpose ;)

Are you ready to embark on a journey that not only takes over your in-game hours but spills into your real life? This grand slam from Hovbaard is an EA title that grabs you by the wallet and doesn't let go until the sun is peeking over the horizon, reminding you that work awaits.

In the hustle and bustle of Big Ambitions, Hovbaard has struck gold. Starting small, you find yourself at the cashier's desk, handling transactions and dreaming of something bigger. Then, the pivotal moment arrives when you take a daring leap, secure a loan, and launch your own business empire.

The beauty of this game lies in the gradual progression from mundane tasks to empire-building excitement. Just as you think you've mastered the art of running a shop, the game throws in a curveball – automation. Hire employees to handle the day-to-day operations or optimize your supply chain for efficient deliveries. Suddenly, you're not just a business owner; you're a strategic mastermind.

At around 6 hours in, I've already set up my second business and am on the verge of achieving the coveted automated dream. Nightclubs and casinos beckon on the virtual horizon, promising a world of excitement that I've yet to explore.

But here's the twist – it's not all about work. Big Ambitions introduces a crucial element: maintaining your character's morale. Endless work can be as damaging in-game as it is in real life. So, remember to take a break, hit the town, and revel in the nightlife. After all, even in the virtual world, all work and no play is a recipe for disaster.

And a word of caution to all you GTA-style drivers out there – your in-game car is not immune to the perils of reckless driving. Repair bills can pile up faster than you realize. Drive safe, park correctly, or risk fines from the city – it's all part of the immersive experience in Big Ambitions.

Ready to join the gaming revolution? Click the link below to join our gaming group and share your adventures in Big Ambitions. Let's build empires, explore nightclubs, and navigate the city's streets together!

Changed from negative to positive. Developer responded and the issue was resolved. 

I don't want negative reviews to badly influence indie games, this one has a lot of promise, but I'd withhold from playing it now as there's a lot that is lacking, looking forward maybe 0.5 will solve some of the QoL issues. 

Mainly:
- Insights are not helpful, since you don't have historic data of previous days and weeks
- Competition doesn't really pay off. I've opened a big law firm with highly trained lawyers, made the prices way below the market, you'd expect people to come to you, but that's not how this game is designed, so basically just losing money, even tho all bars were high, including customer satisfaction
- There should be a way to collect feedback about businesses without visiting them with more in-depth details
- Contracts shouldn't be signed in person, this is a digital world, I want something to be delivered to my business or sign a contract with provider, I should just call them
- Single HR must be able to hold different healthcare tiers, that's how it works in a real world
- Keeping your character happy is harder than running a business. I get good income, but the effects of TV and games are short-lived, tho just visiting a park will stay for like 5 days
- Food delivery should be an option, running for fresh food bags is annoying
- A bug when manage inventory randomly disappears on items/stockpiles/cars/fridges and you can't use them
- The per neighborhood demand is changing too frequently, it will take you more time to open a store, than to catch the wave, not how it works
- Gift Shops for some reason are the only ones that are selling well, everything else is crap (didn't reach high end stores)
- Amount of customers per hour should not be defined by location size or foot traffic. There are shacks in the world where they serve hundreds of people depending on the service, staff skill and popularity of the place
- I think if you can bite the bullet and put some really low prices, your competitors should suffer customer loss and even potentially go out of business
- Painting walls and floor should not cost you a fortune!?
- There needs to be a paid service that will "decorate" your business, loading 4 items at a time and placing them manually for a new store is very annoying. At least make the delivery go inside, and let the player use all items and placement like in Sims, as if it was already in the inventory, this shouldn't be such a dreadful task
- Selling multiple product types in the same store (as per Help Manual) didn't do it for me, nobody bought the "extra" items apart from soda cans. I should be able to sell, e.g toys in a gift store too

Thanks for the efforts tho, really cool concept, really want to play it when it's more polished, I want to feel the progress and recognition growing with my businesses opening, currently it's not satisfying, many times than not I just sleep through days to get something opened, done, etc..
casino go brrrrrrrrrrrrrr
Its a very promising game. Already quite fun to play for many hours

I gave it a fair shot. I had low expectations but the reviews and the premise of the game convinced me that the mechanics and systems would dig their claws into me if the visuals obviously weren't going to. I was pleasantly surprised with the tutorial and fidelity of the simulation. However, once it became clear that I was going to have to control the player character for every interaction, including physically placing the avatar at the locations of places and items to interact with them (ie stocking the first shop from the car, back and forth), I began to have a sinking feeling about where this was going. Anticipated upgrades were going to consist of moving more things better and faster. Boooorrrrrriiiinnnng.

I loathe the movement, controls, camera, and UI most of all. I despise the way windows/buildings are interacted with on the map and otherwise. Considering all this, I could tell that I was going to have a mediocre and time consuming experience. 

I respect the project so far, but at the moment it's a little tedious for me and the issues I have with several systems make it impossible to tolerate for $20 without way more polish.. I can't think of who I could convince to try this niche game but even so I wouldn't presently recommend it. The system of physically trucking stuff around and the arbitrary limitations of old adages such as 'inventory manager' meta-games is distinctly *not fun*, in case ya'll needed to hear that. Games can cut corners in reality in order to be fun - and I recommend you implement some of those shortcuts to streamline the goods - because presently controlling the player character is a painful chore.
Its a good game and a good idea but the execution is very far from perfect. It needs work, and if it gets it, its gonna be one of the best in the genre.

This game is the most promising early access game I have ever played (among the ranks of Project Zomboid and BeamNG drive) and is super fun and detailed even right now. Being an early access game, there are some bugs and things that aren't right, but otherwise the game is super good.

I noticed my boyfriend clicking away, being very quiet compared to his apex sessions and so he started telling me about this new early access game. From time to time I would look over and see how he was progressing and by then he was all consumed. I have played sims 4 for many many years and I was liking what I was seeing (driving!? EA could never without a hundred dollar price tag) so I bought it too. I am truly blown away at the games capabilities at this stage. I put in 20 hours in my first session because the grind is so addictive. We are both sooo obsessed with this game. 

I would love to see a lot more interior design options, that's my number one because I love to build and to have more options that impact the beauty of the businesses and happiness of employees would be awesome. I personally would love to see more business options, grocery delivery / more food stock piling etc. And being able to hire assistants! who you can task to do certain things could also beneficial. That's just off the top of my head though and it is otherwise a near perfect game imo. I haven't experienced any bugs and I am only 20 hours in so i have a lot to work on still. I cannot wait for the full release, wishing the developers all the best!!

Dislike ( nitpicking, honestly ):
--------------------------------

Would like to see:
-------------------

To address the concern a lot of negative reviews bring up: Yes, at the start of the game, you are broke, you have to buy stock yourself and run around a lot to resupply after working at the cash register yourself. That's...the whole point of the game. To start from nothing and work your way up. As you progress, you get your own employees so you just take care of supply. After that, you get your own warehouse, purchasing managers (to stock your warehouse from shipping companies), drivers, and a logistics manager to manage the drivers (the reviews failed at this step). Once that's done, stores are more or less self sufficient and you can focus on expansion.

Tips:
- Foot traffic for a store is very important. No point having a high capacity store if you can't fill it up with people.
- Always build stores with furniture to customer capacity, even if you know you won't get that many customers. Higher capacity drives up customer inflow for the moment.
- Once you set up HQ, get headhunters and hire at the bottom of the salary band. Employees never ask for a salary raise, so train them yourself to get cheap labor. The other upside is training them yourself prevents most types from getting extra needs that make scheduling painful (e.g. 5 days a week, no afternoon shifts etc.). Most of my retail stores run 24/7 with 8x fulltime customer service employees and 2x cleaners. Anything between 30-50 hours counts as fulltime so 4 of my fulltimers run at 35 hour weeks, the other 4 at 49 hours. This way, I have a perfect employee base that is cheap, doesn't need anything and if I need to, I can swap them across stores.
- Assign employees to HR. They passively get training while on the job (make sure to change the slider to 100% skill, it is at 50% by default). I'd suggest training manually until at least 50% since skill level directly impacts your revenue via customer satisfaction. Manual training gets 10% skill per day while passive is more like 1%.
- Retail is very profitable, office jobs got a major nerf and are now my least performing businesses. In terms of profitability, electronics, jewelry, clothes and gift/flower shops (they sell the same stuff) work best.

Some things still need developing:
- Property market has unreal purchase values, due to be rebalanced (confirmed will be done)
- UI fixes needed for mouseover menus, mainly when setting up shelves (confirmed will be done)
- Employee management screen ability to select anyone not assigned to a business so you can assign uniforms and training in bulk, rather than selecting each employee one at a time every day. In later game, you will be training 50-100 employees at once and having to tick a box next to each one every single day is a chore.

Overall, I expect good things from this game. They are very active on the forum as well, responding to queries within minutes.

If you are a fan of tycoon games, this is definitely for you. You can run a nightclub, fast food joint, gift shop, or almost any store you want to. There’s no option to build entire new buildings or deal with multiple floors but besides that the interior design options are great and have potential. If mods/updates keep coming it seems almost limitless what you could do. Honestly in some ways the game is very comparable to sims, with much more of a focus on the tycoon/business aspect than the character creation/personality/auto-simulation(npcs)

Also the recreation of New York City is really cool and well done.

In its current state it’s pretty fun but the gameplay loop can be a bit repetitive. After finding your footing the only way to really continue making money and getting bigger businesses is to sleep through every day, do activities to stay happy, and then check some charts and shift some numbers/employees around. You can get a solid 20 hours of fun I’d say as is. After that I’d hope for updates(cosmetics/character design, more furniture) to have more fun customizing your stores etc, which is really the fun of the endgame imo

pretty solid game, but there's hand full of things that I hate.
     Everywhere you go inside you have a tool tip popping up right in the middle of your screen when your character walks by and another where your mouse is.  Let us turn that garbage off.  I don't need to have a light highlighted while I'm doing something.  Ever.  It's just annoying.
     The camera controls are kind of shit, i can change elevation and direction but not angle of camera.  And I can't change the camera at all in a car.  
     AI doesn't take into account where your stores are when they open theirs.  After opening a Jewelry store an AI opened their own jewelry store right next to mine.  Literally.  We share a wall.  That's  bad location research on their part.  I don't know if it actually affects my business any more than if it were on the opposite side of the district, but I've got to say it's aggravating.
     The happiness metric is pretty bad too.  It requires that you expand aggressively and if you don't then you get sent to a psychiatric ward because it's been too long since you... bought your last whatever.  I don't remember what affects happiness since i play without it enable, but it was a pretty bad mechanic when I last tried it.
     Otherwise the game is good.  It's just got a handful of things I hope the devs address at some point.

you start from literally working behind the register of your first tiny store and move all the way up to calculating deliveries to 100 businesses on a daily basis, managing your employees, keeping ontop of stock (and theft!) all whilst trying to remain in the black and your character happiness stays high. 

very high hopes for this developer based on their critically acclaimed game "Startup", an immensely successful title with amazing reviews. Its a similar game to Big Ambitions (business sim etc.) and it went through the EA process too, finally ending up as a released version that is a now a top-tier game. 

If thats anything to go by, when we're at the end of of 2024, this game is going to be probably *the best* business tycoon sim on Steam. also, regular hotfixes, content updates and communication from dev team!!

Super fun business tycoon game that I hope will get even better over time. From what I can tell, the devs appear to be hard at work and are consistently releasing updates in a timely fashion. 

You can customize shops, offices, and even apartments the way you want with all ready a large selection of items as well as purchase a wide variety of new vehicles with different stats that might help your play-style along the way. Taking care of yourself in the game can also be an important factor in order to meet some of your employees demands and also not fall in a depressive state that would disable you from entering your businesses. 

The most intriguing aspect of the game for me is the ability to play in whatever manner you desire, forming your own strategy and moving at your own pace. I'm sure some people could figure out how to make 60k a day in 20 days while others might want to take it slower and grow each of their businesses slower and only make 1.6k a day in 50 days.

The only problem I can see currently is giving the end game more of a challenge so that you don't become easily bored after becoming rich. The devs are on the cusp of fixing that dilemma though with their next update introducing rivals to the game.

As far as optimization goes, it is pretty solid and the loading times are extremely fast which is very nice to see. When you get bored with the game you can quickly save with f5 and exit. As well as jump back in your saved campaign in less than 20 seconds after launching the game. That's a very nice feature in my opinion.

Highly recommend this game; it has tremendous potential and I have a few ideas that I believe would make the game even more interesting.

First, incorporate the criminal industry. Setting-wise, choosing the criminal industry could result in higher loan interest rates, increased susceptibility to robbery and theft, and higher employee salary demands compared to other industries. Introduce a bail mechanism, where having a law firm would reduce the premium.

Second, introduce a stock or futures system. In the later stages of the game, when players have too much money and lose motivation, this mechanism allows them to invest funds. However, making incorrect judgments could lead to losing their own capital.

There are more ideas, but implementing all of them might transform the game into something entirely different. I sincerely hope the developers have the funding to create a second generation.

I have been searching Steam high and low for a "business empire" game and really wasn't having any luck.  Most business sims only let you run one place at a time, or are primarily just resource managers.  I found this game by accident and it scratches that "biz empire" itch perfectly.  This game lets you (micro)manage dozens of businesses, properties, and investments at once.  You can manage resources and try to achieve full automation.  You can arrange items and decorate each location how you want (on a grid, like how The Sims does it).  I am loving this game so much and it has so much potential for development.  Bought it in Early Access and I can't wait to see how the 1.0 version turns out.  

The developers appear very active in the forums too, responding to players' questions and whatnot, which I consider a reassuring sign when buying something in Early Access.

The in-game bug reporter is very easy to use without interrupting the flow of your game.
Its a very engaging game with a good story line and lots of activity to do! A must play!!!

Don't be misled by the fact it is a business simulation game. It is in fact a business simulation game WITH A GREAT AMOUNT OF LIFE SIMULATION TOO. I would say the it is the sims (except big ambitions is MUCH MORE FUN) with deep and meaningful business and economy mechanics added into it (don't expect to kiss anyone though). Seriously it is not an exaggeration for the game to claim itself revolutionary. I personally can see myself sink hundreds of hour into this in the time ahead.

Personally I think this game is great, there a things that could make it even better, like more customization options for your character, or more objects to decorate or sell, more cars and “toys” to buy. But what’s currently built right now is still a great game. If you’re into the micromanaging, entrepreneurial, real life sim kind of games, pull the trigger on this one. 
Speaking of triggers, I think I speak for many people when I say an M rated crime based version or even add on to this already great game would be awesome. Like a modern version twist of what “Empire of Sin” could’ve been. Drugs, Counterfeiting, Rival “Families” to fight with or alongside. That kind of thing.

Big Ambitions designers are seeing big, but it's clear they have a vision and it is, in my opinion, an amazing one. This ultimate business tycoon is still in early access and it feels like the possibilities are endless. Manage multiple business, take care of the security, employees, products stock. Go ahead and meet with recruiters, gross resellers, law firms, marketing firms, etc. Really is impressive and I wish the best for what follows. Great Job Devs!

Bought this expecting a different game really, i'm really into my city / management games. This game has a totally different playstyle to other games I play and i'm in love! Very additive. The basis of the game is really simple, but I think its very much like Minecraft of "One more block" but instead "One more day"
Anyway, I quickly found out that I cannot drive GTA style as my car will just break on me and I couldn't afford to fix it so I was legging it around this city on foot grabbing my stock for my first shop. Then I fixed my car and could not find a parking space, my partner was like "Lol imagine if you got a parking ticket for parking there" AND I DID. BLOODY PARKING TICKET. 
I may have overspent getting stock for my first shop, so my 2nd business (fast food) has been slow going, and ive had to just hang around for a few days (nice time skip mechanic with sleep, or even playing games in your flat) but its never gotten boring. Even running around getting my own stock hasnt been boring.
Ive just gotten a purchasing person who is meant to make stock and deliveries way easier. 

Its quite a chill game, addictive, good price for the game. You need to be able to drive a car in game without crashing every few seconds though haha.
Im quite a few hours in and business wise i'm still right at the start but it doesn't feel slow going. Feels just right.

The game falls on the good side. While beginning is a lot of walking/ running and much less of the economic simulator, once you get to wholesalers, game gets much more automated and fun. Core gameplay is not hard, but is quite solid. 
Also game greatly shows big American dream - fast food costs much less than any healthy food, almost all people hired are part-timers, so you can skip on healthcare insurance, there is almost no public transport. Wage in supermarket is ridiculously high, it should have been lower to show everyday poverty cycle.
You cannot even afford a desk and computer until middle of scenario, so there are no options for entertainment for a long time.

190 hours in about a month and a half, the game is addicting. I have really enjoyed both games I have started. My first game I started on v0.3. For an early access game, I had very few issues. On my first play-through I reached a 50 million net worth with about 45 stores or so. When 0.4 came out I decided to start a new play-through as I didn't feel like figuring out what items needed to be fixed across all of my stores. 

There were of course some bugs on the new version but the dev team has been awesome about fixing them as quickly as they could even with the holiday's almost upon us. They dropped updates on the 13th, 14th and 23rd addressing the worst of the bugs.

[h2]Gameplay:[/h2]
I personally love this style of game. A bigger city and more business would be great, but I think it’s already really good and more fun than most business sims I have played. 0.4 improved the driving which was one of my biggest issues besides the office-based businesses. Both were fixed which has improved the game and made it more engaging and fun. Being able to build out your various businesses, headquarters, and distribution networks is really satisfying.

[h2]Areas that could improve:[/h2]
[h3]Late game:[/h3]
I feel like I am mostly just sleeping and doing all the happiness activities. So, it would be nice to see more activities and things to do in the city. I realize you can be very hands-on and design all of your stores, do your own deliveries etc, but I think most of us agree that would just get very repetitive and tedious.

[h3]Character models:[/h3]
Currently not the greatest and maybe some love will be given to them eventually.

[h3]Headquarters:[/h3]
The ability to move your HQ employees to a new HQ without losing your distribution plans, HR assigned employees, Purchase manager orders etc. Maybe a moving company could be added for when we want to move our HQ to a new location or something like that. Writing everything down when I upgrade to a new HQ is a pain.

[h3]Add a Store Designer:[/h3]
One thing that would make life really great, would be having a store designer. It could be software you buy for your computer that gives you a new activity to do on your computer. It could also boost your happiness instead of having to game all the time. My thought is you could choose one of the floor plans and the business type. Then you could fully design and layout our store, save the design, and have the interior designers install it. This system could also be used to preview downloaded blueprints so we can get a better view of them before we waste money installing a design that we are not happy with. The current blueprint system makes it tough to see the designs so a designer could solve that problem while making it easier for us to design our stores before we open them. Having a lot of shipments get dropped off and grabbing them 4 items at a time with a dolly can be a pain and is time consuming. 

[h2]Closing:[/h2]
Overall, I love the game, though I do partially agree with a couple of the negative reviews that say there isn't enough variety between businesses as far as managing them goes.

Thanks to the dev team for being responsive and quick to fix major bugs. Thanks to the community that has made so many helpful blueprints that have save me countless hours. Can’t wait to see what Big Ambitions brings in 2024!

Arguably the best multi-business tycoon game on the market. I have critiques but out of the myriad of options that sound similar to this on steam this is head and shoulders above them. If it sounds at all like your cuppa, you'll enjoy it.

Onward to critiques (made constructively)
Automating your resupply can be very annoying and you will need to long before you otherwise unlock the ability. For one or two businesses you can manage but if you aggressively expand not so much.
The ONE map is small and once you learn it it can dampen the fun of the game. Mod support or randomly generated cities would keep it fresh.
Markets behave without variation, they will perform as expected until the end of time.
Drastic income variation between store types, I'm not a fan of balance in games (because good balance gives you an illusion of choice) but come on now do that many people flood a jewelry shop? For all the hassle it is being a grocer, it is a poor way to make a buck.
My biggest complaint would be the combination of a lack of first person and a lack of multiplayer. Working together or in competition with your friends would make this game so much better.

Anyways, 10/10 but fix the driving.

After 24 hours, I think I've seen a bulk of what is offered here.  This is a fairly unique game, part business sim, part Sims Theft Auto minus stealing cars or having to shower and pee.  I like the driving aspect, it's integral to the immersion of the manual labors of starting out from scratch (which I love),  but at the same time, it does get annoying late game because I feel the natural flow of the game tends to go toward less manual operation and more automation, i.e. delivery routes and such.  I found myself sleeping, eating, playing video games in the apartment just to pass time while nothing was going on and then having to leave to do some manual labor, such as opening a new business.  All in all, a great experience, I can't wait try the finished product and hope that more content and depth are added.  It's nearly fine as is, but has much more potential.

Big Ambitions is one of the best games I've ever played. First of all, The sheer scale of New York City is daunting and really adds to the stress and tasks of obtaining stock, going to the bank, etc. Second, the market system is great despite being in early access. It's simple to figure out whats in demand but difficult to determine where that business would be the most profitable and that's a good thing. Lastly, longevity is great for a small title like this. Starting a business is easy enough but making one that's profitable and expanding into other markets is where the challenge comes in. I'll admit I'm at a point where I make $30K a day so it's very easy to go into new markets or open new stores. My hope is in the future, there will be more products / industries to enter and hopefully there can be more to do such as mixed stores, big box stores, real estate business etc.

Overall, just a fantastic game! worth the buy.

Early Access - Review -

I like the game and find it fun but I have a few issues & suggestions.

It would be nice to have the ability to detach the camera from the player. When the player exits a vehicle the camera should point in the direction of the vehicle and not flip around. When player exits a building the camera should face the player and not flip behind the building.

Some items are not found in logical places - Example shelving to store product is found in the appliance store and not the furniture store.

A few items feel pointless - In a small restaurants booths are useless because they only seat one customer. (This may not matter if you are not babysitting a restaurant)  The player can't rest on couches but can sleep on benches? What is the stove for in the furniture store I thought maybe for cooking frozen food but nope. Do restaurant boards have any impact on the business? It seems the only metrics that matter are cash registers, Product holders, employee skill and traffic index. 

The game should also have a metric for product pricing. I've played around with it but going much over a few bucks has a very negative impact on the business. 

After setting up a few businesses furnishing them becomes very tedious and some kind of blueprint system really needs to be added. When you order on the phone to have stuff delivered it should auto fill a blueprint. Also we should be able to upgrade the dolly to the cart you get in the furniture store that holds 6 boxes so you can move more stuff in one shot.

I want to be able to buy a box of fresh food and stuff it in my fridge at home. Or I would like to put an industrial fridge and storage in my apartment and have my logistics fill it for me. But you would need to allow the player to eat it right out of the industrial fridge without a bag.

I would like to be able to take out a specific amount of money from the bank on an investment and not the entire thing.

I don't like that you can't eat at a restaurant you own. (Food feels like more of an annoyance then a game feature).

It would be nice if you could purchase an upgrade to add auto park to cars and vans that don't have it which is all of them except the exotic cars.

A hide walls feature would be nice especially in smaller spaces.

Boats should have a purpose other then a prop that let's you relax especially because they are so expensive. Also they should fill your food meter because of the annual cost.

Fulfilling achievement tasks should not be a metric for your players happiness. Everything else seems fine for this.

Purchasing a building feels very underwhelming with very little return on investment. (You can spend 40 million on a building and only get $1,000 a day). Yet you can have a business in the smallest building and get $20,000 a day. You can spend $500,000,000 and only get $20,000 a day. And unless you exploit the casino or cheat it will take a very long time to save up to buy a building.

As soon as I started playing "Big Ambitions," I was immediately drawn in by the stunning graphics and engaging storyline. The game's premise is simple - you play as a young person with big dreams, and you must work your way up the ladder to achieve them.The game offers a variety of different paths to success, from starting your own business to climbing the corporate ladder. Each path is unique and requires different skills and strategies, which keeps the game fresh and exciting.One thing I really appreciate about "Big Ambitions" is its emphasis on personal growth and development. As you progress through the game, you are constantly challenged to improve your skills and knowledge in order to succeed. This not only makes for a more engaging gameplay experience, but it also encourages players to take a growth mindset approach to their own lives.The game's soundtrack is also worth noting - it's upbeat and energizing, which really helps to set the tone for the game. The sound effects are also well-done, adding an extra level of immersion to the gameplay.Overall, I would highly recommend "Big Ambitions" to anyone who enjoys strategy games and is looking for a positive, uplifting gaming experience. With its beautiful graphics, engaging storyline, and focus on personal growth and development, "Big Ambitions" is sure to keep you entertained for hours on end.

This is a very enjoyable game. For anyone who wants to take a shot at building up their own business, or a corporation of multiple businesses and locations, check this game out! You can choose to do this in your own style, name your businesses, decorate and use various items and materials to make it your own. There are several factors to manage and design including business function and paths to success, public opinion and response to your business as well as general supply and demand, personal and employee needs and happiness, employee schedules and store operation days and times, and much more. There is a certain resemblance to The Sims and GTA, with the ability to traverse and discover the city, exploring different businesses and shops that offer various things a player may use to develop their own business. As you further your own success and gain wealth, you can even level up your own apartment and style your home and offices however you like.

I am very much enjoying the game and look forward to future game development and expansion. The existing items are great and functional, and I'd love to see additional options come available as well. This is an excellent game, I would highly recommend 9/10 with room for additional features to really top everything off. Great job, devs! I am excited for continued development and more features to come!

Big potential in every area of business because it is limitless for this game. Gives you a thousands of hours to play, including both micro and macro management, still got some points to be improved, enhanced, changed or fixed but definitely worth buying and exchanging your life.

I don't usually take the time to review steam games but on this occasion I will as the game is awesome! I have managed to spend a lot of hours on here without even feeling like I have. I hope the developers read this as this game has so much potential and I wouldn't even mind spending £5-10 on future add-ons. 

Just some ideas of add-ons / game modes that I think would be great:

- Gangster / Mobsters add-on - We run legit businesses to grow... why not add a dark side so we can run different businesses which are illegal - make more money but risk of getting caught / fined etc

- Resource production + factory production - If we could expand the map to farmlands / big brown belt sites to start factories to cut out the middle man of importing to maximise profits. Start a lumberjack, to send to a factory to make paper bags to send to our warehouses to our stores for use... the scope of detail that could be added is great and if this can be done for all products would be awesome.

- Family - Maybe a little bit "sims" like, but could definitely explore the option of having a partner you have to keep happy and children that you can pass the game / business on to. If you have neither you risk the game ending so it adds a more realistic feel to the game. If you get married and you don't take the partner out, you risk losing a hefty divorce settlement!

- Online mode! I'd love to compete against other humans or have a co-op campaign on the go I can play with friends!

UI Features that could be cool:

- Add indicators to vehicles that users can use
- When the user presses F1 for help - allow us to move this window around so we can have it open on all screens etc and click other menus to navigate easier

Downsides:

The only downside I see of this game atm with any sandbox - once you have mastered the basics it can potentially become tedious. This is why I am hoping down the line future add-on and features can be added to keep us hooked. 
My main goal at the moment is to do all achievements and literally own the whole map!

If anyone read all this - I highly recommend!

Big Ambitions, currently standing at 6/10, offers a promising gameplay experience with room for improvement. The game's diverse mechanics and engaging concepts show potential. However, the absence of multiplayer functionality feels like a missed opportunity. Collaborative play could elevate the game, enhancing teamwork and strategic depth. Despite this lacking feature, the core game earns its merits. With the addition of a well-executed multiplayer mode, Big Ambitions could evolve into an outstanding title, offering players an immersive and interactive experience. Here's to hoping the developers consider this addition, turning a good game into a great one for players seeking cooperative adventures.

Big Ambitions is a contender for the most aptly named game out there. This surprise title is brimming with potential and incredibly addictive gameplay right from the start. But can it hold your attention while you work and/or gamble your way to becoming the next big business magnate?

The game starts quite realistically. You have no money, no car and no place to stay, which is a pretty awful thing when you live in New York City. Luckily, your rich uncle steps up to act as your mentor, tells you to grab a small business loan and to rent a place for yourself to live in as well as a property to open a tiny gift shop in. Right from the get-go, you can't help but be impressed by what the game is promising to be. You control your own character at all times, but can manage deliveries, staff and other things via your phone. You outfit your own store yourself, by purchasing individual furniture pieces, loading them into your car, driving down to the shop and then grabbing them one by one to place them. One look at the map shows you that nearly every building in the game is purchaseable and can act as either a home, a warehouse or a place to run a business in. This gets you hooked, makes you want to put in the effort to eventually own most of the city. Maybe you could control the entire liquor market and create artificial shortages to manipulate the demand... The possibilities seem endless, especially once your uncle tells you that demand for certain products fluctuates and is also different for each neighbourhood.

This is the part of the review where I finally tell you why it is marked as a negative one. The phenomenal early game experience simply does not last. After opening a couple of businesses, you quickly realise that you've already hit the end game. There is very little difference between running a tiny corner shop versus a gigantic jewelry emporium in the heart of the city, with the exception being that larger stores are a pain to furnish. It feels great to outfit your starter shop yourself, grabbing individual shelves from the back of your car and placing them with care, but having to do the same for a large clothes store that needs you to place over 40 clothes racks to satisfy customer capacity gets dull very fast. There are no options to automate the more tedious aspects of the game later on, which puts a dampener on the experience. It would have been great to be able to save a template for your stores that you can later apply to others you open, to save you some manual labour. Isn't being rich all about just throwing money at stuff so you don't have to do anything? Let me pay some muscle to get my store ready for me, thank you.
Even if you enjoy manually furnishing your businesses, you'll likely never even set foot back in them once they're up and running. Hiring and training staff is done through menus, as is assigning them to their work schedules. Once that's done, you automate the supply line using a warehouse and your HQ workers, the purchase and logistics agents. Again, you unfortunately cannot just tell the people you pay to handle your logistics to actually handle your logistics autonomously. You will need to set exact purchase limits and frequencies, as well as how much stock your stores should receive. Optimising this is a matter of watching the balance for a few days, then adjusting, then leaving it forever (or until you open another business that uses the same goods). It would have been nice to have an option to let some skilled managers handle this aspect as well once you're so rich that you really can't be bothered anymore.

The need for manual micro management on your part makes buying out other businesses more of a tedium. They do come pre-furnished, but often need a few extra pieces that you will have to lug on over. Then, you will need to integrate your new acquisition into your supply chain by adjusting the imports and stock levels and assigning HQ agents to it. Tedious!
Now, you would think that with such a heavy focus on micro management, there would be lots of things to actually manage. Tons of different products, maybe from different suppliers and/or countries. Rare artisan products with huge individual profit magins versus mass produced garbage that sells really well. Unfortunately, not really. Again, in the early game you are almost delusional at the prospect of running many different kinds of shops, but ultimately, there is only a handful of business types available. These are split into shops and offices. Offices are totally hands-off once you assign employees and maybe buy some marketing for them, they'll just start generating passive income. Shops are slightly more involved in that they need a supply chain, but you only ever have to worry about a handful of products. Gift shops for instance can only sell three types of goods: Cheap gifts, expensive gifts and soda cans. Meh. I would have liked more variety maybe. Same with the building interiors, these are the same for all properties and only vary by size and type of business. Some unique designs would have been awesome.

I believe the game is struggling with its own identity. It wants to be a business sim, but it has a bunch of life sim aspects in it that slow it down. But neither aspect is 100% fleshed out, so ultimately, they both fall just short of being great. This game is almost amazing. It's so unique and it conjurs up images of old-school business tycoons but it just doesn't reach that level of complexity. Once you have a comfortable enough passive income (which is not hard to achieve), you lack motivation to move on. From that point, it's closer to an AFK clicker game than a business sim, open another few stores to watch that number go up, done. Reaching the zenith of New York high society should feel like a rush, instead it is a sad realization that you've exhausted what fun you had in the game. Maybe that's a hidden message to us, the audience, that money cannot buy happiness?

I will say that the game is still in Early Access, so additional business types and goods can easily be added, as well as features such as auto-furnish or auto-balancing supply chains. However, I'm not sure how the actual end game can be improved with just more content.

I can't deny that this is an addictive game. I've been playing for 30 hours and still want to continue growing my bussiness. However, and I know that this is a work in progress and devs are working hard to bring new features, I have to say that the more your bussiness expands the harder it gets to keep track of everything while still having fun. These are my issues:

- When you have a large list of bussinesses it's hard to find them in the open menus (you  have to scroll down, but they are not in chronological nor alphabetical order)
- It could be nice to have a button to speed up time, since there is not a bunch of things to do out of your bussiness. I find myself most of the time sleeping for 24 hours so the time goes by faster. 
- I understand the idea of calling to order furniture and reaching out marketing and recruitment agencies. But it would be nice to use the "internet" or some thing to place the orders without having to wait for the store to open.
- Ordering a taxi from your phone would be also nice, instead of just running around trying to catch one. 
- I would appreciate having a way of moving things internally, from a warehouse to another warehouse, from one store to another, without having me to go physically. It seems unrealistic that a guy with millions in his bank account would do that. Maybe a new worker: operations managers?
- It would be also cool that furniture had an impact in the likeability of the bussiness, not only walls and floor. 

But as I said, the game is lovely and I'm enjoying it very much. Can't wait for the coming updates!

The fact this game is still in early access is insane, what a great job done by the dev team. Ive spent almost 40 hours this week getting familiar and exploring and expanding. I cannot wait for the next update and I have definitely found a new favorite game. Highly recommend to anyone who loves tycoon management games like i do. Despite it being early access as well, the bugs are minimal and the features are incredible. Do NOT sleep on this one.

So... I have been waiting for Big Ambitions to be released my whole 2022; it was a big game launch to expect from. Let me say that my whole year up to August 2022, when the game was first supposed to launch, had me anxious for it. Six months passed by, and I got tired of waiting for the game and decided to give up on it.

March of this year, I was very hurt, and my resentment just wouldn't let me give the game a go. Fast forward to about half of the year, and my cousin lent me his account to play the game with (or at least test it). Today I have at least 100 hours of gameplay and gave, for the first time, a go for my much-awaited game.

Let me just say that I already love the game more than I already used to. The amount of details, furniture, cars, city structures, and the inside and outside of buildings, even the BizMan UI is perfect.

-> If you want to know whether you should or not buy this game, coming from a big admirer of managing games, Coursing Business, who has played over 20 managing simulators all across Steam, I would love to tell you that this is the prime of the prime, the best game you can get related to the genre of companies and realistically dealing with people, resources, and the market. Trust me, it is worth your money and, most importantly, your time.

Also, Devs, I loved what you did with the NY Distro delivery system and delivery fee. To me, it works like a charm; it is a great form of automating my businesses, and having it gives the game a lot more of a real business sense and feeling.

I enjoyed this game very much for the first 40 hours, then tried doing a custom run and doing everything from scratch is quite boring. I kind of regret deleting my initial run but I was starting to get bored anyways. Great game with huge potential though!

Absolutely love this game! Love all things management sim, but am a pretty casual player. At first, everything was a bit overwhelming bc I have not played this intense of a game before, BUT that brings me to the most pleasant surprise! The help UI is phenomenal, everything is interlinked/inter-referenced, so if youre starting a new-to-you business, you can find it in the help, then click on a product, which will tell you the places you can get it, which you can click on to open in the in game map. The tutorial was fine enough, but with that much of a resource, I found I preferred to figure the game out organically. I will add though that it took me a little longer than Im proud of to figure out the headquarter's function or really how to use it, but I might be a little slow on that.

For me this is about as close as a 10/10 game could be, so this isnt meant as critique, but more things that need some tweaking in my personal opinion. Right now the driving option is kinda not the best. It seems like the goal is to set it up to be one of the better transportation options in game, but for ease alone I prefer walking/using the subway. I think a couple things would fix that. It's a little outdated, but I wonder if having a slightly cost prohibitive option to purchase alongside the car that could offer sat-nav type thing where you could open the map and then pick a spot and it would autodrive you, I think that could make cars more attractive. Or having something like a bike available, either for purchase or rent to lend a middle ground in ease of use/availability.

I also find it a little frustrating that all companies use a handtruck, with a storage capacity of 4, when the god tier ika flatbed w/a storage capacity of 8 exists. I understand it wouldnt make sense in all locations, but somewhere like AJ Pedersons or the wholesalers, I think it would make sense to have there instead of running over, stealing a flatbed and then trying not to leave the lot without it.

Also for early game, a couple more beginner jobs would be very fun to have, but that's honestly so cosmetic + doesnt affect gameplay long term so it's just for fun.

I cant wait to keep playing this game and I cant stress enough how obsessed I am with it currently, so the above-mentioned tweaks are really just me getting SUPER into this and thinking how I personally would flesh it all out!

[b]Big Ambitions: An Entrepreneurial Adventure in a Vibrant Open World[/b]

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

My initial impression of Big Ambitions was immediately positive. The game offers an extensive and realistic experience of entrepreneurship in an open world, setting it apart from other business simulation games.

In Big Ambitions, you have the freedom to establish and manage various types of businesses, from gift shops to jewelry stores. What truly sets the game apart is its ability to allow you to respond to the city's demand and adapt your businesses accordingly, adding depth to the gameplay.

One challenge I encountered was managing the inventory of my stores. In the beginning, I had to keep an eye on my stock and make purchases manually, but later in the game, I invested in an office building and warehouse to better manage my inventory.

One of the highlights of Big Ambitions is that the developers actively listen to player feedback. After I expressed a desire to see the option for part-time and full-time employees, it was quickly added in an update.

An achievement I'm proud of is successfully managing multiple thriving businesses and paying off all loans at the bank. This allowed me to generate even more profit and continue expanding to new businesses, office buildings, and warehouses.

I would definitely recommend Big Ambitions to gamers interested in entrepreneurship. It provides a playful yet realistic glimpse into running a business and is ideal for those looking to experience what it's like to be an entrepreneur. Big Ambitions is a fantastic opportunity to pursue your entrepreneurial ambitions, albeit in a virtual world.
LOVE THE BUSINESS ASPECT OF THE GAME ALMOST LIKE YOU ARE RUINING A REAL BUSINESS

This is a fun little business economy management sim! It has some features I wish other economy games like American Truck and European Truck Simulator had, mainly the ability to own your own home and upgrade it over time as your wealth grows.  It is similar to the Sims in that regard but at it's core of the game it is a well crafted business model simulator.

 It would be fun to see it develop some of the Sims style social interactions where you can meet and make friends and start relationships, etc. 

Fun game that scratches some itches other sims in the genre aren't with an addictive game play loop.

My favorite expansion for The Sims was The Sims 2: Open For Business.  Sims 3 and Sims 4 never had features that satisfied me in the same way this simple blend of business simulation and interior design satisfied me.  Big Ambitions takes everything I loved about that expansion and builds an entire game around it!

A lot of other business sims, such as Mad Games Tycoon and Two Point Hospital, lack the interior design gameplay that I loved about The Sims 2.  Although options are still limited in Early Access, this game really leans into the interior design aspect and I am confident that we will be able to create some really cool businesses at full release.  I can't wait to see where this goes!

With 32 hours under my belt I'm loving all the variety the game has! Do I feel like decorating my locations, opening a new store, furnishing my own apartment? Who knows what I'll do today. As a lover of Sim City and the Sims, this game is like Grand Theft Auto and The Sims had a baby. I love it. I can't wait to open my next business.

Incredible game, even if it’s early access stage. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Loads of business’s to run
- in-depth logistics networks 
- Devs are active on discord, everyone is very helpful 
- Constant updates to improve player experience 
- Always something to do

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Some bugs which is to be expected with a new game

I really really enjoy this game, and highly recommend anyone give it a try. However part of me wishes I waited so I could of experienced the game for the first time on a full release which will be a game changer.

such an underrated game. It will have your attention for an extremely long time. The developers continue to add amazing updates and truly listen to their fan base! especially with this new update adding blueprints. I highly recommend this game to everyone!

I need a driver !!!

This game is very addicting and fun. It has some great elements and while it can seem very micro-management in the beginning, you can quickly grow to to automate things. There are still some QOL updates that need to happen, however, each update they improve many of those things. 

The biggest complaint I have with the game is it needs to stop trying to be The Sims. It really kills the game having to get back to the apartment to sleep, and then trying to manage happiness and hunger. There is already a game that does this, The Sims, no need to add that to this one. There should be a way to toggle this feature on or off, so those that want to use this as a Business Builder can do just that. 

QOL updates I would love to see (EA as of 0.3)
- Toggle on/off the Sleep, Happiness and Hunger
- Ability to request a taxi from anywhere
- When items are delivered, have the pallet delivered inside your shop (or an easy way to move the entire pallet into your shop instead of 4 items at time on the hand truck)
- Pause time when making adjustments inside of Bizman (lost an entire day when I was optimizing a few things)
- Ability to quickly look inside of a building without having to travel to it
- Ability to turn off damage on vehicles (I avoid driving because driving is so bad in this game, and the vehicle gets damaged so quickly. Instead, I scooter or taxi everywhere) 
- Multi-select racks/shelves for moving together easily OR changing product type. (Takes forever to change each clothing rack in a set of 8, and then to do all 64 of them in your store if you sell all 8 clothing products)
Waaaaay too much "go here, fetch that", and not enough time for actual business management. Not fun.
Good game. Very addicting. This game reminds me of stick rpg 1 and 2 as far as progression and just owning stuff.
This game is so addicting. It's really satisfying to build up your businesses and to see that first big paycheck!

They fixed the issues that were made with the 0.2 update.
The game is a fun daddy Trump simulator again
Must have!

Most recent update has broken save, even when devs said it wouldn't.

Had a blast playing this game on initial release, stopped after 38 playtime to wait for more gameplay updates. Went back to play again after a few decent looking updates, seeing that the devs had said that you could update your save or leave that save on the old version. 

Started up the game and I was greeted with a message saying there had been an update and asking if I wanted to update my save, which I clicked yes. Then clicked 'Continue' and I was greeted with another message, with my only options being to delete or move the save file, or close the dialogue box. Neither of the first two options actually did anything, so I just closed the game. 40 hours I'll never get back, I guess.

That being said, I would say that it's worth picking up if it's on discount, just be aware that you might lose your saves when they release big updates.

(2nd review after 383hrs) This is a fun game to play but FK me is it annoying hiring staff to work in your business, 1st of all Employment Agencies meet the employers demands (full or part time) constantly getting low percentage part timers who tell you what there going to work an how often or what time of day they prefer...I'm paying them to recommend a suitable employee not a bunch of lazy dumb a ss useless morons expecting me to pay for them to train to a better percentage an let them tell me that there only working mornings 4 days a week...£500 to get garbage, can I open up an employment agency an show them how it's done properly, obviously the developer spent most of COVID lockdown furnishing empty buildings and adding annoying info panels that pop up on every single building your not interested in instead of working on the annoying parts, hired a 50% full timer trained her twice now at 70% customers say "Rude not coming back here" the two other full timers in before her are 43% & 47% no customers call them Rude...customers telling me to wear a Uniform where's my comeback "get the fk out my business you a sshole I own the company I'll wear what I like your barred".

 A few tips for new players don't bother painting or tiling floors in the whole shop just add 1 stripe of paint on 1 wall stops "Ugly floor & Walls" comment,

Don't waste $300 on a loudspeaker there's a small $80 speaker on the computer desk further into the furniture store,

Buy what you need even if you don't have room in your vehicle an leave outside the store/warehouse it doesn't despawn an go an pick up later,

 Rent Uncle (Annoying) Freddy's friends apartment for 1 night pick up & pack bed leave an rent a shop terminate your tenancy with the apartment an live in the store room of your shop you'l get your $1300 deposit back to spend on the business when you have the cash rent a better place with parking outside instead of that annoying building Freddy wants you to rent were you can only park at the end of the street...cheap rent my a ss there's the same building in the next street for $800 deposit an it's only $26 rent a day the developer thought you'd do this so you take -50% happiness don't worry it's only for few days.
 
The loading screen saying "After you visit various locations you can call them" it lies you have to find the person sitting behind the desk in each building to start an order/account, heads up talk to the useless Employment Agency before you take the Basic management course you can call them straight away after you complete the course as long as it's before 5pm.

Ordering multiple deliveries (10am - 2pm) to the same location at the same time doesn't work there's only 1 drop off point outside buildings so if you have a delivery at 10am clear it away before the 2pm one turns up an don't order multiple deliveries outside at the same time, warehouse deliveries get delivered to storage inside so it doesn't effect those,
 
Don't think every Start has the same buildings to rent leave an create a new Start you might get better buildings (1000sqm buildings, better buildings with higher traffic), If you want to make cash quickly open up a clothes shop (8 clothes racks & soda) in Hells Kitchen with 72 Traffic (look by the right side near the Ramp) it will make $30k a day after a few days of opening...Don't wait for Freddy to tell you when to start a business do it on Day 2 (if you do a 24hr Advanced Management course is needed to start a 2nd business if you want to follow Uncle Fred's tips later on)...Enjoy, Oh an eat twice quickly it stops your food going down until you sleep again...low food = energy dropping faster.
