This is going to need a lot of work. The ideas behind it are sound, and I wish I could persevere with it, but as it stands it's virtually unplayable. The mouse is alternately unresponsive or massively over-sensitive. It is almost impossible to enter buildings without finding the exact correct place to click, and as they do not tell you where to click, it can take almost all one game day to get inside. Then, it's often past  game bedtime (sleep, and planning it, is crucial to success) before you can actually do the things you're supposed to do. The graphics are good but incredibly slow and jerky, even on the lowest possible settings, and this is a brand new Mac with 48GB memory. It's frustrating beyond belief and I've simply had to give up. It IS in beta, so you can expect some problems, but this, unlike its superb predecessor Startup Company, is light years away from being finished. It is also not cheap either.

It's a decent spreadsheets sim, coupled with a middling car game that doesn't age well, and the potential complexity of RPG mechanics it tackles by not having any. At least not in any meaningful way that adds any layer of fun, as of yet.

I loved it at first, but the further I progressed, the less I cared about piloting a little toon around an empty, static city full of indestructible road cones. 

It's not a terrible game, by all means, it's quite addictive for a while. 
I tend to leave these games paused a lot on a side monitor, so my steam ingame hours are inaccurate. I would guesstimate I got ~40-50hrs out of it, maybe a bit more, which isn't too bad overall. But once the game loop feels like it's getting stale, it's suddenly steep downhill from there.

You have no friends, no family, not even a pet. Driving boxes around stops being fun. The game suddenly feels very repetitive. 
Once you're done setting up some different shops, you have some cars that are mostly crap and some yachts that are glorified beds. 

The sports/luxury cars either slide all over the place, are ridiculously expensive to fix, are too big for the narrow streets.. I didn't find myself enjoying them much. Some of them are ok, but ultimately I just felt like they revealed the weaknesses of the car portion of the game, more than feel like an upgrade. 

They are adding stuff, but so far the DJ booth, the gym, they are the same simple mechanic as the TV/PC etc. They've added some animations so that helps make it a little more visually appealing, but it's still still just gloss and cosmetic variation.

It's not a terrible game, by all means, it's quite addictive for a while. 
I tend to leave these games paused a lot on a side monitor, so my steam ingame hours are inaccurate. But I would say I got ~40-50hrs out of it, maybe a bit more, which isn't too bad overall.
The concept is great, and it's early EA, so this may, or may not, change in the future.

Negative review? Mostly because I feel they use very bold language for selling this game. 
The devs seem quite active, and do a lot of things right, but I've never heard them mention anything other than cosmetic variations of what's already in the game. Modding, as it was described when I read it, also seemed fairly limited in scope.
Great game if you like management simulations!

I changed this review from not recommended to recommended as the devs are really listening to the players and putting out updates that add lots of content and QoL changes.

Original review here;

As of now, it's an EA title with a good foundation, now the devs need to start drilling for some depth.

I could tell you what's wrong or right with the game at this point but instead I'm going to throw out some ideas about how the game could improve, in hope the devs will pick up on it.

First, creating a business is a chore, clicking multiple times to place 1 item at a time is not fun.
My idea; implement a shop layout/blueprint mode where you have free choice of items to use and place in a blueprint. Then allow me to order everything I used in that blueprint from the stores. Allow them to place it all on my doorstep and allow me to call a move company to set the shop up in the exact way I have put it in my blueprint. 

Second, employees need more details. All employees are the same entities and don't have any skills or traits besides being either a worker or a cleaner. The only difference is a worker can clean but a cleaner can't work the cash register. Once you trained them to 100% they will be as good in a gift store as they'll be in a restaurant.
My idea; Add cooks to stand behind the pizza over or burger grill. This way it's not 1 person taking the order, making the food and packing it up. Add traits to employees, e.g. socialy strong (more friendly towards customers), focused (makes more burgers an hour), etc. This adds more tactics involved in selecting/hiring employees.

Third; Hiring people should be way easier. 
My idea; More filters. Make me select if I'm looking for full/part-time workers. Ticks for traits/specilizations, which cost more money to recruit and also more money to hire.

And lastly, the whole business model needs a rework. I was having a ton of fun until I realized my clothes shop made 45k a day and my restaurant was only making 150 bucks a day. I turned my restaurant into another clothes store and by the 2nd day it was already making a profit of 25k a day. No use in setting up anything else but clothing stores as of now. Even the jewelry, which I tweaked a lot, ended up making a merely 14k a day profit. This bummed me out and made me write up this review.

I hope the devs have a use for this review and this game will eventually reach its full potential. Untill then I can't recommend it in its current state as its just too shallow for a business sim.

While keeping in mind this game is in early access, I would recommend this game. However that being said, The first save file was corrupted and I had to restart my game 20 hours in. I did restart, but if it were to happen again I would probably push playing the game off until it's further along. I like how realistic the game is, I'm excited to see what else they have in store for us as it develops.

Q: Do you recommend this game?
A: Yes, I hereby absolutely recommend this game.

Q: Can you give us some detail about this game and why it is worth it?
A: Well, you often hear about an early access game which is really well developed despite the fact that it isn´t completed, but BIG AMBITIONS has so many aspects already implemented, it took me 26+ hours and I´m still not fed up. You start with little money and your uncle gives you some advice on how to start businesses. It is clearly a tutorial, but it doesn´t feel like you are following dull how-to-play-instructions. We are just at 0.2 version, but there are already several business types, a lot of diverse furniture types, a nice variety of cars to buy etc.

Q: Is there any aspect you would love to have improved by the developers?
A: Of course BIG AMBITIONS is far from perfect. For example I would love to get the chance to interact more with my surroundings like other citizens or create a network of people who can help me out or I could help them out. Finding a partner would be a nice addition, too. Getting kids, move into the suburbs etc.

Q: For those fellow steamers who have no clue what to expect, what is BIG AMBITIONS like gameplaywise?
A: Good thing you ask (I am clearly not asking myself!)! BIG AMBITIONS is a mixture of Plutocracy, GTA 1&2, SIMS, The Guild and - this one hurts me the most - Project Zomboid.

Q: Wow, that´s some fruity salad of games. But why does the last one hurt you so much?
A: Project Zomboid decays since 10 Years in my Steam-Library without fullfilling it´s initial promise. Why is a game like BIG AMBITIONS everything Project Zomboid apparently can never be? You got the top down view, the furniture, the cars, the npcs, the buildings, why is it so damn difficult to develope a story which includes clean scripted encounters with non-playables? What do you need a dacade to program the minimum while Hovgaard Games achieves more in a year? Why are there...

Q: You are losing focus, bro...
A: I´m sorry, I am very passionate about this one ... . Buy this game BIG AMBITIONS deserves a lot of credit. Bravo to Hovgaard Games! I´m out bit**es! F*** Project Zomboid *sad*

"Big Ambitions" is a PC game that lives up to its name, offering players a chance to dream big and chase their virtual aspirations with an array of gameplay mechanics and challenges. While relatively new and not as widely known, this game proves that even small titles can pack a big punch in terms of enjoyment and engagement.

Expanding Horizons:

From the moment I started playing "Big Ambitions," I was drawn into a world where my dreams were the limit. The game's diverse range of objectives, from building an empire to achieving personal milestones, truly encapsulated the essence of ambition. Whether it was expanding my business empire or mastering a complex skill, each accomplishment felt like a step closer to realizing my in-game dreams.

Diverse Gameplay:

One of the standout features of "Big Ambitions" is its diverse gameplay. Players can expect a variety of challenges that cater to different interests, from strategic decision-making to skill mastery. This diversity keeps the game engaging, ensuring that there's always something new to tackle, no matter what your ambitions may be.

Navigating Challenges:

"Big Ambitions" doesn't shy away from presenting players with hurdles and obstacles. From managing resources effectively to making tough choices that impact the course of the game, every decision felt consequential. These challenges added depth and substance, making my progress all the more rewarding.

Rising Above:

The sense of accomplishment in "Big Ambitions" is genuinely satisfying. As I worked my way through the game's objectives, I felt a sense of pride in overcoming the challenges it presented. This journey mirrored the real world in its portrayal of setbacks and triumphs, making it both relatable and enjoyable.

Conclusion: Aspirations Unleashed

"Big Ambitions" may not have made waves in the mainstream gaming scene yet, but it certainly impressed me with its potential and depth. From tackling strategic decisions to honing my skills, the game provided an immersive experience that resonated with my own ambitions. In a world where dreams seem limitless, "Big Ambitions" offers a virtual space to chase after them, reminding players that with determination and effort, they can achieve anything they set their minds to.

I wasn't sure whether to invest in this game, but now I'm counting my profits of joy. It's not just loaded with potential; it's already dividend-ing out a fantastic gaming experience.

If you've got a financial forecast that tells you this game is your kind of stock, or if you find yourself checking the market for it repeatedly, consider this your bull market signal – go ahead and buy it. Your investment will yield great returns in enjoyment, and you'll also be backing the developers to make this game a real blue-chip"

The trailer had me worried it might be too liquid and shallow, but as I audit the game, I'm thrilled with the compound interest of challenges and gradual learning (I'm diving straight into hard mode for my first financial venture).

Of course, there's room for a little market correction in terms of polish (just skim the discussions in the game's  community hub), but my portfolio of fun is seeing some impressive growth.

If this game's prospectus catches your eye, consider it a capital gain to buy. Your gaming portfolio will thank you.

The start of every play through is relatively enjoyable but gets very tedious and boring considering there isn't much to do, would love to see relationships, road rules, more options for items to sell instead of just a broad term like "frozen foods" it could be divided into "frozen chicken", "frozen beef" etc so you can actually utilise the store better. I would love to see my staff move around e.g. the cleaners should actually be seen walking around to clean. Additionally, the AI drivers who roam the city need to be improved, you would be reversing or simply changing lanes and they will just completely smash right into you regardless of how far you are. In general we need more leisure activities to do, and the actual ability to sit and eat our food instead of eating everything from a paper bag. The walking animations should of been worked on ages ago, even before release, how can you be content with a life sim game where the person walks like an alien. The UI needs to be improved, including making certain actions more clear like when training your staff. A tip or small tutorial feature would be helpful (myself and others included needed to do research on the internet to figure this out). I've noticed when visiting stores that the line would get ridiculously large because the game kept spawning people without knowing the speed of the cashiers. (e.g. i would enter a cafe, I'm first to enter generally, I then take a look at the menu for a second, next minute there's like 30 people lining up for "coffee"). It would be helpful to have a feature to customise where the queue begins and ends. I know others probably agree with me as well, but there needs to be a way to check the "current" sales throughout that day and total earnings for that day. Instead of a weekly estimate of what items were sold, a daily would be more helpful since the business is constantly growing and it would be more useful to know how many burgers are being sold today with the stat being counted. I love the whole idea of this game and thus i didn't give it a negative review to scare people away, but there definitely needs to be huge change in order to retain their player base.

The Sims and Factorio(ish) rolled into one.

When I first launched this game I didn't think it would be any good. The options to create an avatar were very dated and limited and the graphics looked awful in the menus. However, in the game, things are much better. After playing the story mode for the game (don't just try playing it on your own as you will struggle), I've found this to be an amazing game. If you have ever wanted to start a small business, this is the game for you. You find yourself running to and from the cash and carry in your clapped out car, trying to park in awkward spots without getting another dent. Running the stores yourself until you can afford to hire staff and getting by with just the bare bones until you can afford improvements. You even get an apartment to furnish as you have spare cash to do so. It's actually a pretty compelling game and there is soooooo much to create and do in it, I don't think you could quickly get bored! FANTASTIC GAME, KEEP GOING WITH THE DEVELOPMENT.

Firstly, this is one of the best performing early access games I've played in a long time. I haven't had to deal with any lagging or crashing at all. Kudos to the development team!

As far as gameplay, I found the first 8 hours to be engaging, playing in stints of 3-4 hours at a time. I really enjoyed the element of being able to drive to locations, rather than just pointing and clicking and I also liked that it's a legitimate challenge to keep your needs taken care of while also pouring the time you need to into your business. My two biggest gameplay suggestions would be to expand the number of items available for sale in various shops and to add more options for interacting with customers and employees.

I love the graphic quality and was pleasantly surprised at how realistic objects and buildings look. The people need to have the same depth applied  as currently they basically look like sticks in the midst of an otherwise realistic world. The world itself is big enough for my taste, but I'd suggest adding a few more types of buildings that can be explored in free time. 

I noticed many reviewers saying that it stops being fun after approximately 10 hours. I haven't noticed that yet personally, but will update this review if I find that when I've played a few more hours. It would appear to me that replayability would be high since you can play in a non-story mode where you make all your own choices rather than following quests. More development of how to use your free time (and how to have more of it) would improve replayability as well. Obviously, I can't say for sure yet, but I expect that as you are able to hire more employees, free time might increase.

Overall, I'd give this game a B+ as is. I expect that by the time it's ready for regular release, I'll be updating that to an A.

I still feel that this area could use some improvements as some of the demands from employees are a little confusing, demands such as "peaceful working" which actually means your players happiness level must be at 50-75%. More businesses would be great such as running your own gym, or your own Gas Station or along them lines. Overall i think this is going in the right direction and i really enjoyed a few hours here and there.

Great game! The feeling which you have of starting on your own with very limited supplies and help available and when you see first money come in is really quite unique. Definitely would recommend to buy and play and I will happily revisit it once it progresses a bit down the development roadmap.
Currently at some point it becomes a bit tedious when progressing above certain level (I am easily bored by tediousness relatively to most players) - the way to improve it would be:
- improved hiring / recruitment - currently only available via text messages which is a bit tough when you need to hire more than a couple people ([i]on the dev roadmap[/i])
- interior blueprints ([i]on the dev roadmap[/i]) / interior designer - moving 50 boxes from the street level is a bit tedious. Also potentially it would be much easier if you could unpack in an easier way from the trolley as there is too much clicking to do it
- some more interactions when it comes to buying / renting buildings - otherwise these are just money storing devices to protect from inflation
- ability to change colour of the items placed
- some benefits when it comes to buying a better furniture for your own apartment - otherwise there is not much to work for
- some rationalisation of the cost of repairing cars - when you get a more expensive one the costs become crazy! :)

Still definitely one of the best early access games I have tried, a bit addicting and soooo stable - a gem in this regard

Played this for 11 hours straight, yes it was fun during that time but I quickly found the drip fed dopamine had run out. 

Starting off is fun, it's an incredibly tedious process of trying to stay afloat and build your little empire. However that makes it fun. I started off with a wine & cigar store, progressed to a gift shop, built a massive law firm (* huge waste of time don't do it *), before finally blowing a million hard earned dollars through careful stock flips on a "five cups" coffee shop which is nothing more than a tax write off I can not make a profit nor keep employees. 

The problem I have is that you're going to hit a part in the game where there's really nothing left to pursue. 

That bad business I blew a million dollars on? I can't sell it. I didn't even know it was a failing business, all this game will let you do is make a proposition to the business owner and he says yes or no. You don't even get a due dilligence packet showing you the finances of the business and whether its going to be a good buy or not. 

The stock market is pretty limited. You're enclosed to two banks. Jensen capital (* a shady bank *), and a bigger bank deep in the city. Each bank has 3 stock investments you can buy. That's it. Very slow moving. The more money you pump into a fund the more volatile your gains / losses will be, but it's pretty fatiguing watching that. Granted, that's not the point of this game - it's to build a business empire to gain wealth, not work the stock market. But, freedom should be in the player in how they want to play this. The stock market mechanics need work. We need more investments. 

We should be able to sell businesses. Also, wheres the moving service? The process of moving a business is incredibly painstaking and tedious work. Even with a freight truck and a handcart,  you'll be putting in upwards of 30-60 minutes just to relocate a business to a bigger office. I would rather pay a hefty fee to have all the furniture packed, boxed, and shipped to the location of choice.

Also with the import / export service in this game, it's bugged. The person I hired to manage that part of my business so I could establish contracts, doesn't really do anything. Despite being scheduled, and the import/export business saying they would continue negotations. This is a drawback, as the warehouses I built can not deliver very cheap goods to my businesses - increasing profit margins and reducing supply bottlenecks.

There's a lot to the city that just feels empty. This game has big ambitions right now but delivers short. It needs a lot more work. For the price I guess it's a fair investment, but if you look at the roadmap of where the game is in its progress it looks like they have one more milestone? Definitely needs years of more work. So do I recommend this? Sure, if its on sale or the developers have pumped in a ton of more content. It kept me entertained for a little bit.

Very cool game - can start to feel like a delivery man simulator, but once you get in the ground staff and an HR you should be good.

The game reminds me of GTA 1 and it's giving me wild nostalgic feelings of 98/99 again but with a different soundtrack.

Game has a few bugs, but nothing not playable or solvable through a restart of the game. It's early access, playable and fun to play. Looking forward to what their team will provide in new updates,  there's so much more things to add which is exciting.

I've played Startup Company and thoroughly enjoyed it so when I saw 'Big Ambitions' I didn't hesitate. I am now hugely addicted!
It's an Early Access game so it's a bit rough around the edges but the potential is enormous and it's great fun to play even in this early state.
Even the driving simulation is fun and the 'feel' of driving in the US is surprisingly accurate. I'll be interested to see if the same is the case when London is introduced!
I'm not going to list my 'gripes' because it *is* early access; I'm looking forward to the rollout of more features and the clearing up of some of the 'clunky' bits.
The support via Discord is first class too!
Thoroughly recommended.

If you're into finance and entrepreneurship, then this is the game for you. I've always dreamed of a game where I could run multiple businesses, customize them, and have my own employees working for me. That's this game and more. You're not only running businesses, but you have to prioritize your health and personal life too. There is such a big variety of businesses you can start, from fast food to web design. The list is seriously large, and there's so much more to come. I also like how you have to use knowledge of the market and other analyses to figure out which district is the best to start your business in. I've always been obsessed with automation and passive income, and this really hits the nail right on the head. The road map makes me so excited for the game's future, and I'm glad that I am a (little) early to the game's release. Already 23 hours of playtime in 4 days. I might be a little obsessed...
100% IN LOVE with this game. Literally played this for 14 hours in two days and I am not even close to being bored of it. So excited to see what is to come.
nuh uh

I'm obsessed with the game and got all the achievements (except the ones requiring you to get over 75 years old, those are ridiculous). The core idea of the game is amazing, and I love the concept of merging a business manager with a life simulator. The level of detail for the steps required to create and manage business makes it very enjoyable: not too bureaucratic, and not too simple. The game has a lot of bugs but none that ruin the experience completely, and I assume they'll get fixed with time. In the meantime, I'm very excited for future releases and updates. Super promising game.
Love the game, and its only going to get better!!!!
It's a great game. Lot of things to do and a lot of creativity. Recommended.

Vraiment le coup de coeur de cette année !

Big Ambitions is the type of game that I've been waiting for my entire gaming life.  I always wanted something of a "life simulator" that allows you to create a business and kinda just live.  It's a great balance.

There is a shit ton of potential with this game, and I know for a fact it's just going to get better.

Considering this game is very early access...
It's a lot of fun if you like a little less detail on the shelf stocking part of your retail building empire. For example, you can open a gift shop. Instead of having to fill shelves of numerous types of items, you just drop a shelf and assign either "Cheap" or "Expensive" gifts and it will refill automatically if you have backup storage.

The city is nicely laid out and you will have to drive around it in 3rd person to buy furniture and supplies for your businesses. That's a whole another world to deal with, which can be both fun and frustrating.

Graphics wise, it looks really good (1440p). I'm running over 197 fps (according to the AMD software) with the a rare stutter here and there. So optimization seems very good.
The game hasn't crashed while I've have played so far. I had a couple of minor bugs (one which I reported) but nothing that will spoil your day.

Is it worth your money? I'd say yes, even though it's early access, it's better than many 1.0 game releases out there.

This is not a business sim game, it is a game that tests how well you can run around a town and gather supplies and fixtures for your business. Most common things that are open to business owners in RL are locked behind ridiculous gates (or i at least assume so, like the job to get deliveries for your business.

Ridiculous that quests have a maximum space limitation to get them done. Get a space twice as big as the quest requires. Nope sorry, you cannot complete the task/quest.

I loved the idea of this game, but from the pictures/video I expected it to be a janky experience. I am pleased to report that it is definitely not the case. I am just as bad at driving here as in GTA, and the variety of things to spend money on is quite entertaining.

Being able to spin up new businesses at a whim without having 10 hours of 'be a worker' style gameplay is actually a great idea. Instead of having to save money to start the meat of the game you get right into it fairly early, and the build up into a larger and larger experience is great. Starting with just a store or two, manually restocking, to eventually having a whole warehouse and logistics network to handle it all is just fabulous. It's not even a finished game yet and already it has so much depth to it.

Late game you can even get rich and just start buying out your competitors. Don't like that donut shop? Buy them out and fire the lot of them! Great fun, highly recommended.

Highly recommended purchase!

Good gameplay going from solo act to first few businesses up and running with contracts for shipping and delivery drivers. 

The only problem is after HQ/warehouses are set up, you don't need to go anywhere and in fact the game punishes you for stepping into any of your businesses by emptying the place of any active customers and starting the lines over again (more noticeable in food/cafe because they actually serve more in simulation than they can in rendered gameplay)

I think that one thing that could help the feeling of wasting time is if phone calls/online management actually kept the clock running imaging going through a restructure of the organization and needing to break for lunch on Saturday or Sunday rather than changing everyone's shifts and benefits in the snap of a finger on Tuesday night. would mean less time doing 24-168 hour sleeps at least while waiting for enough capital to start the next business.

Something that would actually pull you out of your apartment at higher levels is if you had in-person meetings or interviews at your headquarters or with lawyers for aquisitions or at banks for loans/investments. the fact you can phone everything in might be convenient, but it stretches the suspension of disbelief at times and pulls the scope of this game into a spreadsheet simulator.

Overall this game deserves a positive review because of the complexities of building up your first few businesses, I mean I already have sixty hours from doing that twice and trying to go deeper, but I am hopeful that these ideas are in the back of the developers minds and just not big enough to put on their roadmap, because there's nothing there to indicate that they see more time in the menus the longer the run goes as a problem, and after exploring the map I think it would be a shame to see them add a private chauffeur service in the future only for every player that reaches that level of wealth to see no need to use it other than to buy groceries (if they even want to keep up that level of realism).

No real sense of accomplishing anything, progress is your uncle calling you saying good job now do X about 20 times. I know this is early access, I just dont see the fun it anymore, grocery shopping for yourself is annoying and time consuming, can get groceries delivered, you cannot buy a commercial fridge and just buy loads of supplies, you need to drive or walk to the store, grab a cart, buy like 6-7 days worth in a paper bag, put it in your trunk or walk it up to your apparment. The game says Sims on stereoids, it's more like Alpha Sims from 20 years ago.

Really enjoying the game so far. It's one of those games that you get sucked into, constantly striving to set everything up perfectly to make the most money possible. Would definitely recommend and exciting to think more is to come.

It's a great game and got lots of potential. I was literally hooked on the game for the past 2 weeks. But after a while, like others have said, it feels flat and bit repetitive. As you progress in the game and earn more money, there should be more ways to automate (i.e hire a contractor and build the same clothing store - so I wont need to buy all the furniture, retrain everyone, and lay out everything again).

Also, I wish there are more fun and rewarding ways I could spend my hard earn cash. The casino is great start, something different from the every day. Sometimes I just want to sleep through the entire day just to see how my finance is doing from the micro adjustments I have done the previous day.

Again, it's still in EA right now and the devs are working hard and listens to the community. I hope they see this and will consider my suggestions. Love the game, but have to put it down for now and see what comes up in the future.

I have enjoyed the variety of businesses you can own and the need to manage your money. The cost of goods will change over time along with the demand of products. You may have to use different suppliers and buying in bulk tends to save over buying small quantities. The tutorial does a nice job of getting you going without giving you too much detail so you still have to figure out the intricate details on your own, but you know the basics quickly.

So I sat on the fence for a while before buying this due to several concerns: 
Is it a walking/driving simulation?
Is it repetitive?
Is it a stripped-down Sims?
However, I needn't have worried, the game quickly lets you automate chores so there is less running around and you can hire staff  to manage staff, inventory and other repetitive chores etc. The whole Sims decorating your apartment and shops side of things is generally optional and can be ignored (it is not a major part of gameplay).

I played for about 45 hours and had a blast. A lot of fun and interesting, addictive game play. But there is not much new to do in the late game other than "rinse and repeat". There seems no clear goal other than to accumulate money. I could make my stores and offices more efficient and perfectionists will love this aspect, but for me, I think I will park this until  new features roll out. Though I am not sure I would want to play the game all over again from the beginning (I am not sure how much replay value it would have). For me this meant I stopped playing after about 45 hours. 

If you are undecided, for £19.32 it should give you many hours of absorbing gameplay and I thoroughly recommend it. Going forward I hope the devs add more to the late game.

I think I've just stumbled across the perfect game for me..... I was the kid in school who loved playing those lemonade stand & stock market simulator games in entrepreneurship class. They were fun ways to teach basic business process and you could inject your own creativity. Big Ambitions takes this same feeling to a new level. 

You start in New York City as an ambitious 18 year old looking to grow a business empire. Uncle Fred gives your some cash to get started and you are then off to rent your own apartment. You have plenty of places to choose from, yes all with different deposits and daily rents. After a couple days working, you can get a loan to open your new business!

The control you have over your business is unlike any other game I've found. The developers to a great job at not shying away from important business concepts, but making it fun and easy to understand. From hiring employees, to managing contracts, Big Ambitions covers many parts of the business process.

In addition to the management parts of the game, you can decorate your business in really fun ways! I hope the developers continue to add more items to the game that we can purchase. It would be cool to see a managed content library of thousands of items we could purchase and decorate with.

I just moved to the NYC area and so finding this game has been really cool. They great job at representing the city environment and I hope there is a chance for the map to continue expanding and more businesses to be added.

Worth buying in its current state though!

As of July 2023 this game feels very unfinished. It has definitely promises but it's not ready - even for early access:

- some features feel flat, missing complexities that would make the game interesting. e.g .law offices require seat, pc and lawyer. There could be more... specialization in law, contacts to law enforcement for criminal law, contacts to corporations etc.

Big Ambitions presents an impressive array of business ventures to pursue, offering a deep level of personalization and a chance to carve your own path to success. [b]However, the game is marred by an overemphasis on micromanagement.[/b] The initial thrill of attending to every business detail, from finances and staffing to inventory and even your avatar's wellbeing, eventually succumbs to tedium.

This game leaves you wanting more than it has to offer. Less than 20 hours in I generate $30,000 every day by just sitting in my home and playing video games (if only it were that easy). Once you've made shipping contracts and automatic deliveries there really doesn't seem much to do other than decorate what businesses you own and keep your happiness up. Every now and then you can buy a new business, spend maybe a week hiring new people, training them and decorating the place but then you are back to waiting to generate more money. The game certainly did what it set out to do but it's a very empty game play loop of mostly keeping your happiness up by either playing video games, exercising or walking in the park. Aside from keeping your happiness up you also have to manage your sleep and hunger. Sleep is easy enough to take care of as you need to keep it up to prevent going to the hospital from passing out. Hunger however just slows the game down as there is no fail state if you don't eat. Reaching zero hunger just increases the amount of energy that is used when doing actions such as exercise but once you are at the stage where you don't have to leave your home hunger becomes insignificant. There is also the issue that regardless of whatever you call your burger joint or however you decorate it the food is the same quality of the burger joint down the street. It's like having two vending machines next to each other with the same snacks but different names. There's no drive to pick one over the other as it's the same product. The amount of customers that are drawn to the business is already predetermined by the location and not what you have to offer. 

There are a few things that could help give a little more life to this game such as more character customization, optional mini-games to increase happiness, a social life system, food buffs from eating particularly good meals, product quality based on skilled workers, custom recipes for restaurants or random encounters such as customer complaints that you have to deal with which can positively or negatively effect your business. These are just a few ideas. 

All in all Big Ambitions isn't a bad game. It works, runs well and gives you something to do. If you're looking for a way to burn a few hours here and there give it a go but it's not something you'll be sinking hundreds of hours into. It is early access so I can give the game a break. As it stands I give Big Ambitions 6/10.

This game is a great business simulator, and honestly I was impressed by the quality coming from an indie game company. Focusing on the "tedious" aspects of running a business, this makes you think steps ahead and supply everything from the furniture, establishing relationships with delivery drivers, and making your own supply runs until you can get distribution set up properly! My biggest issue with this game is the bugs, but they make it easy to report. It's also super hard to control the cars that you need for certain aspects of the game, and no way to lower sensitivity.
Vehicle, even brand new, does not work. Hence, no logistics at all. Venture into tedium thus far.
I can’t wait for what’s next in the development

Title: A Solid Foundation, but Yearning for More Depth and Variety

Review:

"Game is Good" presents an intriguing concept of business management, but it ultimately feels somewhat one-dimensional. While the core objective of running a business is engaging, I believe there is room for improvement in terms of depth and dimension.

One area where the game could benefit from expansion is the inclusion of more jobs and educational opportunities. It would be fascinating to have a broader range of professions and the ability to invest in the growth and development of our employees. This would add a layer of complexity and realism to the game, as we navigate the intricacies of managing a diverse workforce.

Moreover, exploring life management aspects beyond business could significantly enhance the overall experience. Incorporating elements such as personal finances, leisure activities, and character control would broaden the game's scope and provide players with a more comprehensive simulation of life itself.

Speaking of character control, implementing traditional control schemes like the WASD movement would greatly improve the gameplay. Many players are accustomed to this control style and would appreciate its inclusion in the game, allowing for more intuitive and immersive interaction with the virtual environment.

Additionally, considering the introduction of families as a new aspect within the game could be an interesting avenue to explore. Managing a family alongside a business could offer fresh challenges and decisions, adding a new layer of complexity and emotional investment for players.

Expanding the variety of businesses available to manage is another avenue to consider. The inclusion of additional ventures, such as running a bank, factory, or car dealership, would not only diversify gameplay but also cater to different player interests and preferences.

In summary, "Game is Good" lays a solid foundation with its business management concept. However, to truly captivate players, it would greatly benefit from more depth and dimension. Incorporating diverse job opportunities, exploring life management aspects, improving character control, and expanding the range of businesses would elevate the game's overall experience. I encourage the developers to consider these suggestions as they continue to refine and enhance this promising game.

I was pleasently surprised at the level of detail, micromanagement in this game, at first, i thought it was just gonna be another cash grab by the devs, no offence to the devs of this game though. We see a lot of small team devs on Steam, making a lot of different type of games of different genres, but only doing it for the money & not really putting in any effort, with this game, we can clearly see the dev behind this game know what they're doing, its nice to see a dev team bring a new take on this type of genre. Its refreshing, i don't think this has been done like this. Maybe i'm wrong. But this game has big potential to be a very successful game. 

I like the idea that you can walk into almost any building. I really like the idea that you can even buy out other businesses or your competition. Haven't played it long enough yet to give a full in depth review, but what i can say is, i'm quite surprised how good this game is.

Conclusion, for those who like a challenge, this is a great game for a challenge.

I don't often make game reviews but I feel this one is worth it. For anyone who enjoys time/resource management games this will be your next time sink. Since it's still in early access the game does have the occasional issue but it's worth it. I can not wait to see the finalized and polished version of this game. I know my listed play time is 12 hours but I'm probably closer to about 100 already. Ok so with that out of the way personally the only issues I have so far is that the game doesn't always close out properly meaning I have to force close it, and other than the the only real game play issue I have had is driving. iThe controls are very touchy and due to the way the road layout is there are a few areas where you literally can not see where you are going but other than that the game is a lot of fun. For those who post complaining about not liking it due to the need to restock constantly i fully recommend playing the story to get through the tutorial and learn about warehouse management. Getting a headquarters and warehouse set up can save a lot of time and tedious trips, Also I may not be far enough into the story mode to know but from looking through the menus going to the right car dealership can get you a cheap cargo van (around 6,000) which can transport 20 boxes at once compared to the 8 from the starter vehicle.

I'll do a review as a first impression for a change.

The best way I can describe this game in a few short sentences, is kind of like a top-down SIMS game with direct control over your character, with the useless waffle cut out.

Something I personally appreciate, is that the game doesn't instantly overwhelm you with all of it's features, unlike a lot of other management style games do. It eases you in, and you've time to learn one mechanic before having another dropped in your lap. 

In short, It's fun, and I'm looking forward to putting more time into the game whenever I'm free.

I picked up Big Ambitions the other day at sale price (20% off, ~$18) after watching it for a few months. I already have ~14 hours in game after 2 days. I would have happily paid full price, had I known then what I know now.

Big Ambitions is so addictive. In early access, it's already smooth as butter, has tons of content, and very in depth game mechanics. Countless store types, products to sell, furniture and equipment choices, vehicle selection, etc.

After reading the dev/update logs, it's clear that they are passionate and committed to delivering a polished and refined product in roughly ~1 years time.

I am thrilled to join for the ride and see what Big Ambitions turns out to be down the line. As of right now, I'm very happy with my purchase. 

If you like management/sims, you will thoroughly enjoy this game. It reminds of The Sims, but better (in my opinion)

I am impressed. Hats off to Hovgaard Games.

Cheers

I've played the game for 24 minutes and ran into two game-breaking bugs right off the bat: 
[list]
    [*]The first time the game froze the map while trying to tell me to get a loan. Escape menu didn't do anything so I had to shut it down manually. 
    [*]Secondly, I was soft-locked right after that when you start your own business. The game tells you to rent a retail spot, but seemingly wants you to rent a specific one without telling you, because when I did rent it out (as per instructions made, I didn't rent some huge building) nothing happened - I opened up my business but the game didn't progress and still wanted me to pick a building where I'm going to start a shop. [/list]

If a game, regardless of it being early access or not, can't even create a proper intro into the gameplay loop without crashing then you should not be selling it. And gamers, you should not be buying it. Simple as that.

The mechanics are all there for this game to be amazing, they are just lacking content. Content, mind you, that they are actively adding with a well made road map. The game plays quite well, the designing aspect is fun, and I have yet to run into any major bugs after 30 hours.

The only thing I can ask more from this game would be Steam Workshop support. If that were to be added, this game would live on forever. Players would be uploading mods that add whatever products or furniture they would want.

If you are wanting a completely fleshed out game, I would put this on your wish list and wait a little bit. But if you are looking for a nice casual time sink, and don't mind getting updates here and there, it is well worth the money.

This game is a good pretty realistic business game. The story mode acts as a tutorial and tells you everything you need to know to run a good business. The customer caps on the buildings are really annoying because if I add more registers and more employees, I should be able to serve more customers. The customer caps just don't make sense to me, because then you rent out a huge building and barely use any of the space and it just looks bad. It has all the things you have in real life, fast food, banks, recruitment agencies, marketing, car and truck shops, etc. Looking at the game so far, it is very good and well simulating game. This game has huge potential and I can definitely see this game going big and far. In future updates, I'd like to see, more options of business, not only just selling things, but also services, like a moving company or an agency of some sort. More options of things to sell in on business type, for example in the coffee shop, you can only sell three types of baked goods, donuts and coffee. I'd also like to see being able to put multiple different units in one storage/display case, for example, in the bakery case, if you didn't have to buy two different cases to sell croissants and whatever, if you could just do half half.

Hey can you not apply the new update stuff to old employees , the insurances and new satisfactory stuff made 20% out  of my 200 employees and their  satisfactory went down , and it very hard to locate one by one to each HR managers for insurance .

It's just not fun at the moment. Every single game mechanic seems to be there to make you like the game less.

Wait for a shop to open? I'll just wait in my car. - minus 25% happiness for the day

Hire new staff? You have to pay the employment agency to find you someone, then regardless of the quality of the staff, whether or not they want to work full/part time (you can't choose lol). Don't like the person they found? Well you still have to pay them $500. Awesome. Oh, and new hires set their own salaries apparently.

Day two, regardless of job performance staff start texting you with demands. How about no, just do your damn job.

Your character is manic depressive and unless you have them watch TV, play computer games and go for walks in the park daily they start sulking to the point it affects the work performance of your staff city wide.

Driving is a nightmare. AI traffic constantly smashes into you, and there's no game mechanic for swapping insurance details and having them pay for the damage so you just have to pay for the damage.

Deliveries are bizarre. You have to place a weekly order for stock, but that isn't fixed. Sales are variable, and I don't have infinite stock space. So...I have to manually check the shelves in all my shops periodically to make sure the deliveries are right? Why can't I just order up to a limit?

Then just as you think you've got everything organised staff start calling in sick. This doesn't stop the time skip for sleeping. It was at this point I thought F this, this isn't a game, it's a job, and I'm not enjoying it. I quit.

I'll start off this review by saying I am a massive fans of Tycoon-like games. I also enjoy the Sims from time to time. So this game ticked all boxes, it genuinely looked promising.
I watched closely for a release window and jamp at the chance to buy during EA.1.0.

Beginning with the positives; this game has a LOT of potential and I am excited to see where the Road Maps leads them into 2024. I like the whole aspect, the management system, some graphics and music are very good, some not so much! It's a very "lite" game, maybe 30 hours of fun and then the boredom kicks in and the cracks start to show. 

As of writing a new hot-fix came out yesterday and effectively did nothing. I was being forced into unrealistic employee demands as early as 50% skill acquired. I was told it should be closer to 100%. I was 40 days in and I realised... listening to the tutorial is NOT recommended. I didn't realise it at first but I was spending all day just running back n forth mopping, it makes little sense as a business owner. Then I restarted and changed prices. I panicked when 1 out of 3 customers declined and restarted again. This time I bought cleaners, full-time, and watched 500 wages deduct every day for virtually no reason - the floors still filthy so - I persevered. I had no idea I was up against an aggressive AI buying everything from under me. Bidding low and selling high. That's supposed to have changed as well. The final nail on the coffin following this tutorial was the delivery fees. £1000 a week just to bring over a few cheap gift cups. I was bankrupt and had to restart again. Well, I didn't... I uninstalled. It needs more time in the oven I think. I hope they fix and add and stick to their road-map. I will be back to change my review when it happens. 

Pro tip:- just ignore the tutorial and read some guides free on Steam before you begin your "Big Ambition" journey. And Dev's... if you are reading this, please for the love of god, fix the cleaner system! There's so much wasted potential there. Many others have flooded the forums with suggestions please listen to them!

TL:DR
Wait a year before sinking real money into this potentially great game.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: This review is/was written when this game was in/is still in Early Access. Think twice before buying/playing this game [/quote]

Big Ambitions is a game developed and published by Hovgaard Games

The game has some really beautiful environments and the graphics are really well designed and laid out. The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless

The game also suffers with some weird bugs and glitches which the developer seemed to have overlooked but they don't hinder the game at all

Big Ambitions overall, however, is a fun game to play in short bursts and a good open-world simulation game to play!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]
[list]
[*] None

This game has a lot of potential! I enjoy playing this game! Now, I'm hoping they allow more control with the cars. I would love to see first person view/ be able to zoom in more. I'm hoping there will also be more editing with the characters. They are very basic. Driving around has a real feeling, where as the characters are terrible, lol. I know the game has just came out, so ill definitely be patient and wait for updates!

I very much like this game. I only found out about it from Youtubers. This is a top down Business RPG Sim where you manage stores and employees all while keeping your sanity until you retire.

There is just sooo much to do its absolutely fun to do so and this game can get complicated quickly if not manged properly. For now I'm just trying to get my stores operating better and I hope later on to see the development of this game and where it heads.

The User Interface however in EA is rather annoying when mousing over objects and buildings at the moment, with popups dancing all over the place and the busier the store, the more the menu popups keep showing up and hopefully it gets fixed soon.

This game has lots of potential but as another has mentioned, it falls flat. My biggest issue is that it is very time consuming to get to places and it's becoming much more of a driving simulator then it is managing a business. After starting a custom game and finally ticking off the boxes for opening a Jewellery shop, 3 days in and not one single customer. Spent more money on marketing and yet, nothing. From what I have read online, this happens in pirated version of the game but seeing that purchased it via Steam, I don't see what I'm doing wrong and at this stage, it's not worth troubleshooting the game just to start all over again.

Great game. Addictive. The sensation of starting a business, streamlining the supply line and making money is very satisfying. 

However a few problem points.

Not all business are equal (much like in real life) but in the game the gap can be quite jarring. Clothes shops seem at the moment quite overpowered in that they dont cost particularly much to staff and maintain, the supply is relatively cheap and the rewards are enormous (disproportionate to other businesses)

Second point would be a criticism over how you staff your businesses. You have little control on negotiating salaries, who the employment agency shortlists for you (typically part time or full time)  And employees seem to be able to max their stats too easily. Maybe if you could implement a way to interview the candidates that would be great. 

Third point is more a personal comment on the direction the game has gone down. I would like to see more depth in the businesses. An example would be a restaurant (not the fast food one in the game which is horrifically basic). 
Creating a restaurant requires lots of in depth actions. 
You need a manager, waiters, cooks and cleaners (not just the cleaners and customer service in the fast food). 
You need to have a place to store ingredients (not just a storage room, but industrial fridges and freezers)  
You could even use one of the food or fruit and vegetable shops to supply your own restaurant. Business Partnerships. 
You would need various different types of food, drinks, alcohol... Like have categories : cheap meat, expensive meat, cheap bottle of wine, high end bottle of wine. 
Have Customers complain if you run out of a certain food type or drink type. Not just complain about the colors of the walls and floor. 
Same for the other businesses. 
What i am asking for, if it is possible is even more depth to make the game a bit less repetitive.

This game is awesome even though it's still in early access it has a lot of replay-ability! I spend quite a bit of time scouring around steam store looking for something to entertain me, and this game definitely cures the itch. The moment I had to rent an apartment, get a job, buy appliances and buy groceries to fill my fridge, it's then I realized this game is awesome! You get a sense of fulfillment and satisfaction after opening your first business and pleasing the customers. Having to actually rent the space, furnish the store, fill your cabinets with products all manually hits it for me. I know some might find this tedious, but I get enjoyment out of the simulation of running life and a business. Hiring people work for you can be a pain sometimes because it takes money to find people and a lot of time. But once you get a business up and running and you see cash flowing in, I just get excited to work on something bigger and better or just improve my stores. It's so cool!

with 24 hours in i definitely have seen some slight improvements to the game, but honestly doesn't appear to have changed too much from launch. The game sort of has something, but i can't imagine playing it as intended. I play it in the custom mode and I've been noticing that some businesses legitimately don't work or function as they are supposed to. One of the first shops i opened was a coffee shop because i would love to actually own one irl, nut strangely enough i have put everything into the coffee shop and it still doesn't turn a profit above essentially pocket change. It legitimately does not work. i also have a very flushed out fast food shop with maxed employees and it still gives me the least money of my businesses. I also have a clothing store, which, when stocked, is bringing in nearly 30k and supporting all the other businesses, even though i intended to have the clothing store be one of my less popular or lucrative stores. this is highly irritating for me because it just seems i can't play the game as i would want to.  The fact that i can have a fully stocked coffee shop with multiple spending points such as donuts, croissants, coffee of course, gifts, sodas, salads, and flowers that has maxed employees and employee satisfaction (i also have an HR department, but we'll get to that later) along with having a marketing campaign and the coffee shop still turn next to no actual profit tells me that it seems like all of that is down the drain. I am running the business perfectly, and i would argue i'm running it too efficiently, but because of how the values in the game are worked i am making next to no money. It's irritating that my hunger bar shoots down completely while at work to, as if i don't have a break or don't occasionally snack on my own product in general. Everything in my shop i paid for, so i'm entitled to my croissants. I am selling so many products i may as well be a 7/11 with higher standards. And somehow i'm going negative. My homes aren't expensive either, and definitely not enough to justify being put under by an obviously flourishing business. And as much as i love driving around in the game, not being able to turn the camera or even zoom in enough to get an idea of what's coming is a huge nuissance, even when i'm driving like a normal citizen. IT has been this way since release and It isn't really justified when you look at the map and realize you aren't going too far either. Also, i know i'm technically still early into the game but the fact that certain  residences aren't available because they are "occupied" is pretty annoying, especially when you're stuck in a progression loop and can't unlock more options yet. Because i did notice that more options slowly became more available, but when i first started i wanted a place by the park so bad. There is one available to me now but it's facing a plaza that seems ripped right out of 28 days later. I'm not trying to look out my window only to remember why i wouldn't want to rejoin society. I want to see the sprawling park. My next issue is that the WASD function only work for the vehicle, but completely cease all functionality the second you leave the car. Why would i want to play the spam left click game or click the scroll wheel and get annoyed when i start bumping into or circling around things until i get my character to stop when i can very precisely control the movements with keys. Oh yes, how could i forget, the customization. There are like 3 customization options in the character creation screen for every section. 3 hair styles, 3 skin colors, two face, etc. Then when you get later into the game and start to design uniforms for employees the options are incredibly limited and not all that enticing. The one thing that had the MOST customization in the whole game seems to be the logo for your company, and even then a majority of the options are just pooled business representations and slightly abstract designs. I also went out and to celebrate my business i bought some clothes, only to get home and realize i have no idea how to use a bag of clothes. I've gotten a pretty good grip on how to move everything and how to properly interact with items and yet there is now a useless bag of clothes sitting next to my couch that i SPENT MONEY ON, mind you. this has not been changed or updated despite numerous updates to other features and countless references available for choice. Speaking of my house, why am i even buying furniture if i can't use it? Can't cook on the stove, can't prepare food at a table, can't sit on my sofa, can't even sit at my dining room table or chairs at all for that matter. The only option i can do is use a computer or watch tv, and all that does is skip time and boost happiness. Also please for the love of god, listening to the same 5 song EVERYWHERE i go starts to become worse than clipping parts of my ears off with toenail clippers after a certain amount of time. Just add some royalty free music or something. At least some piano. Listening to pop rap or whatever the hell that middle school kid-with-speaker-in-backpack shit is the most excruciating part of walking into my business or just taking a joyride. Give me some dahm bach or mozart or royalty free synth wave or something. I'm not spending over 20 hours listening to the dog shit audio tracks that play everywhere except the streets my helpless little human runs down out of sheer terror of having to hear the song i skip every single time. As i said before, when i play this game all i see is room for improvement. I don't hate this game. And i would really look to playing it as much as i can in the future, but if these things aren't improved on or just get ignored then i don't see a point. I love EVERY single other aspect of the game, but i feel the need to highlight the blaringly obvious things that could see this game tumble and fall flat.

Here are some of the things I liked about the game:

Freedom and control: You have complete control over your character's actions, from what kind of business you start to how you spend your time.
Different and challenging game play: Big Ambitions is not your typical tycoon game. 
Engaging and immersive: The game play is engaging.

For some reason I cannot figure out how to post on the big ambitions game feature suggestion forum.

I really hope the dev introduces an annual mandatory wage increase or even a perk system for your employees. Perhaps employee variety could be a better justification for wages, other than training level. Morale is tied to wages and leaders in real life, why not in the game? Employees can be head hunted in real life, people leave, ect. The point is to maintain the investment that has been made into all personnel. Perks and traits may allow the player to have an emotional attachment to the simulated person. This is much closer to how life is. Traits could be simple like 5% increase to foot traffic, 1 more item sold to each customer, ect.

I'd really like the dev to implement a better hiring or human resources system. I have 400 employees and it is getting complicated to manage and keep track of them.

The game is too flat. You can barely manage anything. Open up a Jewelry Store for instance. You have the choice to put 2 different items for sale. Cheap Jewelry and Expensive Jewelry.
Then you can train your employees. Thats it. Thats pretty much all you can adjust to make the business sucessful. When the business makes enough money, you are able to open another store and do the same thing, adjust the same 2 screws and you are set. All that is left are chores, you will drive 100s of time with your car to buy your products. Yes, you dont have to do that anymore once you become wealthy, but there is literally nothing else to do.
Thats the gameplay.

Here are more shops and the available products:

Florist: cheap flower
expensive flower

Gift Shop: Cheap Gifts
Expensive Gifts

Liquor Store: Bottle of Wine
Cigar

Even worse are Web Development Agency and Law firm.
You literally cant do anything. How can you double the income of a law firm? Yes, Just double the amount of the employees. You are unable to change the product at all. You are paid for every hour an lawyer sits at his table. Place workstations, hire lawyers. Done.


Big ambitions calls itself a "role-playing business simulation". The whole part of the simulated business of a lawfirm is sitting the god damn lawyer at this table. No negotiations, no contracts, no patents, no laws...no nothing. LET YOUR LAWYER SIT AT HIS TABLE and the business simulation of your law firm is complete. That´s ridiculous.

What a detailed game. Micromanager the F out of your stores and get that big pile of money dude. I like cash.

You start off with a sexy $15,000 loan from your uncle Fred, the dude in the Blue suit red tie. "He's one of the good guys." Then you buy your store set up merchandise then hire someone to run the cash reg or run one yourself. You get tired and need food, so you gotta get food from the stores all around the world. It looks a lot like the grid of New York. Pretty cool in my textbook. You just end up expanding into new industries and rent out stores. Your empire grows and grows. Bigger moves are made, more people depend on you. Ohh, Hi boss how are you today Errrr. "Stop KISSING MY ASS NO RAISE FOR YOU!!!!" =(

The lowdown when you get to mid game....

You train employees, set up commerce routes to stores from warehouses. You order from Big Shipping companies in bulk to your warehouses. You have logistics to deal with so you have an HR office which you hire people to constantly order same products. You have drivers that you can train and drive your wares around to sustain that paper, Boo.

Upgrade your apartment with all sorts of furniture items.  Upgrade your car too, or just take the taxi around. 

The developer of the game is really active in the forums. Your voice does matter. That's some solid loyalty and they have my respect. I've submitted many bugs. They do get addressed. And they update this game regularly.

There are a wide variety of businesses available to run and the option to hire staff to work in various roles, something that will need to be done when you get more than one building. The game looked very promising. Half a Tycoon game, half an RPG set in a modern day setting. If the developer would make either side very interesting, the other side would be an interesting addition. Our character starts poor. 

But only after 3 days, it is super easy to get a loan and start a very profitable business from just that, without any skills, without any story, without significant difficulty. It looks like it is automatic, it looks like this option is here for everyone. So the realistic low money start is gone. With this the sense of achievement for the first successful business is gone. Too easy start is bad BOTH for the RPG side, and the business sim side. 

Mixing RPG elements and Tycoon elements in the same game, same campaign is possible, with many different kinds of gameplay. But right now the problem is with the [i]campaign[/i], having the option to start a successful business (without any consideration) from loan after very short time spent working is bad story wise. Starting a side hustle from your hobby (drawing, etc) at recommendations from a friend, would be good, and could realistically lead to creating enough merchandise for your own gift shop. It would be easy to add more challenge, and more story.

But lets speak about the gift shop... If I would visit a gift shop in a foreign city, I would expect to be able to buy T Shirts as gifts, but I wouldn't need a changing room for that. In addition to "walk in business" we would often see "mail order" or "online" business, maybe cooperation with celebrities, intellectual property (maybe for our own designs or designs of others), etc.In the game we have only cheap gifts, expensive gifts, and we can't even sell T Shirts without a changing room. We don't have to think about which gift will be popular, we don't see how different retail businesses can be very different.

In our fast food chain there are no option to create a value menu, and our option to sell cheap toys (gifts) like McDonalds did with Happy Meal (huge success) has no effect on our profitability. Selling some items to differentiate, to draw in more customers (and sell other items to them), upselling, etc. are all ignored in this game. In our burger shops we can't even have a 2nd kind of burger. 

We can't have a normal brand (like Toyota) and a premium brand (Lexus) as we don't see market segmentation. 

We have a game mechanic that checks how much time we have spent in a park, which shouldn't be that relevant to the game, and not all business owners would like this (so a game mechanic that reduces player agency) but the developer avoids providing many meaningful business decisions, and we can't enjoy the good decisions, and the good reviews, feedbacks from customers, etc...

We had bad driving mechanics, fuel consumption, parking tickers, etc. but we don't have IPs that can sell our merchandise in a game about business.

I killed the Forklift?! "I killed the forkliiift, but I did not kill the haaandtruck". Yes, I killed a forklift. Usually, when you are placing items, it will show red if you are over something that will conflict. I was placing a Pallet Shelf, the forklift seemed close, but not in the way. Then suddenly chaos as the Forklift starts hopping up and down under the shelf. I was able to get on the Forklift, but it wouldn't move. I removed the shelf and the forklift just sat there, jumping up and down. I left the warehouse, usually this resets all hand trucks to their normal location, I figured what the heck, should work. Upfront this review is less about the game and more about its developers attitude. I love the game so far although I expect it to develop far more and the developers will for sure have to add far more decorative items, textures and so on. But the basic idea of the game is great and now comes what I love definitely most:

It has been just 2 days ago that I was posting about some major bug I have with a game called "Stranded: Alien Dawn". I did spend around 30 Euros for that game and can't play it, because it crashes on my Linux thanks to my graphics card Radeon VII ( it a very expensive seldom used card the developers might have just not tested for their game). However I tryed to talk to the developers 3 times with 3 different posts there.
Each time with no answer at all as long as I was still super nice and begging for help. Only thing they told me was to send a report with files from my computer. I did. Now the last time I was complaining a bit more aggressively and said that I felt pretty ignored after waiting 3 month for any help. They asked me then for my computer specs and I know that means on steam forums trouble for the Linux users, because we get always treated like idiots, as if the mistake would be always on our side, if anything doesn't work (praise windows that spys everyone out and will soon charge you for every little programm extra). Of course the people there started to call me a troll, because the developers also treated me like that.
Yes yes I am already coming to the point! *grin
You like reading stories, don't you? Otherwise you wouldn't read anymore ;)
However those developers here are the absolute contrary from what I usually experience. At the forum of "Stranded:Alien Dawn" the answer of the developer was: Oh I was trying to help you, but now that you say you are playing on Linux ...blabla Mr Freemen ..just get lost customer, we are not responsible that steam posted that this game runs on steam deck and who cares that steam deck uses Linux!

The developers here were just super kind they reacted very polite and nice to the problem of crashes on Linux. Did send me a link to a post some other players that use Linux already did and said "We are investigating to fix it".
I mean that is unusual and even if you are a windows user that reads this now, just imagine you would have to use a different system on your computer and get for that reason constantly treated like a troll.
This is like being different in any way in society, you just loose either all attention and help or you get treated like an alien or idiot. That kind of intolerance and narrow-mindedness seems to be very common nowadays.

I love those developers just for this, but also for some other reactions. They put their heart into this game, you can easily see that and they care a lot that the players are happy! They read reviews and posts in the forum and pick up ideas. This is awesome and so rare nowaday!
Thank You!

I very rarely write reviews so hopefully you understand that I only write this now because I am really enjoying the game, even at this early stage. 

It's super addictive, extremely well paced and gives just the right amount of guidance to get you started. Obviously a few things missing here and there in early access but there is always something you can be doing to continue expanding your business. You can be as hands on as you like or you can leave everything to your capable staff whilst you go out looking for the next venture. 

The missing: character customisation is severely lacking. I personally would like more "life sim" features. Hang out spots, interactions with customers or staff or even the people you walk past on the street. Even just a basic one line greeting would make a huge difference with wandering NPCs on the streets and maybe a "well done" for your employees. I think having contract negotiations with your staff would add to the immersion too. 

This has become rambly which is why I don't write reviews generally but overall I recommend this game. Everything in the game so far is great and even in early access, it is already worth the money. I'm really excited to see what will be added in the future!  

TL:DR
Fun, addictive, well paced. Lacking in some areas as expected in EA. Can't wait to see what the future brings!

2.7 hour review.  I'm a little past the time that I could try to get a refund.

Not any chance I would need a refund for this game!  Nor much of a chance I want to spend a lot of time writing a review when I could be playing it instead!  So here it is, short and sweet.

This is a business/management simulation.  Because it's in EA many features might change, but the roadmap is listed here: https://www.bigambitionsgame.com/roadmap

You might notice there is no technology tree - that's the only feature I wonder that might be something I miss.  But there is a school and you can't do certain things like hiring people until you've completed certain classes.

Otherwise, unlike other business sims, this one requires running around on foot or driving in a car to get around town to manage time and bring all the pieces together that make up your business(es).

I love this idea!!  I'm a horrible driver too.  It adds just that extra bit of humor when you're trying to race to buy some furniture before a store closes.  People honk their horns when you cut in front of them too.  Hahaha!

The forums have a HUGE list of ideas people keep submitting as feature requests.  So I think the sky  is the limit for what this game could eventually offer.

Do I recommend it?  If you like business simulations absolutely, but you have to understand that it's in EA and some edges are still a bit rough.  I have noticed some bugs where I have to Alt-F4 to quit the game and reopen it to continue, but I imagine that will be addressed eventually since this is still EA.  Full price for the vast range of different businesses available is reasonable I think.

This reminds me a little of Capitalism, but this is a very different game which (at least currently) doesn't have any supply chains for manufacturing, but it does have imported goods.  It would not take a large effort to implement supply chains though... but for now the emphasis is very clearly on retail.  This game has another obvious emphasis on "painting".  Just spend leisurely time decorating your business in the way you want it and can be proud of - this can be extremely casual and relaxing.
Hours of endless fun... overall a good game, I like the attention to detail in the early-release stage and the planned additions in the roadmap. Very little bugs and tons of opportunities!
Great potential. Needs more work, its a bit rough around the edges. More content needed also.

This is STUPIDLY good for an Early Access. It's been a long time since I've been excited to play a video game the moment I get home from work, and I find myself playing this from the exact moment I do get home, to the time I have to go to bed. 

While I've been playing the Story Mode on Normal difficulty, I wouldn't say it's all that difficult (There is a custom mode where you can adjust certain aspects of the world to make it more challenging, or just try the story mode on hard), it's a rewarding slow burn. Starting your first business feels great, and every little improvement you make over time feels more and more rewarding as you see profits slowly rise. Until you make your first 5K and you feel real good inside. 

From there, it just keeps getting better and better. That's what amazes me the most about it being early access, I have yet to hit a ceiling of content or enjoyment. And the update roadmap looks very promising! Huge recommend.

This is the business game I've been waiting for. As an entrepreneur myself ive CRAVED a game that dives into the exciting world of starting a business. In this game you get to start multiple businesses which is super fun. As a someone who has started a few companies I really appreciate how you have to research market demand prior to starting a business in order to ensure success. I also like all the manual work it takes to start a company and as your resources increase, so does your ability to automate things. For an early stage game, this is a home run! 

Hoping for a future multiplayer, store blueprints, and armor upgrade for vehicles. (Cars take damage way too easily)
