You can really see the potential in this game. It will need some big updates though as after 15 hours of playing, there is not a lot for me to do. The end game currently is rinse and repeat making the same stores over and over. I am looking forward to purchasing property being expanded, as well as maybe balancing of the different business types and new additions. 

Could also be interesting to see a crime element implemented into the game.

The early and mid game is very fun but maybe it needs to be slightly longer. 15 hours to get to late-middle/endgame seems too short, but it is still in early access and I am looking forward to playing it again on the next update.

As others have said, this is being developed as an instant classic. Heavy Sims 3 inspired base, old school GTA thrown in, and sprinked with the depth of a tycoon game that reminds me of Lemonade Tycoon, Mall Tycoon, etc. I understand the game isn't done yet, and as it stands is a fully playable and enjoyable game for hours on end- i can't wait to see what else is implemented, but i have a little list of wishes.

Its exactly what i wanted, start with nothing and create a business empire. It works pretty well, make businesses that you can name and design yourself and then run around town trying to keep them stocked until you can hire people to do all that for you.

However, that is part of the issue and there is very little to do once you start making money.  You can get a better apartment, buy some furniture which achieves very little and make bigger businesses which are much the same.
 
Being Early Access, I am sure that with some positive feedback things will improve, and I will be all for it.  Other than the pacing of the game, the UI can also be very clunky, but on the positive there are some things it does really well, like speeding around town weaving through traffic to get to the warehouse before it closes feels quite real, as does filling up on gas and making sure your fridge is filled.  I just feel like these things need to be more "fleshed out" and some of the UI probably needs a rethink and this will be a must buy.
This is a game that we all been waiting for, for years.

I'm only a few hours in. The game seems to have a lot of potential but definitely has some areas it is lacking in. Nothing that can't be fixed but I can see it souring a lot of people's first impressions. 

For instance, I wanted to hire a part time cleaner and a full time cashier for my business. The player MUST use an employment agency. It costs money whether or not the player hires the candidate or not. I can choose what AGE I want the candidate to be, but not whether or not they are full or part time. That makes no sense and it is left completely up to RNG as to which one you get. I ended up having to spend a ton of scarce early game money going though tons of people just to get two suitable employees. Also, you pay the same price regardless of how qualified they are...I got so tired of the RNG I hired a horrible customer service employee for almost $50 an hour to run my cash register! It cut my daily income by 2/3 but I couldn't stand waiting anymore.

I really think this game has a lot of potential, but allowing mod support would probably bring it to the next level. Allowing a community to help add variety to the game in the way of maps, business types, items, building, etc would give the game a ton of replayability and variety.

This is an incredible business simulation game that’s still in Early Access. 

Whether you just want to manage a small Mom 'n' Pop's coffee shop, or have bigger dreams, this game has you covered. Turn that coffee shop into a successful franchise, or take over and run the next big clothing retail chain, or maybe spread that market risk and manage a mega-sized business conglomerate. Work at your own store, and/or hire staff as your empire expands.

And if your business isn’t successful enough and demand is too low, just buy out your competitors and shut them all down and reassign the staff to some other business, or fire them with zero consequences. Create your own monopoly on goods or services and jack up the prices to help pay for your expensive boats and cars.  

Unfortunately, there are no meaningful social elements in the game. You can’t, for instance, get married or anything like that. 

The game is also very management heavy, sometimes to a fault. For example, if you run multiple businesses and want to hire cleaning staff for them, you have to buy cleaning supplies from a store, put them in your vehicle (which can only hold so many packages), drive to each location, put the supplies in the building, then call and hire a cleaner through the recruitment agency. 

It takes a long time to set up stores and offices, but it does pay off as you’re kind of forced to decorate them by hand. And while it’s possible to just buy an already established business and improve upon it instead of starting your own from scratch, these unfortunately do not come with cleaning supplies. So, towards the late game it does become a bit silly – surely you should be paying people to figure some of this stuff out for you while you go chill on your yacht or something? 

All in all, the game is fun in its current state, and has a lot of potential. 
It’ll be fun to follow the development of this.

This week I woke up with Big Ambitions. I wanted to be a big time big money rich business man. Totally achievable.

I started my new business McBearPig's, a fast food chain with a difference. My signature burger, the 'Half Bear-Half Pig Tower' was the speciality and I was hoping it was going to attract customers in their thousands.

There were initial complaints about the high prices and drab interior, but I ignore complaints. The customer is an idiot. You gotta remember that. 
Soon enough, there were concerns about the cleanliness of the floors. I was prepared for this though and responded, telling people that we cook our food on the grills, not on the floor, so it wasn't an issue.

Over the following weeks McBearPigs ran at a loss. I even became a full time driver for the company. My days were spent picking up and delivering burgers, and my nights were spent drinking wine and wallowing in self hate.

I even tried getting a job at the local store for some extra cash to support the business, but that only led to a small gambling problem. I was a fiend for that casino boat. Every friday I would take a big wad of cash in and leave with nothing, each time believing 'tonight was the night'.

I had to close McBearPigs. I was in the hole, it was in the hole, and to be totally honest, the burgers were abysmal.

The worst thing about all of this. Uncle Fred was disappointed in me.

I love simulation games and have spent hundreds of hours in them. I was really excited for this one. Honestly, it's just not that fun of a game. After a few hours, you're really just going around doing the same tasks over and over again. It could be a great game if the developers:

1) Fixed the driving experience. It's just plain not fun. 
2) Give the players the ability to hire an office manager. The office manager would purchase things like desks, chairs, computers, shelves for stocking, cleaning stations, etc. and have them delivered to the new location. All you'd do is decide how it would be set up. Truly, going to the wholesale stores time and time again made starting up a new business repetitive and feeling like a chore. 
3) Completely rework the stores that the player buys items from. I really tried to like this game, but this was the nail in the coffin for me. There two different wholesale stores. They sell almost the same stuff, but not quite. So if you start a new business you have to drive to both of them. Or, you could drive around the IKEA-esque store, which is logistically a disaster. Really poor job here.  
4) The happiness system needs some work. Realizing that I actually have to go walk in a park every day or two or else my employees will quit was just plain absurd. Not sure what you guys were thinking here. 

There are other items that should be addressed to fix the game. It has good bones, but right now it is a genuine chore to play it.

You know that entrepreneurial guy or cryptobro friend of yours who keeps asking you if you 'know how to play the game?' Well this is it.

I literally work with startups & SME's in real life and this game is BY FAR the closest thing you can find online to a business simulation game that sticks close to actuality.

I have a few gripes, from the meticulousness of moving everything and I mean EVERYTHING, in a new business (it's fun at first, but gets old and annoying when you've done it a hundred times. Some form of copy/paste or ready made format would be great) to a lack of late-game goals and activities. Perhaps automation or corporate/international expansions? 

However, keeping in mind this is in early access, it's already well worth it for its price. If you love making money/planning businesses and have an entrepreneurial itch, this game is for you!

Its a fun game that needs some crazy balancing and/or give you more influence in the success of your business. Right now it feels very limited and some businesses seem to struggle to create any income at all, which is VERY bad since you have to use one of them during the tutorial early which will mess up with your income badly.

Then the Tutorial , or "Mainquest" seem to suddenly make a super time jump, where the mission basically is "Ok play now for xx more hours until you have an insane amount of money" where it feels like they just ran out of ideas how to guide you on and introduce more mechanics to you.

The "Happiness" of the Main Character can be annoying too. It doesnt feel very nice to be forced to stand around an hour in the park every day so your employees which you never see get their "i want my boss to have 50% happiness" fullfilled.

Theres alot of work to do to make this game what it can be, but the foundation is already worth the price and your time. But it could be more.

I do wish some QoL improvement that's not mentioned in the roadmap to be added:
- speedometer.
- toggle to hide occupied workspace and assigned employee (not just cleaner) in biz scheduler. Since it's currently a nightmare to manage business with more than a dozen employee due to excessive scrolling and inconsistent color coding.
- Piggybacking the above; option to adjust/ set default shift length in business settings.
- Color-coded map based on lot layout, so you can easily spot desirable lot with proper size and layout rather than hovering on each one.
- maybe a gas station in garment district?

I have now been playing for a couple of weeks, so this review may differ slightly from any earlier statements, but I still remain completely positive about BIG AMBITIONS.

Basically, you make one of TWO main choices at the beginning...  follow the guidance of Uncle Fred, or go it alone.   For me, the guidance route was painful (despite it acting as a decent tutorial at first with 3 levels) but the requests seemed to arrive out of sequence and put the business in trouble when you try to comply, so the GO IT ALONE option on my later efforts showed that it allows you to play the game at your own pace, even when starting with ZERO capital to make it more difficult.

From there, you need to build a few businesses of your choice before making the move into a head office where lots of the work can be automated through teams of managers and warehouse delivery drivers.

Once you get some intermediate success, it becomes a bit tedious trying to replicate that a few dozen or more times in other businesses, sometimes with their own manager and warehouse for separate industries to give you more of a challenge.

I'm still hoping there is more to come from this fabulous game, but after 300 hours, I am finding it more challenging to find a challenge, having bought the biggest yacht and parked my Rolls Royce beside it before enjoying a night on the Casino boat.   

I am hopeful that other businesses like bars and nightclubs can be added, with agencies booking showbiz acts for their venues, and giving us somewhere to relax for a few hours after work.  We could also buy and operate those venues as part of our organisation, balancing drink sales and ticket prices with the costs of products, staff and entertainment acts in different sized venues with a stage, bar and possibly food sales in larger ones.   Sure there are many ideas being floated at the moment.

Great game though, and everyone will find their own threshold for how long they want to play it, but watch out for more developments on BIG AMBITIONS from the team at Hovgaard.  Brilliant start.

Big Ambitions is a unique take on the tycoon genre that is on the verge of being addictive and boring at the same time. The drip-feed incremental gameplay is barely rich enough to make me want to stay in the game, but just satisfying enough to keep me coming back.

It has a big focus on automation, vaguely like Factorio, but unlike Factorio there's nothing to do in between. I find myself sleeping away most days just to save up money, which feels wrong; the unique 3D-represented player character hurts the game more than it adds.

I have no desire to explore all the various business types because they are essentially just re-skins of the same thing, and I can't be arsed to furnish them again. I also have no desire to move out of the starting street (Garment District) because it has everything in close proximity, unlike other locations. The starting area should've been the furthest distance from all important busineses, so that there is a logistic reason to move to a more expensive area.

After 11 hours, I've done everything I wanted to do in Big Ambitions, and had quite a satisfying time doing so, but it's not enough time to justify the pricetag.

Competitive multiplayer could potentially make the game more worthwhile (and add some much needed difficulty), but sadly only cooperative multiplayer is found on the official roadmap.

Only recommended if you're a huge tycoon game fan, otherwise pass.

good game

It's pretty fun, but not very dynamic. You rent a building, fill it with the right amount of shelving/displays according to the size of the building. Building sizes create a hard cap of customers per hour, which isn't very realistic. You then tediously have to get that product to the building using a wholesaler, or setting up a warehouse with importing those goods using a purchaser at your headquarters that you also have to set up, and then hiring a delivery driver to get that product to your store. 

This is all well and good for the most part, but it doesn't really feel much like a "game". It is more about time management. It challenges you to see how fast can you become a millionaire. If you rent a place, buy shelving, stock it, and hire workers for around the clock shifts, you will make money. Do this again with a larger building. Rinse/repeat. Once you figure out the game loop, there isn't much reason to keep playing. You're setting up infrastructure so that you don't have to do the manual things yourself. 

Adding to the negatives of the gameplay, the controls and camera are frustrating. Why do I use WASD for a car but not for player movement? Why do I use a mouse for player movement, but I can't in the car? Also have fun mis-clicking your vehicle when you are trying to load/unload it and keep entering the vehicle instead. 

Basically its fun until it isn't, so its not really worth 23 dollars full price. Maybe more like 15. So buy on sale or wait until there is more compelling gameplay here to latch on to.

I absolutely love Big Ambitions! From the moment I started playing, I was hooked. The concept is fantastic and the execution is flawless. The game runs smoothly on my computer, even with the graphics turned up to the highest settings.

The attention to detail in this game is impressive. The city is bustling with activity, yet the game never slows down or stutters. It's amazing how many objects and NPCs the game can simulate without any issues.

Driving around the city is an absolute joy. The controls are tight and responsive, and the physics engine feels just right. I love how the game seamlessly transitions from indoor to outdoor environments without any loading screens.

Overall, I highly recommend Big Ambitions to anyone who loves open-world games. It's a masterpiece that should not be missed. Kudos to the developers for creating such an incredible game!

You start a business and it seems automatically profitable, you start another automatically profitable business, wait until you have more money, start another business and so on. I only have 4 businesses right now (All in the small 75m buildings) so I'd say this probably still qualifies as the early game. Maybe this changes in the mid or end game, but the game as it is seems pretty easy, almost like you can't fail unless you specifically try to fail. 

I think it's fun, but I'm probably going to stop playing for a while so I don't burn out on it. I'll let some more updates come in and see if that makes it a little harder. (I have 8.6 hours as of the time I'm writing this, so now you know if I've played it more since writing my review!)

I have played this for 100 hours and I am absolutely hooked in this game. This is something like between sims and a tycoon game and I am a real fan of that. Furnishing your own shops is super fun. Profits in this game are really easy, maybe too easy though after you know how the menus work. This has a lot of potential be a really great game, but it is still early access and I would love to have many features in the future updates. Many features that are lacking are frustrating. 

I WOULD LOVE THESE THINGS TO BE ADDED: 
-Visit your own shops as a customer: 
The most frustrating thing to me is that you cannot really visit your own shops as a customer, there is not really incentive to own the whole city by yourself. It would be really cool to visit your own coffee shop or supermarket because you have to visit them anyway to buy food.
- Better looking shops owned by NPC:
The competitors shop look really bare and unrealistic and are all the copies of each other, so there is no incentive to buy them and furnish them at this point after you have done it once. It is far better to make your own shop from the scratch. They are also ridicilously pricy and there is not really point, because competition is not that hard. 
- Blueprint mode:
I would like to share and download other designs from other players so I would not have to individually design each shop myself and tediously drive multiple trips downtown for days to furnish them. 
- Custom led signs:
I see competitors having great signs but you cannot design them yourself.
- Filters in various lists:
When you own 40 businesses like I do, it is really time consuming to find a specific business menu, I would love to filter the menu. Same goes for workers, when you have hundreds of them. 
- More business types of course
- More fun offices:
More office furniture, like separators to each desks and beauty score that would affect the revenue of office and the happiness of the workers. It is not fun to furnish them, especially when you have to drag each chair, computer and desk separately. 
- Bigger deliveries:
It takes days to furnish a big department store, when you can only order 18 things at a time, twice a day. Even that is limited to 1 delivery / store so you cannot order multiple deliveries from the same store. 
- More gameplay when you own multiple businesses:
After you have set up your stores and headquarters, there is nothing to do, the whole thing runs automatically without any problems ever.
- Color picker:
I would love to have pipette tool for picking the colors from environment when customizing the color of the furniture. 
-Color option when buying furniture, not having the only option to recolor them for a price afterwards, although it is really cool you can do that
-Carts inside the offices too, it is really slow to use your hands only to move the furniture there one by one
-Working yachts so they would actually sail somewhere
the game really should have controller compatiblity being that the keys are so limited . overall i enjoy the game so far and im still learning

Really nice game; very unrealistic as far as traffic and other notable things but still an enjoyable game. As usual i'll list pros and cons below and update as time goes by.
Pros
-Good Tycoon elements (such as short term, long term elements)
-Driving has good control despite not realistic traffic/traffic laws (a lot of players should be in jail, just saying xD)
-Running business is good for early access. (would like a lil more accurate details on how many days i run out of product)
-Good design options would like to see a lil more
Cons
-Needs more furniture options
-Needs more business dynamics (theft)
-Would like to see multi placement instead of single placement
-More happiness options (consume luxury goods, taking shower, attending classes (self defense, yoga?) Vacations?
-More business types to run
-Business balancing, clothing shops make an insane amount of profit while other shops like donuts shops and cigar shops make sad amounts. (my 24 hr clothing store makes me 400k a day vs other shops making around 1k-9k a day. If i were to make the small shops 24 hrs it'd be around 4k-27k a day)
Overall great early access :D

"There's no such thing as an ethical millionaire" - Myself, justifying why I defrauded a casino.

Numerous times playing Big Ambitions, I joyfully exclaimed "I'm Donald Trump, B****ES!" A game where you can establish a business empire across four neighbourhoods in New York while other drivers constantly honk their horns at you for your poor driving skills and propensity to wander out in to the middle of 5th Avenue is naturally going to give you a bit of a power fantasy.

In a third-person RPG setuo, you'll start off as an 18 year old with a generous gift from your uncle. You'll then need to rent out a tiny apartment and get a simple retail job until you've saved up enough money/credit for a loan to start your own retail business. As your uncle, who is fully voiced and characterized, guides you through the basic operation of your store, you'll soon find yourself locked into the core gameplay loop. Trying to scale your businesses up requires learning and utilizing additional mechanics including importing goods, training and managing employees, renovating and designing your spaces, and coordinating operations with a headquarters. Repeat until you suddenly find yourself running all over town checking in on your dozens of businesses, or spend the day at home playing games and watching TV once you got things running like a well-oiled machine.

The game is, at heart, a time management game. You only get so many hours in the day, support businesses like ad agencies and supply stores have their own opening hours, and certain things need to be completed by a certain time or on a certain day. Although most may assume the game revolves around spending your money wisely, I've found the money side of things to be relatively easy and simple. Most of the time, your businesses are going to succeed as long as you are paying attention to the requirements and needs of the business.

Big Ambitions's greatest strength, coincidentally, lies in its potential. The game's systems are very modular, meaning it should be easy to add additional business types, furniture, mechanics or specialized support businesses down the line. Adding in official mod support is hopefully a major consideration for the studio as it could offload a lot of the work in that area.

This is where things get tricky, however. Outside of the core gameplay loop, the game is a little bare-bones which is completely understandable for an Early Access title. By no means is the game unplayable or missing core features, but after I finished my main headquarters and set up my logistics, there was little left to do other than open a duplicate business, buy a building that wasn't for sale, or play video games for hours, which made me realize I could play a different game at that point. While I have no concern that additional things will be added, I do worry that the studio might start suffering from "Kickstarter Bloat". They have previously stated this is definitely their passion project and, after receiving overwhelmingly positive support on their initial Steam release, they have stated that, essentially, their plans and goals have expanded. It will be interesting to see how well they manage their own expectations as well as find a balance from the demands of an ever-increasing audience.

Overall, Big Ambitions has an incredibly addictive core gameplay loop, similar to the studio's previous entry, and shows a lot of thoughtful design decisions to help aid further development. Everything implemented works well and the game looks and sounds great as well. All in all, the game has an incredibly strong foundation and it will definitely be worth keeping an eye as it develops if you're not already interested.

I never knew I needed a game like this, till I saw it. It's kind of a mix of a Stardew Valley, and a traditional business sim. I had fun early on, when I didn't really know what I was doing. running around to keep stores running, getting sent to the hospital a couple times. Setting up a Jewerly store before I was ready for it, and watching my modest daily income suddenly turn into a red death spiral. XD

Even in this unfinished state, there's so many well thought out little details, and features you wouldn't expect so early on. Like being able to setup deliveries and campaigns over the phone, after you've been to a business. Being able to pay for inventory directly from your vehicle inside the big wholesale place, change the colors of most items, and edit the register line for the customers.

There's still a long way to go, but the foundations are mostly here. The gameplay loop of setting up stores, supplying them with stock at first, and later setting up warehouses and HQ's to help automate them, while trying to look after your own character, is fun. It mostly just needs more content.

...And mod support. ;)

I wasn't really sure how to feel about this game.  I think if you want to play a tycoon type game and you're only interested in the tycoon aspects, then you'll probably enjoy this game.   If you're interested in a more immersive life sim type of game, I think you'll be disappointed.  What I mean is you never really feel like you live in the world, but building up your business is interesting and I think this game does it well.  However, you'll get to a point in the game where your business is more automated.  You hire employees to do most of the work for you.  So, at that point what is there left for you to do?    The game is pretty much over and I can't see myself doing it all over again.

I know it is extremely early in my play time to start a review but I just couldn't help myself.  I am in love with this game.  It crashes every time I click "Save and exit to desktop", the tutorial barely told me anything, the buildings disappear depending on your angle in game, you have to learn a lot of the stuff on your own, and the game itself is pretty hard for newcomers, but I say all that to still say I am in love with this game.

I saw a buddy playing this and immediately started thinking of the Sims.  Little did I know, this is quite a bit better.  Instead of just being told "You went to work" or "You got a promotion", you get to see it all happen first hand.  You get to pick your business.  You get to pick your locations.  Almost everything is opened to you.  You don't really have limits on what you can accomplish, and that is great for these types of games.

If you love Sims, Cities Skylines, Sim City, or other life simulation games, but need a little something extra to it, this is the game.  I would have loved for the price to be a little lower, but whatever.  Is what it is.  I haven't felt this sucked into a game since Drug Dealer Simulator, and this has way more opportunity and options.  I always wanted to play the Startup game from the same Dev's and this game is making me wonder if I need to give that a shot too.  Great work Devs.  This is a banger right here.  Give me a free copy so I can get my homie the game to stream.

So me and my friend are coming up on a combined 20+ hours already, have also played "together" by streaming each other starting a new save game. 

You're always learning new tricks so far, how to best manage your business, how to maximize profit, and it's just incredibly fun if you're into games like this. Yes, not everything is perfect, it still needs some small but important features like proper staff needs, more simulation of the competition etc. but there I see a lot of potential, which the developers surely know on. 

I have read a lot that later quickly runs out of content, so from 40-60 game hours. But when I see the roadmap from the developer, I have high hopes that this is still a real Gem. In any case, absolute buy recommendation. Let's see when the game becomes repetitive, but for 20 € to have 40-60 hours of fun, worth it all.

It's like playing Sims 2 - Open for business but in an open world and you can drive your car around! I like it a lot. However this recommendation comes with a warning. The game looks polished at first but you will soon notice how bare bones it is in some areas. There is a hunger bar but there are absolutely no consequences for not eating. The game tells you to keep your character happy but there are no benefits to it...
I played the game on normal difficulty until I made over a million a week from huge retail shops that sell almost every product there is. Took me around 40 hours. Now uncle Frank wants me to be worth 50 Million, but to be honest I lost interest at this point. There seem to be no more features for me to explore. Bought the fastest car, had some fun with it, but now I don't really know what to do with my money anymore.
I really hope they are going to add some more role-play elements to the game, like going to crowded night clubs or attending to actual meetings in your headquarters. My character spent weeks in his apartment doing home-office from his phone, and playing videogames for no reason... please devs: give us more reasons to leave the house :)
we need startup company internet thing integrated for web design stuff
I just want to be a drug kingpin, right out the gate. It's got a very original grand theft auto feel.

I'll join the chorus of people who like this game. At first it would seem to not be that much fun, it's basically a business sim, right? But by involving the player using role-playing it makes it rather addicting. I feel involved because I can actually go to these places, buy furniture and stock for the shelves and put them where I want in the stores. I'm up at the crack of dawn because I'm running low on paper bags and I need to restock them. I'm looking at resumes so I can hire a lawyer to work for me who [i]doesn't[/i] need an executive desk. I'm looking at the work schedule at my coffee shop so I can keep the part time folks from working too much and the full time folks from having too few hours. I have to drive my work van to a garage because the last time I was rushing to reach the appliance store before it closed I rammed a couple of trucks. 

Wait, what? Is this fun? Surprisingly, it is for me and I'm sure for a lot of folks. The gameplay isn't terribly deep right now, although the devs have a detailed roadmap, but it is engaging enough that I've put in over thirty hours and am not bored of it at all.

I've never written a review for a game but this one deserves it! It's so addicting. Graphics certainly have room for improvement but the actual game concept and game play is great! The only recommendation I'd make to the developers is add gyms as an industry. Buying and using gyms would mirror this staple of society and would certainly be a valuable addition to the game. Not only would starting a gym, purchasing equipment, and setting up membership costs be a fun addition for passive income, but you could add a small smoothie bar to maintain inventory. You could also add a dynamic where using gyms would increase energy levels (or at least slow the energy drain) and impact hunger. That's just my thoughts. Again, the game is extremely addicting as is. Great job!!!

tldr: idle-clicker game with very shallow economic simulation part, which in many areas needs to bring significantly more quality-of-life improvements in addition to more game depth. At the moment, the game is not recommended. 

tldr: idle clicker Spiel mit sehr seichtem WiSi-Anteil, welcher in vielen Bereichen deutlich mehr QoL-Verbesserungen und mehr Spielteife benötigt. Momentan empfehle ich das Spiel nicht.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This review will be adjusted should anything change in the game.

It's pointless to ponder why this game is so hyped. As we all know, there is no accounting for taste. However, to call the game an economic sim is quite cocky, and when I read reviews that say it's one of the best eco-sims of the last few years, it says more about the reviewer's gaming level than about the game and it really needs some counter statements. 

Big Ambitions falls far short of an economic simulation. As others have reported, it is basically an idle-clicker. For the first few hours, you're just running around trying to get your first automation (warehouse, buyers, logisticians, drivers) up and running. 70% walking or driving, 20% annoying and cumbersome store setup, 10% EconomySim. After that, almost everything can be organized out of HQ. Only new warehouses/shops have to be set up manually. From then on, you virtually only drive a cab to a) gamble in the casino (boring, since exploitable) and b) to the tax office to pay your taxes. The rest is done via the HQ. Market analyses are so shallow that the term economic simulation can only be understood as an ambition, which the game currently fails at.

Deliveries from external companies to the own companies have to be moved manually (not the import). If this does not happen, no new contractor delivery can take place (because the pallet is still there and only one may spawn. This is easy with 5 companies, but not with 20 or more. The ability to interact with objects such as delivery pallets is really poorly solved: 

If you open a large store and then first order some 100 items from Ikea, the office supplier or the store supplier by phone but a maximum of 18 items per order is possible, it gets annoying. Because of this bootleneck you need (ingame) days to setup big companiers. And as I said, if this one pallet is there, the other (scheduled) orders of the facility are simply canceled  (because the delivey slot is occupied). 
At the first big store there is still a certain hype and you just do it, but at the fourth or fifth it becomes dull, at the 10 store it is unbearable.  An open-plan office quickly has 50 employees, which means 50 tables, 50 chairs, 50 PCs, 50 speakers, couch, coffee machine, cabinets and all the little gimmick stuff like carpets, Flowers, Plants and so on... every single item you have to move and setup by hand. - Dont get me wrong, I really like grindy games, but there is a difference between grind and chore. Big Ambitions' lategame is sadly the latter.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Diese Rezension wird angepasst, sollte sich am Spiel etwas ändern.

Es ist müßig, darüber zu grübeln, warum dieses Spiel so gehypt wird. Über Geschmack lässt sich bekanntlich nicht streiten. Das Spiel jedoch als Wirtschaftssimulation zu bezeichnen, ist ziemlich dreist, und wenn ich Rezensionen lese, in denen es als eine der besten Wirtschafts-Simulationen der letzten Jahre bezeichnet wird, sagt das mehr über das Spielniveau des Rezensenten aus als über das Spiel, und es bedarf wirklich einiger Gegenstimmen. 

Big Ambitions ist weit davon entfernt, eine Wirtschaftssimulation zu sein. Wie bereits von anderen berichtet, handelt es sich im Grunde um einen idle-Klicker. In den ersten paar Stunden rennt man fast nur herum und versucht, seine erste Automatisierung (Lager, Einkäufer, Logistiker, Fahrer) zum Laufen zu bringen. 70% zu Fuß oder mit dem Auto, 20% lästige und umständliche Ladeneinrichtung, 10% EconomySim. Danach kann fast alles vom HQ aus organisiert werden. Nur neue Lager/Läden/Fahrzeuge müssen manuell eingerichtet werden. Von da an fährt man meist nur noch mit dem Taxi (schneller als das eigene Auto) zum Glücksspiel im Casino (langweilig, da ausbeutbar), zum Finanzamt, um seine Steuern zu bezahlen oder eben zum Einrichten der Shops . Der Rest wird über das HQ erledigt. Die Marktanalysen sind dabei jedoch so oberflächlich, dass der Begriff Wirtschaftssimulation nur als Anspruch verstanden werden kann, an dem das Spiel vorerst scheitert.

Lieferungen von Fremdfirmen an die eigenen Firmen müssen manuell verschoben werden (nicht der Import). Geschieht dies nicht, kann keine neue Fremdfirmenlieferung erfolgen (weil die Palette noch da ist und nur eine spawnen darf. Dies ist bei 5 Firmen einfach, aber nicht bei 20 oder mehr. Die Möglichkeit, mit Objekten wie Lieferpaletten zu interagieren, ist wirklich schlecht gelöst: 

Wenn man einen großen Laden eröffnet und dann erst mal 100 Artikel bei Ikea, dem Büroausstatter oder dem Ladenausstatter per Telefon bestellt, aber maximal 18 Artikel pro Bestellung möglich sind, wird es ärgerlich. Wegen dieses Engpasses braucht man (ingame) Tage, um große Geschäfte einzurichten. Und wie gesagt, wenn diese eine Palette noch nicht leer geräumt wurde, wenn die nächste Lieferung termniert ist, werden die anderen (geplanten) Bestellungen der Einrichtung einfach storniert, weil Lieferslot nicht verfügbar. 

Bei der ersten großen Filiale gibt es noch einen gewissen Hype und man macht es einfach, aber bei der vierten oder fünften wird es langweilig, bei der 10 Filiale ist es unerträglich.  Ein Großraumbüro hat schnell 50 Mitarbeiter, das bedeutet 50 Tische, 50 Stühle, 50 PCs, 50 Lautsprecher, Couch, Kaffeemaschine, Schränke und all die kleinen Gimmicks wie Teppiche, Blumen, Pflanzen und so weiter... alles muss man von Hand bewegen und aufbauen. - Versteht mich nicht falsch, ich mag grindige Spiele, aber es gibt einen Unterschied zwischen grindig und lästig. Das derzeitige Lategame  ist leider letzteres.
Started playing based on Real Civil Engineer youtube video, happy customer.

As someone who previously spent a lot of time playing tycoon games on mobile, this is a truly fantastic implementation for the (comparatively) bigger screen! With great attention to detail, and lots of things to learn as you go, this game will keep you busy for a long time to come.

The big twist as compared to other games of this genre, being that you are a person in the world, you are given a sense of immersion that isn't usually offered, you can take real control over your time, money and ambitions, and get the opportunity to tell your own story of success on each playthrough.

I don't often take the time to leave game reviews, but this game is worth it, I am sure if you try it, you'll quickly become hooked too!

Hi, I played till I reached a net worth of 100,000,000. Here are my quality of life suggestions:

- All contacts should be categorized & visible without the need to scroll (bank, import, furniture etc.). Messages from employees should not clutter the contact list.
- Make it possible to automatically invest a percentage of your income.
- Make it possible to walk with WASD keys (was counterintuitive to use my keyboard for driving & mouse for walking)
- Furniture should be delivered into the building so it's less tedious & players can immediately start placing objects (maybe solved with a designated delivery area inside bigger buildings like in real life)
- There should be a 'build mode' players can switch to inside buildings so they don't need to walk around when rearranging objects that are outside of their characters view.
- When coloring furniture it should highlight which part the player is coloring & there should be more pre-prepared color options to choose from.
- Players should get a warning if there are not enough shelves inside a store to handle the whole delivery from the warehouse.
- Indicate in the description of items how much costumers they can handle.
- Make it possible to set up uniforms for a business instead doing it individually for each employee.
- Make it possible to skip more than one day or skip days faster, with the possibility to ignore warnings or to stop time-travel if a warning pops up.
- Bigger carpets : D

I recently stumbled upon a game that's worth writing a review for, something that I rarely do. Big Ambitions has really caught my attention, and I'm glad I took a chance on it.

What I love about Big Ambitions is how it manages to balance the business simulation with the human element of running a company. The city feels authentic and immersive, and you can add your own personal touch to your store. It's refreshing to see a game that doesn't forget about the people behind the business and the impact they have on their community.

The game mechanics are solid and make sense, making it easy to get lost in the gameplay. The attention to detail is impressive, and it's clear that the developers put a lot of thought into the game's design. I'm excited to see what other features the game has in store and how it will continue to evolve.

Overall, I'm thoroughly impressed with Big Ambitions and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a well-designed business simulator with heart.

Nothing like working the ole 9-5 up at the grocery and coming home to play video games all night in my studio apartment. 10/10 life sim realism

I would hate to use the term "unique" to describe Big Ambitions, but it is a fairly unusual take on several genres.  It's too early to call it something like "The Sims meets Grand Theft Auto except you are a small business owner" since that implies *quite* a bit that isn't true about the game.  In reality it's closer to Harvest Moon than either, but again that implies quite a bit that isn't here either.  What *is* here is a day-to-day loop where you manage your life and, as the game focuses quite a bit on it, one or more small businesses.  This is also where it grasps at some uniqueness: you could easily run a single business by yourself and one could argue that is just as or even more satisfying that running multiple.

For example, you set up shop in a small building with limited items.  Over time you add new things for sale, improve the decor and save up.  Eventually you can move to a better/more profitable location, and so you pack up all your furniture and goods, haul them across town and set up your store again.  Like, yes you can run multiple stores but that's where the life sim swoops in.  Grabbing a cup of coffee before rushing across town to take a load of paper bags to a business running low, opening up a shop for an extra day because your hired worker won't run that shift and you want to make some extra bread, rushing to the store to buy some fake plants before realizing you haven't eaten all day and now the grocery is closed.  These are the moments that the game thrives under, and they feel organic and scale with your businesses.  There's something exciting about hiring a new worker to pick up shifts which frees you up to pursue other actions.

This is also where the game runs out of steam the fastest: the life sim.  Right now you have a couple of bars to manage but it's neither challenging, nor deep.  You have no relationships with your employees or other people, no hobbies to pursue outside of work.  Given *that* is what ultimately elevates the life sim and casts conflict into the business sim, it's absence is felt immediately.  It's good that investing in your businesses is fun since that offsets it a bit, but while I wouldn't expect a full The Sims-style social life I would argue that the game would be substantially stronger for it.  This is just blue sky, but being able to go play golf with some investors in your company would be fucking amazing considering on the other end of the spectrum is rushing to buy condiments you need for tomorrow's shift.  I don't think Big Ambitions will get quite that far, but for the price and the content on offer I think you'll have a good time with this one even in Early Access.
AWESOME GAME Cant wait to see when they open workshop to have new stores and new items we can sell

Really solid for early access! Really interesting idea of mixing a Sims-esque RPG with a business management Sim. 

Thus far Logan Roy has opened up Roy's Toys gift shop and Shiv's Sliders. Happy to announce we've purchased the first office space for Waystar | Royco. 

Asides from letting me live out my Succession fan fiction I have a few notes. There's plenty of potential for a bit "more" of everything... more products to sell would be nice to diversify the types of businesses we can run. More furniture/interior design options would be great. Foot traffic seems to affect office jobs such as law offices a lot more than it should compared to a retail/restaurant business. Inflation is weird in the game, simply the more cash you have the bigger hit you're going to take from negative interest. It incentivizes you to keep your balance as close to $0 as possible. The game's Help section mentions some ways to avoid "inflation" penalties for keeping a high balance... such as investing in stocks, investing in a new business or upgrading one you already have. It just feels a bit counter entrepreneurial to avoid a cash balance/emergency fund. Theres some minor customer pathfinding issues and some other quality of life upgrades I expect they'll continue to work on so I'm not too concerned. 

Looking forward to what future updates bring!

For early access it's really good, but it has a few glaring issues. If I see some of the needed changes then I'll change my review. 

The scaling of inflation is totally out of hand imbalanced and should be a much smaller amortized percentage each week. The "inflation" aspect, termed as "negative interest", while creative, as implemented is ridiculous on its face. Holding more than 50k? Prepare to get taxed about 10% per... year? per....quarter? Nope, per week. Or day, it's so frequent I can't even tell, and I have no wish to lose half my bank again to that nonsense. Currently it is sitting at 14,204% per year. Not good.

It needs quite a bit of other polishing and a lot of QOL additions, such as click-and-drag directional placement for objects in the world, and being able to rotate objects "the other way" rather than having to click the rotate button 8 times for every item. Populating a new retail location is tedious and annoying due to rotation-spam during placement.

Marketing seems to be underpowered for office building capacity, and foot traffic is too powerful. A law office shouldn't only receive 4 customers/day with max marketing because the law office has low "foot traffic". Seriously, what does foot traffic matter for an expensive and purely service oriented business? Do people walk down the street, walk past a law office and think to themselves "huh, I'm gonna spend $500 right now for a quick consultation." If anything, low foot traffic should be a plus, and there should certainly not be a cap for marketing's effect on customer capacity.

Game has huge potential, can go in multiple directions in more details, but it is too early for it as it has few bugs. Bugs are not critical, but I will still name few:
1. Sometimes when going outside from building there is only gray view, unable to save or load. Had to re-install game, because next time when I launched game I was seeing name-tags for buttons.
2. Traffic needs re-construction. I.e. when I drive next to other car, other car decides to move to my lane without checking if anything is there. Or the line, where you do U turn (next to retail or the first import/export point), AI does not understand how to make that U turn and smashes cars into each other.
3. We need more variations of life, like dogs, people jogging, people being busy too or being more important than me (i.e. building's that I am currently renting landlord). Well, hoping you get what I mean here.
4. Sound meter keeps re-adjusting itself after some time and game does not remember music bar setting as well, which makes me always adjust it back where I want every game session.
5. Daily income usually is being shown as 50% of what I am really getting.
6. Happened only once, but when adjusting import order - adjusted order just stopped being delivered. Yes, I have checked if I have clicked "Order", it was checked. Minimum price for order was in red, but had two of them like this, one worked just fine, other didn't deliver.

Other than that - game is interesting. Even made me thinking about being entrepreneur myself lol.

When playing these kinds of games I like to take my time and go slow, but my 40 hours are already 10 to many. There is simply nothing more to get out of it.

The controls and UI may be clunky, some of the elements may be unrealistic, but damn this is a fun and original simulator. The little details and life simulation elements are charming and it does capture the feeling of starting a new business quite well at times.

The main thing I'd like to see improved is the UI and UX -- it would be nice to be able to see my margins displayed for each product on sale and seeing as we can drive using WASD I'd like to be able to walk around using those controls too as it's a bit jarring to keep switching.

Great tycoon game with Amazon depth.

Pros: 
- Very realistic: there is no buy button that makes an object magically appear in front of you, want that desk for your office? Well drive to the furniture store and get the desk yourself, want groceries? Go get them at the super market, want a bunch of shelves for your business but don't want to drive? Call them and ask them to ship them next dayto your door. Like I said great depth and realism.

-Open world (ish): You can freely move in a part of New York city, it covers 4 neighborhoods working class/ middle class / middle-upper class/ upper class, which give different options to open business, it feels great to not be confined to your store space only. 

- Business management: It is very detailed and complete, you can go from creating a little store to managing an empire, setting HR offices, Importing stuff, Planning logistics to deliver merchandise to all your stores.

- Business Variety: you can open a gift shop, foods store, fast food restaurant, lawyer office and many more, you can combine most of them in any way you like.

Cons:
- Employees management: the interactions with your employees is non existent, you can't raise their salaries, give any benefit, nothing, they have pretty basic requests like having a part time or full time, or asking for the office to have a specific thing (like a fridge or a big table), it really feels very lacking compared to the depth that other aspects have, i read in a future update this will get polished.

- Real State: No real benefits of buying buildings, they are super expensive, even when you have several stores producing a lot of money it is extremely hard to buy buildings, and if you do the rent is very cheap to get any benefit from it. I also heard this is being polished. 

- Your character needs: it also feels very lacking, you have 3 needs: eat, sleep and fun. If you miss any there is no real consecuences at certain point it feels more like an annoying thing to complete rather than a fun one, you can buy stuff for your house and you can't interact with most of it, and if you do it is pretty basic like watching tv, it needs a LOT of polish to feel like it is worth it to reserve time for your character rather than in your business.

Pretty much those would be my only negative points about the game, out of that it is a great experience and if you like tycoon/ strategy games this will give you tons of hours of fun, keep the good work going!

Short answer, 6/10.

This is going to be long if you want to read it but I'm going in depth here.
Long Answer:
I was very excited for this game for a long time. I've had it on my wishlist for almost a year. It was supposed to come out in August last year, but that got delayed. I was a BIG supporter of this companies first game, because they were so in touch with their community. I pointed out a problem, within 5 mins the developers reached out to me and pushed an update. And startup company was a great game. And as I mentioned, I had REALLY high hopes for this game. Despite not having the funds to buy it instantly, I decided to buy it now. Here is my summary.

Before I begin, I'm not a hater. This is just my honest opinion.
PROS:
-It's strangely satisfying. Something about trying to make sure you have everything you need and rushing around to get it all before you go into the red is fun.
-It takes a good bit of time if you're looking for something to do.
-It's pretty brainless, you can easily run it on the side as you're doing something else, but if you really pay attention, you can find some more success.
-There's a decent bit of customization you can do to your interiors depending on how you want and if you have the funds.
-It's a fun little thing to have running from time to time and seeing your success go up.
-There are some easter eggs if you explore a little.
-There is some variation in the AI businesses when it comes to what the same types of businesses in different locations do. For example, there are 2 marketing firms on the map, and they both offer a special kind of marketing.
-The driving is a fun challenge and racing to not hit someone is fun.
-This game has a LOT of potential to be something much greater.
-Every run can be different.
-It gets a lot more in depth in terms of the initial setup of your business once you start figuring our supply chains, warehouses, stock, employees etc. But after that, it becomes automated and there's not much to do.

CONS:
-A lot of people are saying this is sims meets GTA. It's not. You can't really interact with anyone unless you're trying to buy something or place an order for store managers to deliver directly to your business. This is the only interactions you get.
-There is almost no competition. Depending on which district you set your business up in, you may see competition for the same products, but there is no way to see who this competition is or even check what their prices are to be competitive.
-As I mentioned earlier, there is no interaction with anyone. No negotiating prices, no negotiating rent, no economies of scale, nothing.
-There is no real way to see what your customers want or what their expectations are.
-There's no dynamics to the world. Every AI business is fixed, they don't move or change, or really seem to compete with each other at all. They just exist.
-You can't interact with your own business. For example, if you open a cafe and want to eat at your own cafe to fill your hunger bar, you just can't. You HAVE to go spend money at your competitors.
-The jobs offer nothing in terms of actually working. All you do is skip time until the end of your shift and make money. That's all.
-The actual life sim aspect of this game is very mediocre. All you do is eat and sleep once a day to make sure you don't pass out and go to the hospital. That's it. No social life, no way to do much.
-The moving system is done by middle clicking so your character follows your mouse, or clicking where you want him to go. WASD would be a nice addition in the options to switch to. The mouse movement is annoying.
-There is no way to see a financial overview of each individual business. You can only see your profit margin, which I'm not sure if it's actually your profit or just your revenue, because the business overview page always shows I'm in the red despite making money everyday, but when you click on the business itself it shows a green profit margin. But there are no way to see your expenses or exactly what you're paying your employees.
-When you're hiring employees, the hiring firms just give you random part time and full time employees. You can't choose which one you want, which can get really annoying. You have to spend more money on more hiring campaigns just to find one.

In conclusion, I'm giving this an upvote because the devs have always been open, they have a very clear roadmap, though I don't believe it addresses many of the issues I pointed out, but as I said earlier, this game has GREAT potential to be something fantastic if they can add a little bit of life to it. Currently, it's a clicking simulator. You click here and click there, and all you're really doing is ordering materials and picking up equipment to place in your buildings for all your businesses for your employees to work. That's all it is really. Fun to leave in the background, but that's about it. 
I really hope they add a bit more interactivity for the player and between the AI in this game. It can go places. I have hope. That's the only reason I'm voting yes here.

20hr deep and i think it is review time. I DO NOT RECOMMEND IN THIS CURRENT STATE. It runs well and i haven't encountered really any bugs. Certainly not game breaking bugs. The issue i have with this game is the lack of content for the price tag. This plays very much like an early alpha in terms of content. It's almost like a proof of concept.

The business selection is lacking but fine i understand it's early access.....but the assets are extremely lacking. There are 1 type of display for every single item you can sell. There is almost zero variance. I assume this will change with time, hopefully.

Content is extremely lacking as-well. You are forced to live through 24hr days but in reality you'll only utilize 1-2hr unless you're opening a business. You can get any business type up running and self sufficient in 2 days, maybe 3-4 for large operations. 80% of your time will be sleeping, eating, playing games/watching tv then sleeping for another 24hr. This goes on for days and days....until you get bored and open another business. This is literally all there is to do at this time.....i guess decorate your apartment/office but at a point your very limited by furniture type.

Early access is pretty much dead at this point. Think back to the last EA game that came out (especially in this genre) that lived up to the promises made(rim world?). There's so much potential here.....they should just open it up to modders and patch is official ports of popular mods. It seems thats the special sauce to these kind of games surviving early access.

I not only like the basic idea of the game, no I love it. But the game also exhausts itself incredibly quickly. Even after my playing time, 
I spend most of the day sitting in my flat and skipping through until there's something to do. What fun would it be to open another shop at this point? It's always the same procedure. As an experienced sim player, you quickly figure out how to get the most out of it, and then? Open a law firm - sounds great at first, but I rent a room, put lawyers in it and vary the fee until I reach the possible maximum. That's it. That's it for every other shop.
 The lifeim part is also a great idea, but it's a minimum of possibilities. Investing in shares is advertised, but the reality is that I can pay money into 3 different shares and they go up or down by pure chance. 
There is also almost no furniture or anything else - which means I always buy the same ones. I think the developers are making a huge mistake by setting modding to sometime after release - a Steam Workshop would be the key thing for this game to generate unlimited content. And that's what this game is missing. 
Actually, the game can already come out of the EA now - because the sandbox, the basic framework, it all fits great. But there is just a massive lack of content (especially things to buy) and therefore you should really gear your game more towards modding. 
Maybe wait and see if the developers really deliver something on a regular basis, and then go for it and support it, because otherwise games like this simply won't exist anymore.

Feels good when you're not actually the one in the grindset.

Edit: The gameplay loop seems to stop being interesting after getting up to like, 15 or so businesses. I got the imports, I got warehouses shipping to sub-warehouses to support a growing web of businesses throughout the city, I got my hq loaded with desks, logistics and HR guys, all that's left to my gameplay loop is setting up new businesses and restructuring my warehouse web when needed. (Rent space, order furniture, place furniture, hire, train, schedule employees, rinse repeat) I need an option to make a template of some sort to start getting these businesses set up automatically. A service I'd be happy to pay in-game cash for. I never thought of a use for retail spaces bigger than 280sqft besides getting a bigger customer flow. The math seems to check out but it's not something I'd be willing to bet on or bother with until I don't actually need the money. Experimentation reqd.

I'd call it a feature that you can sleep an entire day, wake up for 2 minutes to set up a business entirely on your phone, then go back to sleep for another day, rinse repeat, without eating anything for a month, without dying. The bad part is that's not a super interesting gameplay loop. 

Also: If you use cheat engine to blow out a game after getting bored with it, DO NOT edit your cash balance to the billions and/or freeze the value, then try to buy every building in town. I think there's a memory leak or something that overrided something important in my OS, resulting in a bluescreen-reboot loop. Had to reinstall the OS.

Big Ambitions has big ambitions and has lost sight of the details in the process. There are lots of different types of businesses you can run but ultimately it all feels the same as there are only 2 types of employees: Cleaners and Customer Service. No Cook for restaurants or Baristas for Coffee Shops. This means that the only different between types of business is the demand for the product they sell.

There's also a major issue with how pointless and manual your player character is. You have to manually move furniture around stores yourself by grabbing the object and moving it to the place you want it to go. At some point there should really be a more SIMS like system of just buying the objects from a catalogue and placing them in the store - having them delivered by the manufacturer: I don't like the fact that my CEO has to drive to IKEA and buy tables himself.

The Sleep - Food - Mood meters are also entirely redundant. Mood is impossible to keep up and is entirely ignorable, Food is easy to keep up and is entirely ignorable and Sleep will always be maxed out because you spend most of your time sleeping in your car waiting for something to happen.

I enjoy where the game is trying to go but it's completely dropped a load of basic functions in order to get there.
If you want to have a player character with wants and needs then you need to give us a reason to fulfil those wants and needs. Make the game a bit more SIMS - Increase the penalty for not fulfilling their needs and give us a reward for doing it. Right now it's just a slightly tedious task that I can just skip by sleeping in the car. Apparently my character is battery powered and just plugs in for the night (Or day since you can sleep for a week straight if you want to (There is in fact no reason not to other than it costing you real life time to do).

I cannot recommend the game in its current state. At first glace there's a lot to do but in actuality there's nothing to do at all since none of it matters and all of it is the same.

EDIT: I also want to say that the delivery vans not actually going anywhere and just teleporting the goods to the store was really disapointing.

It is playable... and feels like a competent entry the first few hours.

...but before too long, the economy ends up feeling as shallow as a sheet of paper.
The biggest disappointment for me was the lack of graphs showing how the different businesses were doing hour to hour/day to day/week over week.   Just two meager graphs showing total customers - one for the day before - and one for the last 7 days. Not last "monday-through-friday", but last 7 days... as if a Monday would play out exactly the same as a Friday, or a Sunday... 

Businesses fail to give the appearances of being bustling with life when the player enters... only to send all the customers in a single wave - causing the tills to be instantly overwhelmed. Which lead me to believe I had to add more tills... When in fact I was already wasting having too many of them.

Staffing anything larger than a small gift-shop is also an outright pain - especially if you want to exchange an employee (to fire, or train) - as one has to do this on a day-per-day basis. (Rather than having a "shift" which one then just staffs)

I hope the dev stays with it and fleshes out the systems that are already in - rather than adding new ones...
It is a reasonably solid entry for an Early Access, which is the main reason I'm giving it a thumbs up...

TLDR; Somewhat entertaining for a handful of hours...

The game is just fun.  Lots to do , a bit clunky in some places..but I really like the way you have to run all over to get things done.

There's a lot of potential here. It's a fun game as it stands, but things do get a little samey after a while. At my current playtime, I've about 'completed' the game. As a sandbox, there's obviously always more to do, but it's more of the same at this point. 

The main goal is to make numbers go up, and as others have pointed out, it's an effective (if debatably unintentional) critique of capitalism. Once you're making ~50K a day in profits, there's not much to spend your money on other than things that are expensive for the sake of being expensive. You can buy luxury cars and a luxury apartment, and fill it with expensive stuff to demonstrate your wealth, but other than the cars, there's no real impact on gameplay.

Interestingly, this does aid the role playing part of the game. You can customize your virtual space and fill the block with your own personal fleet of supercars. The cars are quite a fun touch, as each one drives differently, although I do wish the top of the line sports cars didn't constantly sound like an electric drill working overtime.

Lategame concerns aside, getting your first several businesses set up and automated, running errands to help keep your businesses afloat, delivering products, covering shifts, and eventually setting up a distribution network and a headquarters, is all quite fun. I'd say for 30 hours or so of enjoyment, it's worth it.

Just don't expect (at the moment) the type of replayability or infinite growth possible with a game like Factorio. The "endgame" is to do more of the same, and although there are some plans in the near future to alleviate the tedium of that (blueprints), once that tedium is gone I'm not sure what's left, other than watching numbers go up.

This game shows a lot of promise but it does have a ways to go. Whilst the core game-play loop is fun for a while it becomes clear that the game is fairly shallow and the mechanics suffice to say aren't yet at a stage of real polish (such as marketing, decoration, layout of stores etc) basically there is some stuff to do in the game but at this point none of its really well fleshed out. One example is law firms. You can get a law firm and put it in an area that has the highest level of demand, give it marketing, and tick all the satisfaction boxes, yet, that law firm will only attract the same amount of customers as your tiny little one in another district with nowhere near the same demand, marketing or satisfaction. You still get to experience the game in its early access state but like I said its pretty flawed atm.

This game just simply needs... more but in saying that what they already have and what will be added will also need to go through some serious polish so I am not too sure of how much more they would be able to pull off in terms of scope.

It is worth it at the price if you like games like this and want to experience it now but if you only dabble in them or prefer to see how it turns out at the end of early access then either wish-list it or wait for a sale. Unless they abandon it or really mess up the rest of development this game will be quite something upon its release

more job options like chef, server, clerk, barista and so on would just make sense to me.

I would not recommend the game at the stage it is in now. That being said, it's still in early access and it remains to be seen whether it can actually fulfill it's potential (I'll come back and update this review if necessary).

Right now the game mechanics are closer to a mobile game than an actual tycoon type of game. You keep grinding the mundane tasks, setting up retail after retail, warehouse after warehouse and so on. They all work the exact same so there's absolutely no variation in this at all. You also have your office businesses, which really are just you renting a space, getting a desk, computer and a chair and hiring a dude, or several dudes. That's it - nothing more to do there, ever.

At this stage, there really isn't any sort of role-playing involved in the game, apart from the cheap talking head of an uncle ordering you to go on a cruise or something. Eating, sleeping and "fun" are all just empty mechanics: you eat from your fridge before bed and all the "fun" meter does is it makes you "sad" so you have to sit at your home computer and play games (skip time) for a couple of hours.

Apart from building your businesses, there really isn't anything to do in the game. You can either not hire people to get full schedules (meaning you have to go to your retail and skip time by "working"), or if you do hire, there really isn't all that much to do besides waiting to get enough money to open yet another retail.

So right now all there is to do in this game is:
1. wait until you get enough money (skip time)
2. work at your retail (skip time)
3. run tasks for your retails (drive from A to B, deliver items X, Y, Z)
4. open new businesses (works exactly like step 3)

So yeah. If you like driving around in an old GTA style city and skipping time, this game is right up your alley.

The good:
*The gameplay loop is fun, simple and stratifying. You can really get nitty gritty in running your business if you like or you can micromanage the hell out of it.
*It runs fine. I assume they'll optimise more, but it runs good for early access.

The bad:

*The intro is pretty dull but I get why it is the way it is. Honestly not sure how you could get it more interesting though.
*It runs fine. I assume they'll optimise more, but it runs good for early access.

I'm all for management games, resource management, simulation, mundane tasks, etc. However, this not it. I'm beyond astonished at the nearly 4,000 OVERWHELMINGLY POSITIVE reviews. It really makes me rethink my entire life is a lie.

This game is a collage of crippling mundane tasks. I don't think people realize how much this game is actually indirectly forcing you to make a binary choice out of something that should have a lot of nuance given time, speed, distance to common resources, etc.

Want to pick up more resources for your business? Then shut your business down for a full day or more and hope you can get to the wholesale store, buy the resources (if you REMEMBER EXACTLY what you need), and good luck on getting back, stocking shelves, etc before the day runs out. Need to eat? Ya cram that mechanic in just before bed. It's another mundane (click here do this) pointless task.

I'm done writing this and feel like watching hockey now. You get the idea. Over and out!

I set up my first business and slept only spending time making deliveries and cleaning when needed. When that was going well I opened the next one. Now I have just bought a HQ and had to pry myself from the game to sleep. Excellent so far!

Now this is how you do early access.

What I missed in Planet Zoo and Planet Coaster in management, this game makes up for it. There are still plenty of things on the road map to be added but for Early Access I am amazed how much gameplay is already available. What I am missing mostly is actually on the road map to be added and if you head to their site for Big Ambitions - people give feedback on the game all the time that the Dev actually takes time to read. For the amount that I paid - I am extremely happy with this game and looking forward to the next road map release scheduled in May.
That being said, I suggest new players to read up a little bit on tips&tricks online since the game only teaches you the bare bone fundamentals. You might really struggle in the beginning to lift off from minimum income if you try to go fast and don't understand what things mean.

- Follow a storyline that teaches you basic fundamentals
- Hire employees from recruitment companies
- Schedule employees according to their requirements and train them up
- Start multiple different businesses (retail & office)
- Buy goods from wholesale stores until import becomes available
- Decorate stores, offices and your home with furniture from IKA [;-)] and other places

Great potential but >>>at this point<<< very shallow and a lot of minor grievances, e.g:

It's great that you can order stuff to your doorstep, but I didn't know that in the beginning and either the game doesn't tell you at all or not in a way that you learn it. Ordering items is also limited to 18 pieces, which makes sense with the pallet layout they arrive on but is arbitrary and hindering when you try to fill a big store. Allow multiple pallets?

Huge stores but no point in filling them. 8 shelves give you the maximum serving capacity in the largest retail buildings, which could fit 80. Why bother wasting the money?

It's a hassle to populate your stores with furniture, as (to my knowledge) you only have your handtruck (which holds 4 items, see also previous points) and placing those items is very tedious from a controls standpoint. You cant just handle the handtruck and place everything that's on it in one go, you have to enter the storage of the handtruck, pick up the item, press place on the item, place the item and then go back to the handtruck. [u] this is probably the one that stopped me from playing further [/u]

Not really a difference in how to run retail businesses regarding the type of sold items. Clothes? Flowers? Food? Sure it's different presenting furniture but that's all (and with food a prep furniture). I was intrigued by "grow any business" but in the end there are 10 or 20ish prefabs that all feel the same.

Sometimes very tedious to click the right thing. Especially in the starting alley where you live, depending on the camera angle I usually click the wrong house first.

Interior design is neccessary for customers but  it doesn't matter how it actually looks, as long as enough decoration items are present. I know "looking nice" is hard to quantify, but if I can just yank 10 plants and 10 rubbish bins in a corner and get to 100%, better not use that feature. Especially since (as previously mentioned) putting stuff in your store is very tedious and unintuitive.

This game is already amazing and it looks like there is still more to be added. I love the gameplay and diversity of it. This game is very well done, its like sims meets a business venture game. I can't wait to see more of this game.

There is no camera tilt. This game begs for one because of its depth. It's the first odd and annoying thing noticed. It gets even worse when driving. Not only is there no tilt like before, but there isn't even a zoom. Try parking with a big tree in your view. Controlling is wonky and just leaves me frustrated. No recommendo at this time.

--Walking is slow and tedious and there's a ton of it. Not extremely easy to find your way back to key locations like your apartment. I would recommend having a "Go to" button or something similar to speed up 
walking. 
--I'd suggest making buying easier. I don't think there's a good reason to have a player walk to a separate store to get shopping carts for their upcoming business. I think The Sims handles purchasing much better. 
--Hard to find what's in the area. Neither the map nor manually exploring the area are intuitive. 
--It is hard to round a corner without unintentionally clicking on random buildings. Even entering a building is kind of challenging. My guy's been reprimanded by his boss for being a minute late to work. Getting fired because the controls are that bad for walking and entering buildings would be a pretty brutal introduction to this game. 
--The game clock should pause whenever the player is in the help menu or in any other menu where they're not playing. 
--It is possible there is some brilliant layer of business management within this game -- I don't know, I didn't get far enough to see it. In my first hour of gameplay, the closest I got to a business decision was whether to buy one set of shopping carts or two. :-/
