I've been playing this game for only a couple of hours, and so far I am really enjoying it. As someone who has always wanted to start up a business, this game is exactly what I've been looking for in a management game.

Would recommend this game to anyone really, but especially those of you with an interest in business and management in general. The game allows you to start a business in anything from a gift shop to an office, and eventually start to take over the whole of Manhattan! (although I haven't got anywhere near that point yet)

Considering this game is only in its infant stage, I am thoroughly excited to see what else is to come!!

The EA of this game reminds me a lot of the Planet Coaster EA: Even as an EA it is a solid, playable game worth every penny you paid for it. If the developers abandoned it tomorrow, you wouldn't be mad. Looking at a really strong roadmap makes me think this game is going to be one of them top tier hidden gem titles. Yes, it is clunky in places.. it is a bit repetitive right now, gameplay can seem somewhat shallow and it was a bit cumbersome to travel everywhere until I found the ability to just call the stores you have a relationship with the manager to place an order for things to be delivered - and it also needs some QoL work - but this is still far better than some games that label themselves as "finished" and should't put you off at all... and you could probably pick it up and play without instruction; or by watching a few YouTubers playing it. The price point of this game doesn't do it any justice; this is worth far more than they are charging for it.. Seriously, if you spent 3 weeks wavering about buying it because you were unsure, take this as your sign that you need to get into this game.

This game is amazing and very unique in the sim field. Played it for more than 5h when I bought it and it is a lot of fun! 
The updates and communication from the devs are really good and hyped to see more!
If you start with story mode you still have lots of freedom when it comes to choices and you aren`t confined just to the story tasks. Before investing in a fast-food like OG uncle Fred asked, I added expensive gifts to my gift shop and it payed of right away! The risk/reward is really good and you always have to keep an eye on the market demand to stay at the top, but also watch out for the competition in the neighbourhood.
Driving is fun and the music as soon as you get in the car is just a vibe ☜(˚▽˚)☞. Except when you get honked for no reason, but hey, you can block the traffic if it annoys you. Tho wish there was more visibility when driving under a bridge.
Look wise it is quite beautiful. The park is nice and tranquil (✿´‿`) and if you want your char happy then better spend some time here! Customisation is quite nice already in this early stage. You can customise your apartment, the work place, your worker`s uniform and plenty of options for car colour too.

TLDR: if you like sims, economy and organising then give this game a try. It is really nice and fun the devs communicate well and have some amazing upcoming updates!

I did really enjoy it, however once I got to the point where I had a single uber successful business (clothing) I was making $20k a day and didn't really need to have any other businesses. I was able to buy a huge apartment, Some nice cars and then I just kept pouring money into more and more businesses which didn't really make that much money but then they didn't really need to. Having lots of businesses meant I needed lots of logistics and staff management which started to get a bit repetitive. Basically, go out, rent a unit, fill it with stuff, fill it with staff, open business, hope it makes money, then if it fails, close it, and open another business. Rinse and repeat.

In short, it's really good, but it needs more late game content.

This is an awesome business management tycoon game. If you're into games about building up a business, you should definitely check this out.

Overall, I really appreciate this game. Those who plays Coffee Inc. I or II, Bitlife or even The Sims for the business aspect will also likely fall in love with this game. In a sense I wish the two could collaborate and make the ultimate game. That said, I've had the game a week and have already clocked close to 80 hours, I'm obsessed! Presently I bounce between the objective driven and sandbox modes of the game. I would like to share first my ideas, followed by my overwhelmingly positive feedback.

Game play improvements Suggestion:

*Presently, I only receive "alerts" under the delivery tab for contracted deliveries from the Wholesale Warehouse. I would like for their to be alerts when entering our own delivery warehouse so we don't have to jump between the two screens to allocate resources. I think it would also be amazing to be able to show our own deliveries under the "Delivery" section where external contracts are presently shown simplifying the process.

*It is unclear to me how effective the marketing campaigns work, so perhaps tweaking this feature.

*Recruitment agencies offer you a selection of up to ten candidates for a store or business at a time. Beyond the specific skill there is little to go from. This leads to a number of candidates who may or may not want full time hours and have varying degrees of need for pre-training. I think it would be beneficial to tweak this feature to fold-in higher prices for more detailed candidates (e.g., $3000 for ten candidates seeking full-time/par-time work with at least 50% skill in cleaning/customer service/HR/Lawyer, etc.).

*Contacts: A city phone book to call taxis and limit the need to run around the world to meet vendors for future orders.

*Warehouse signs/ pallet & storage shelves assignments: Either automatic signs over warehouse stock shelves OR the ability to assign shelves for specific items for easier self distribution. 

*Mouse control: Drive the vehicle with our mouse opposed to keys

*Handcarts: Ability to purchase larger handcarts. (TIP: Travel to IKA to get 8 storage cart and then travel via taxi to locations to carry more stuff in/out OR keep one box on cart in locations to keep the cart from disappearing.) 

*Traffic

Dreams:

*Employees / Board: The ability to hire store / warehouse managers, executive leadership roles: CEO, COO, CMO, CFO, CPO, etc. (Their functions maybe to run the mundane tasks of proper stock and inventory sending requests for increased supplies or notifying if supplies need to be pared down in a dip // oversee the Headquarter operations and make AI suggestions // the board approving motions for sell, market share increase/decrease, fire ELT members, etc.)

*IPO, Acquisition and Mergers: The ability to go public to earn more money quickly and expand operations (struggling companies may be offered for purchase or buy-out other public companies). Purchase controlling interest in companies. Hostile take overs in either direction (AI to player or player to AI).

*Franchise: The ability to allow AI to buy a location or start a shop with our information and logo while we receive benefits (maybe we even supply their store for a profit). Also the ability to buy or open a franchise of our own (e.g., Five Cups, and other heavily advertised and multiple store front locations).

*Player driven multiple store fronts: Presently, if you want to run a large corporation you have to call them "Store 1" "Store 2" and so on to feel like you have the brand throughout the map. Yet, AI corporations have multiple store fronts such as groceries, coffee venues, and offices with the same name for each location. 

*Start ups: Put money into AI store startups or have AI business partner offers to open businesses opposed to only taking out loans. 

*Wealth: Purchase sports teams, donate to schools, more homes (with garages), families to take care of, donate and have buildings/schools named after character, more furniture, more cars, ability to purchase clothing and edit sim character.

*Bankruptcy: File for bankruptcy or have businesses foreclosed when unpaid debt is not settled. 

*Improved simulation: Families and children to pass business/wealth to, plastic surgery, lose/gain weight, ability to change clothes/appearance, ability to place/use e.g., gifts/wine/cigar, etc. that we purchase, more functions such as sitting while eating, working out, bathroom, interacting with pedestrians and employees, etc. Also the ability to buy from our own stores.

*Decor and Objects: More variety and ability to erect/destroy walls. 

*Businesses: Gas stations, distribution/whole sale warehouses, consulting, ride share, furniture store, car garage, dispensary, hospital management, etc.

*Basic politics: Monopoly laws, minimum wage, increased/decreased taxes, ability to support for or against candidate or law with money.

*Lawsuits: Sue a AI company for ripping of logo or brand name (may or may not win), be sued for forming a monopoly or cartel market (forced to shut down stores or re-brand or pay fines). 

Feedback:

If you like management/tycoon games, this is one of the better ones. I really appreciate it doesn't throw arbitrary obsticles/catastrophes in your way, you somehow have to solve. It's one of the things that drive me nuts in certain games, It's pretty straight forward in that regard. Set your business up right and everything will run smooth.

The bad news is, the game gets very repetitive once your business is running like a well oiled machine. All you do at this point is open a new shop, hire workers and set up a supply line. Then just watch the numbers roll in, rinse repeat. 

As far as Early Access goes 60 hours of enjoyable gameplay is pretty good and along with a promising roadmap I can only recommend it.

I never heard much about the previous game, Startup Company, So I wasn't really sure what to expect, probably nothing crazy just a generic Tycoon that burns out after a while. But that's being unfair, this is not a standard tycoon at all, in fact, I'm not sure I have anything to compare it too. This game doesn't pretend to be anything other than itself and it's beautiful. I won't go into a full analysis of every single aspect of the game, someone else has probably already done it better. But I will say, for ~$25 this feels like more than it's money's worth. Sometimes I'm still surprised by the Early Access, since it felt like a full game already. Looking at the road-map and how well the previous game, Startup Company, turned out, I have no reservations. This is THE capitalism simulator (Sorry Recettear), and for a more than reasonable ~$25.

This is a fun little rags to riches game, plays like a tycoon sandbox. You have your run of a miniature NYC where you can buy pretty much any building, run businesses and develop an increasingly complex business empire. The third person nature of the game gives it a bit more character than your typical tycoon game, making it feel like it's 'your' business, not just a business you are running, the fact that you can buy (and upgrade) your own place and car lends itself even more to this feeling, so when your successful you feel successful because you get a nicer place and vehicle. Great game, definitely not the best graphics, but such a great idea that it doesn't even matter.

Honestly speaking, this game deserves more recognition. It taught me how tough it is to start a business and actually win in life. This game probably brought more realism than business classes taught in a average college class. Furthermore, it taught me about supply chain and logistics management, alongside looking at market researches (supply and demands). I usually don't invest my money in games, but this game taught me a lot more about business, life, and making money more than I anticipated. It's a combination of management, open-world, and simulation. Furthermore, the game taught me how important it is to gain connections to people in different businesses because they can save you time with extra-deliveries, and time is money. 
Thanks to the developers for making this game and teaching every player a lesson, you guys rock!
Additional info: Wow, the radio stations in game reflects how devoted you guys are to details of the game. This is truly amazingly addicting and breathtaking game.

My thoughts after 62 hours.
So I did the tutorial story on easy. I made it till I had about 4M net worth. At that point I lost interest.

Started a new play-through on custom. Made the game harder. With all my previous knowledge I have 6 shops in the first district all 30 caps and I'm making 200k a day in about 1/3 the time. Once you understand the basic concepts it is impossible to fail and snowballs rather quickly.

I think my original play-through felt tense to an extent because the tutorial does not have you maximize your first business before opening your second. So it gets messy and those businesses aren't making you maximum profit because nothing is explained as well as the information I got from you guys here in the forums and in disc. (not saying the tutorial is bad). Also, I'd never waste my time on a 15 cap. Is it profitable? Sure is it worth it? Not really.

I feel like other than setting personal goals and chasing achievements I've kinda seen/did all I can for now. 10/10 EA game I can't wait to see what they bring to us next.

I'll continue my current play-though here and there. I'm shooting for having 6 businesses in each district and possibly getting the best apartment and doing the 2M decorating achievement.

This is a pretty fun management sim.  You start from the ground up with a business.  You spend your time either working there or finding employees so you can spend your time picking up supplies in your cheap car.  

I will say this game is still very early access.  Some of the ideas are well fleshed out and I see a lot of potential (hence the yes) but this game dies a quick death once you hit late game.  If your have a bunch of businesses and real estate you end up not really having anything to do but hang out and make money, which is a bit like real life I suppose, but as a game I feel like there's just no reason to play anymore.  There's a lot of potential in this game.  I give it a thumbs up for now because of how engaging the early game is, but it really needs work on mid to late game,

On the 'box', Big Ambitions is sold as a Business Management Sim that varies in scale from running small-time Mom N' Pop-esque shops to managing a billion dollar mega-corporation. And it delivers on that promise in a pretty fun and engaging way, you'll enjoy it if you enjoy sim-style games. And if that's all you want, read no further. But what Big Ambitions ACTUALLY is, is a molten-lava cake of scathing satirical commentary on late-stage capitalism. And I love it. 

Join me, won't you comrade? As we peel back the layers of the simplistic facade and delve deep into the comparisons of modern day America and the criticisms inherent in the game. You'll first be struck by the fact that employees are king in Big Ambitions. Yes, you'll be rising to the top on the backs of your hard working laborers, profiting from their struggle. More on that in just a second. But they actually hold a lot of the power. They set their own rates, based on their skill, and you have to pay it or they simply won't work for you, and if you don't give them the hours they want, they'll just quit, putting you out of pocket to hire their replacement. How are you supposed to get the feel of running an enterprising business in America without the ability to underpay and overwork your employees? Simply unrealistic! But counter to that, they will work, happy as a clam, provided you meet all their demands, until they die. You never have to worry about investing in their training and them up and leaving you for a better gig, they will work for their entry-level pay no matter how skilled you make them, as long as all their needs are met. Imagine that. Happy workers being consistent and loyal? Paying a living wage and still being able to turn a profit? What an absurd flight of fancy this game is!

That right there is the chocolate cake exterior of the molten-lava cake. Warm, crumbly, amusing and comforting. But as you delve past that moist commentary you'll eventually strike the hot, decadent, truly over-the-top, gooey center of this lambaste of the American Dream. 

In the beginning, the game gives you limited (but free, care of a wealthy businessman uncle) resources, and requires you to husband them while eking out a meager profit, all the while tantalizing you with prizes that could eventually be yours, if only you hustle, including fancy cars, palatial condos, and even a Mega Yacht. If you're careful with your free car you can move inventory without incurring undue costs, like logistics laborers and vehicle maintenance costs, but be careful! Those parking tickets are costly! And if you work some shifts in your stores that's salaries and hiring costs you can avoid. There is no need to buy luxuries like a TV when a walk in the park is free and makes you just as happy. 

Eventually you've scrimped and saved enough to really break out. You hire employees because your time is better spent on other things, like establishing your corporate offices, or expanding your budding empire with new business locations. And if you balance everything just right, your efforts pay off big time. You'll find your profits are more than enough to not only sustain new expansion, but also to provide some sought after comforts. A big bullshit truck (after all, it carries more inventory), a big screen TV, maybe just a small yacht. 

But as you shift your focus from hours to days, and from days to weeks, you find your little businessman avatar has less to do, day-to-day. You've set up import agreements and all the logistics to keep your businesses stocked, your employees are happy, your HR managers are doing the training you had to manually manage, all that's left for you to do is ensure the weekly purchase amounts are increased as you wait for enough money to accumulate to either buy out another business to add to your empire, which will come with [strike]firings[/strike] restructuring tasks, or blow it on an opulent display of wealth (what's the most you've ever won in a game of black jack?) What do you do til then? You might find yourself in a loop of waking up, checking your daily earnings, and playing video games or watching TV until it's time to go to bed, not because you need the happiness boost (you have years before that modifier ages off), but because you CAN be your best basement dwelling self, playing games until dawn and sleeping well past noon. Maybe you leave the house to do some grocery shopping, because the game is only early access and they haven't modeled in Door Dash just yet. Maybe you restock the warehouse on paper bags. Not because you have to, you could have set up a purchasing order weeks ago, but because it gives you something to do. Something to use that big bullshit truck for.

That's when you start to notice certain things. You drive a little more recklessly, time is money, after all, and you can afford the repair bills if it means you can bully people out of the way. You don't even shop yourself anymore, you can order everything over the phone and have it delivered. You don't even think about the delivery fees you once thought were extortionately high. Where once a warning about low-stock in your burger joint would send you into a panicked rush to their nearest CostCo to buy a handtruck full of French Fries, now you ignore out of stock warnings for days from the very same store. It's small-time, barely makes you $10k a day. How much was that interior decorating? Oh who cares, I want the wallpaper that looks fanciest. You long ago stopped looking for free parking, who cares about parking fees when you're making hundreds of thousands a day? Hell, you might even park illegally and just eat the ticket, if it offers a modicum of convenience.

Then it hits you, like a steam locomotive riding on rails built by wage-slaves. You see a quote from Final Fantasy Tactics in your minds eye "If the penalty for a crime is a fine, that law only exists for the lower class". But the lower class pays your tickets, they pay your delivery fees, they pay your repair bills, they pay the rent on your 8 penthouses. You're free to do what you want, it's just a matter of how many workers you need to build your tower to extravagance, thus always the end-state of late-stage capitalism.

Once again an absolutely terrific game from Hoovgard Games!The atmosphere in the city is lively and there is a lot to discover. The point and click sometimes takes a little getting used to, but absolutely not a negative point.The variety of companies to create is impressive. Once the game starts, you're immersed in the world and don't even notice how time flies. That's what makes gaming fun.However, a few things fall under the category: suggestions for improvement.Hiring and training cleaners for each business individually is a bit of a hassle in the long run. A central cleaning company would be a useful solution here (either under the company's own control or bought in externally).Removals are not yet possible. If you no longer need a warehouse with the products, you can manually transfer the goods or sell the entire warehouse with contents. Here a move function would be a great idea.One point I still have to address, but here it must be noted that it could also be an isolated case:The concept with deliveries via the department stores, doesn't always work flawlessly. Sometimes the products are not delivered at all, even though the department store is full and the stores' warehouses are empty. (Yes drivers and logistics managers are in place and also the goals are set).Also, the replenishment of the goods in the store itself, is not always carried out by the employees, even if there is enough and correct goods.

There is massive potential here, the game is already great in it's current state especially at the start when you really have to crunch the numbers and struggle a little(on hard mode at least). It does get a little monotonous after some time tho. Once you have set up a few successful business's, there sadly is close to zero thinking left to do. The end game loop could use some work. Here is a peak at it: check what's in demand -> Spam phone calls to the recruitment agencies -> Hire anyone cheap -> Train in mass -> Order required furniture to make the business work -> Call Ika a begillion times to make it look good if that pleases you -> rinse and repeat.

While not necessary a bad game, it just really lacks content to be marketed at $23 IMO. After 8 hours I feel as if I've kinda seen what this game has to offer. Its a pretty basic game loop, get a job, make a little money, run some businesses, sell what people want (which the game tells you), decorate, rinse and repeat. Most the progression is really just buying stuff, not really anything hard earned. Want more customers? Spend money on a marketing campaign. Want happier customers? Spend money on training employees. I understand the game is still in EA, but I also think about other games I've purchased in EA around the same price point. Games like Valheim, Satisfactory, Dinkum I have put 90-110 hours in and probably will put more once they release. I feel like this game should be priced at $10 max, its also a pretty janky experience as well.

I don't always write reviews, but when I do, it's because a game has taken me by surprise; not only that, but so many people would potentially bypass a title like this because they think they wouldn't find it interesting. This game shows great potential and gives you a very hands on approach to handling every day business stuff, which is why I am looking forward to seeing how they fair with the milestones during Early Access. That's not to say it doesn't have any drawbacks, primarily I would say they are personal niggles but I believe many would feel the same: - Time passes too quickly; there is a fine line when scaling time inside a game, but it's difficult to keep up sometimes, especially with how much there is to do. I feel it would benefit from an option to adjust the speed at which time passes to the preference of the player.- There is a in-game help menu, which tells you what goes where, but if you are following the story/tutorial, it seems like the pace isn't consistent and then you end up with businesses you don't necessarily want - inevitably making you want to start again, at which point you then might give up.All that said, it is still early access; there is plenty they claim to have in the pipeline, so it's worth watching - also, it's well priced.

Eventhough its still early access, it already has a really addicting game play loop. The game does still nee some depth though, esepcially in the end game, where the game becomes a "how many stores can I build and scale up in 24 hours". Its a really good game and I cant wait for the next content update.
Fun so far! Looking forward to where it goes

As of right now I can't recommend this game due to a single fatal flaw: This is not a business sim. The game itself is great - in the beginning. Starting up a business, managing it, employing people, furnishing the business, that's all fun. However, the game scales very poorly - when you're a dozen hours in and start earning millions all that employing people, furnishing a business and so forth becomes a huge headache of micro-management. The game does not really supply you the means to scale up these processes and so the methods you was using at the beginning to employ people, furnishing and import goods for your single small local business are the same methods you use to run a huge holdings company with a dozen businesses. Getting 18 items a day delivered to your business and doing a trip to the furniture store for 60 items (the most any truck can hold) is okay when it's your first business and you only need a few things, but once you start buying huge stores that may need hundreds of furniture items it becomes an absolute painful chore.Calling an employment agency to hire a few people is fine when it's a few dozen people. However, once you're hiring hundreds of people having to hire them in batches of ten via a phone becomes mind numbing. Especially when you start receiving text messages from your employees about why they're unhappy and you have dozens of employees sending you complaints. The game really needs a way to automate or, at least, speed up the process of furnishing stores and hiring people, because until then this isn't really a business sim, it's a interior decorate sim and most of your time will not be spent making a fortune, but instead running back and forth to the Ikea and decorating buildings utilising the most tedious tools possible. Just for a concrete example: Suppose I wish decorate my business with exactly 60 clothing racks. To do this I need to get in my truck, go to the appliance store, stock up four racks, buy them, take them to the truck and transfer, go back into the store and repeat. This will take 15 trips in and out the appliance store. Then I need to drive to my business and begin unloading, again, only four at a time and this will take another 15 trips - then I need to place all the items down myself. It doesn't sound like a lot, but it really is and just doing this alone can easily take hours, because you also have to manage your characters hunger and sleep on top of all this. Now suppose I need 50 employees to run this store on all the checkouts for 24hrs (in-game), well, now I need to ring the employment agency and ask for a maximum of ten applicants, so I need to do this 5 times, I wait 24hrs, get the applicants and the need to read them all for specification and accept/deny. Again, this is all fine for your first few business, but now imagine you need to do this 80 times, which, yes, is a mission in the game. So, I'll change the review if they ever address these issues, but for now this is a big thorn in the game that seriously changes it from a business sim to a micromanaging interior decorator sim.

This game has a lot of potential, but it's not really playable right now. The controls are pretty buggy and awkward but my main issue was the lack of explanation on how to accomplish some tasks. The main goals of the game need to be made more clearly on how you can progress in the game. Just telling me to open another business with no explanation on how to purchase buildings made me stop playing. If a new goal is going to be provided, it shouldn't be difficult to figure it out, and sadly with this game, it is. I do not recommend this game at all until it is MUCH more established.

If you like process management games, you'll probably get enjoyment out of this one.  Right now it's limited to purchasing, distribution, and staffing but it's still fun figuring out how much profit can be made in different areas off products.  There seems to be a dead space in the game after you figure out the tricks of setting things up effectively but I still got my money's worth out of it and I'm looking forward to their future plans of incorporating manufacturing chains.  If you like the cosmetic parts - making nice looking stores, offices, and apartments - you'll get even more out of the game than I did.   You can also drive around, but if you don't want to there are taxis, a subway, and most stores allow you to order by phone once you've spoken with someone in person at least once.
Great game, but the driving is driving me nuts xD

it's well made, the UI is very clean, responsive, unconfusing, and everything (aside from driving) can be played with just one hand on the mouse. the radio music in the car is excellent: i had hip hop and bossa nova with actual singers that weren't bad at all. the graphics are very stock asset-y but i don''t mind it. my only gripe with it is the GTA mechanics, because it doesn't add any additional physical flavor to the game other than giving the player the busy work of manually moving your character or vehicles from one point to another. when i was given control of my character, having lived in NYC, i wanted a simulated physically demanding experience of negotiating the streets and vehicles in the city. you can run your vehicle into traffic without repercussion. shlepping around doesn't really tire out your character. at the end of the day, part of the challenge of the zero to hero come up living in this city is its baseline physical demands, and i didn't feel any of that grit. at the very least make vehicle collisions heavily punishable, and make physical exhaustion/sickness a thing. otherwise it's just a very smooth business sim, without much character, where i can do without the pointless manual labor of moving a pawn around the board

Amazingly well developed for an Early Access game! I love this game and haven't been able to stop playing it. It's like the Sims and a Business tycoon game had a baby. You control a character and have to make sure to eat, sleep, and relax in addition to setting up and running your businesses across NY city. You can rent/buy different business venues and apartments that you can design, decorate, and fill up with furniture. I love the variety of businesses you can setup and the freedom this game gives you to work your way up to owning the whole city any way you want. Highly recommended! Can't wait to see what features the developers take on next.

pro tips: never buy a warehouse with only one vehicle bay. 
              only buy large 8,000sq/ft offices for lawyer, web, and your HQ. 
              hire HR managers ASAP and get your people training. slide that bar to 100%. 
              pay attention to logistics, if it lists an item you dont have in the store as a delivery item, you
                  need to start selling that item!
              the market insider is kind of a joke. just open the map and select the business' you want to start
                  in whatever area. start a business that does not have competition. (nearby similar stores)
                  i notice this has been far more profitable strategy than following what the demand says on 
                  market insider.
              never do a donut shop. the price of the food is just not high enough to cover cost of labor, 
                  equipment, etc.. even if you raise to the highest point before pricing& drops. 
              last but not least. allways keep raising your prices every 3-4 days until the % drops in insight. than 
                  lower is .2 at a time until 100% again. this is insure your getting the most money per product for 
                  the area your shop is in.

(these tips are just my opinion of what i found works and does not in my experience. it is also written in the early access period of the game and will most likely change over time. do not expect me to ever change or update this. gl hf, pz!)

I recently played Big Ambitions and was blown away by its unique blend of role-playing and business simulation. The ability to start small and build your empire in any way you like is truly revolutionary. The game's mechanics are intuitive and engaging, making it easy to lose track of time while playing. Overall, Big Ambitions is a must-play for anyone who loves business sims or RPGs. Also, I used ChatGPT to write this review.

This game is very much Early Access.  If you like the idea of the game and want to support and give feedback based on an incomplete product then buy it.  This game is very much in the category currently of "Good idea that needs A LOT of work."

My main complaints are that it is seemingly extremely easy to pull back the veneer of the game and see the inner workings.  Once you've seen the inner workings of the game then it becomes extremely formulaic.  To start a new business you just have to check off these boxes every single time.  You're just stamping out businesses.  The only gameplay after a while is the tedious running back and forth to bring objects 4 at a time into your store to set it up.  You know exactly what you need to do before you even open the store, you do these things in an extremely slow tedious manner.  Then rinse and repeat. 

I think the game needs a lot of balancing on the back end as I think the difficult part of opening a new store should be reading the market, targeting a demographic, and getting customers in your store.  Not the tedious loop of running in and out with your handtruck to physically set the stuff up over and over again. 

I think this has a possibility to be a great game, but currently it's way to easy to "Get" and once you "get" it it's very difficult to find a way to have fun because there is no further challenge.  The biggest positive thing I will say after the success of the Early Access launch the immediate reaction from the development team was "How can we use this money to make our plans for the game bigger and better?"

After 25 hours of game play I am still enjoying Big Ambitions. This game takes a well balanced and user friendly approach to building a business empire in a simulation format. The breadth and relative depth is very impressive and the systems seem to work well. There are no major bugs that I have encountered. Simply put if you enjoy simulation games, business, and building, then you will enjoy this game. The end game just keeps on going and there is always something to optimize or buy.

One of the most addicting games I've played in my entire life. My only complaints are that hiring and scheduling employees becomes tedious and time consuming at a certain point, and the game could use some QOL changes especially to the controls, but overall its an incredibly solid game and it seems to be in good hands.

After making every shop, maximizing them, and doing my research, I will say that the developers need to look at this as a number one priority. Quite some time ago I had a dispute with the creator of this title,  their last game changed direction from what was originally pitched to people who kickstarted it and their was a failing to see eye to eye.

I preface with this so that you know there is no bias in this review, it is about as objective as one can be considering to this day I am still banned from the DIscord.

The usual mantra in this day and age would be to damn the game out of spite or simply find something negative to highlight and feel like i got my own but did it truthfully ...

On the contrary if Startup Company was the prelude to this masterful piece of game design then what happened had to happen.

What you have here is an amazing mix of genres and ideas both new and borrowed to create something truly unique.   So many "life sims" have come and gone in the past few years and none of them delivered anything more than a time management game with lots of clicking ... this is like a business sim done from the POV and  gameplay style of GTA ... you are not a picture in the top left of the screen, you are an ingame character with needs and requirements to sustain your health.

In doing so you can then use your business skills and he tools the world gives you (courtesy of uncle Fred) to start building your first business, and you RUN this business this is a living breathing thing that exists irrespective of whether you are ready for it ... and then you conquer that challenge and you automate by hiring staff and training staff, you spend cash to further enhance the appeal of the premises to customers.

Every shop, is a physical building in the 3D world the player plays in.  You don't use an order form (at first) to get your stock you physically drive to a wholesaler and carry boxes of items you intend to sell to the trunk of your car ... in time you will hire delivery vans, rent a warehouse and automate all this within the simulated world ... hell you will skip the middleman all together and start shipping contracts direct from the suppliers.

The scope and potential for where this little masterpiece can go is measured only by the desire Jonas has to realise it ... honestly this is an Early Access title you don't just buy, but you support because you want to provide the means and feedback and benefit for just how far this rabbit hole can go.   

If you love tycoons and you love management games but you are not impartial to a bit GTA or something similar you would be absolute crazy to not give this a spin given it has a very reasonable pricetag aswell.

Genuinely can't wait to see where this one goes and MAYBE just maybe my whole hearted support might mean I can return to the Discord and bygones be bygones.
love it, runs flawlessly and thinks of everything. looking forward to the future updates of this great game.

Big ambitions is an apt name for this game. This game could well be on its way to a Capitalism Plus tier game if it plays it's cards right, with so much more. It has GTA vibes somehow, sims vibes, it has so many vibes but carves out something that hasn't been seen before. While most games will let you manage one business in this detail, this game lets you manage as many as you want. You can kit out each store how you like it (although, in my opinion this is quite limited in purpose at the moment). The fact you at least initially need to drive around and talk to people and will be doing this the whole time is a very interesting addition to bizsim, sometimes it's just better to take the soda there for today and up the daily delivery. The survival aspect is interesting too, and I think they've made it work really well. Although once I had money coming in I spent an awful lot of time playing video games until enough came in for the next store which seems probably quite realistic if it was a golf course instead ;)

There's a few bugs and only one major bug I encountered so for early access this is a good sign. There is simply so much more that can be added to this framework to make this mind bogglingly good.  At the moment the game is quite easy and would benefit with some real Capitalism style competition trying to beat you out of the markets forcing you to change up your businesses. A nice DLC for resources in a few years is a no brainer. Driving and parking - this was absolutely a masterpiece, so simple but such a part of the game. For me personally, I can't wait for the full release of this and see what other features are coming as this game deserves years more development, all the way into the sun.

I was going to wait to give this a full review until I finished the game but I just got to the insanely grindy late game so I don't think that's going to happen anytime soon because I have a life to live and I don't enjoy setting up stores as much as the game wants me to.

I'm kidding (kind of). I love tycoon sims because I like to watch the stonks go zoom and there's something to be said about the repetition of a satisfying gameplay loop. This game scratches that itch up to a certain point, but setting up stores feels way too clunky especially late game. There needs to be a way to pay more in game to streamline this process. Something like a store editor where you can just take the items from an online marketplace, plop them into a miniature model of the store, and have them automatically ordered and moved in by people that you hire.

Hiring also bogs down the gameplay in later stages, I should be able to filter employees by skill level upon hire, again paying extra. Generally in the late game it feels like I have a ton of money but I can't use it to buy time, which is what you're supposed to be able to do when progressing in a game like this. The game attempts to balance this with real estate purchases but it's not satisfying enough to have me spend hours of my life on the frustrating tedium of setting up stores, which gets exponentially worse the more stores you open. I understand the point of the game is supposed to be the magic of ~doing it yourself~ but that magic quickly wears off. I came here to role play as the bootstrap-theoried, hyper-efficient capitalist existing in the fantasies of yesteryear.

Speaking of, if I'm roleplaying a capitalist, I expect to go all the way with it. Let me store money in offshore bank accounts. If I hit a pedestrian on the street I want to get a lawsuit that I settle out of court. I want to hire a PR agency to deal with the fallout of 30 hit and runs in my Ferrari every year. I want Uncle Fred giving me advice on which sleazy hedge fund is about to commit insider trading so I can cash in too. I want to gather with other rich people in the forest and make sacrifices to Canaanite gods.

I'm kidding (unless...?), just throwing out ideas to give the late game more spice. Now that I think about it, the reason I was hesitant to buy this game in the first place is because this developer's other game, Startup Company, had many of these same issues (though to a much more severe degree).

I still give it a thumbs up, the early and mid game is great, and the roadmap gives me a lot of hope. In the most recent update they announced that because of the game's success, money is no longer a restraint. With that being said I fully expect to be able to bribe city council members for future tax breaks. Happy stonking!

First off, would I recommend this game .... No ... No I would not recommend this game.

If I could sum it up in one sentence, it's as vast as an ocean and as deep as a puddle.

I've played around 30 hours now and the game is finished, I have zero desire for another play through, the game mechanics are kind of rubbish, the game play experience is like that of a mobile game in almost every aspect. I can forgive the unbalanced economy, the small but frustrating bugs, the minimal level of customisation, because this game is early access, I cannot forgive the game playing like something a facebook mum would dedicate her wasted life to playing on an ipad tablet.

The game lacks depth, it isn't fair to compare it to other tycoon games, the complexity just isn't there and I really struggle to believe how the developers will achieve it.

Realism is off the charts here.

As the capitalist chad I am, I can stroll into the bank and ask for a 15k loan and they give it to me on the spot, no questions asked. I'm just like "hey i've got a great business idea. you know my uncle, right?" and they are like "sweet, have some cash, nobody is regulating us anyway lmao. lemme know if you need some more, we've got piles just sitting back there."

So i use my skills as a natural-born *ontrapanure* to use someone else's money to rent a place for my new business. I buy 3 things: a grill, some burgers, and a cash register. That's all a business genius needs to run a successful restaurant. BOOM. Efficiency. That's a minimally viable product, baby.

Oh right, and I almost forgot, I had to hire some unskilled labor too. I hire a 63 year old man, and I call him at 11:05am to let him know I've decided I want to open the restaurant today, and I've just scheduled him for a 12 hour shift that started 5 mins ago, so he better hustle over here or else I'll fire him.

So he walks into an empty room with a cash register and a box of frozen burger patties. I hand him a spatula and tell him good luck while I prance out to spend the rest of my loan money on blackjack and hookers.

I'm paying the dude $13/hr, so I pat myself on the back for being the job creator I am, and then I stroll on over to the bank again to take out another loan and do it all again.

This is one of those "50/50" reviews where I would ordinarily recommend the game, but in this case only if the dev sorts a few glaring issues out. I haven't read through other reviews, but I imagine I am not the only one that wants a certain system to be reworked. Since most people read negative reviews to get a sense of common issues, if the below puts you off until some updates have landed then my review did its job. If you still want to play the game and shoulder through the build system, you will enjoy this game and you will have gotten your monies worth. That said, here comes my nit-picking review on the single negative thing that makes me want to wait 71 days until the update: 

There are a lot of good things in [b] Big Ambitions [/b] but the item placing system is not one of them. In fact, the item placing system is so badly built/unintuitive, it ruins the fun of opening a retail store from scratch once you have done it a few times. It is better to just sleep your way to profits and buy retail stores that are already established, furnished and staffed. 

Allow me to demonstrate the item placing system by using the number of actions required when placing something down (let us assume it is on a hand truck): 

[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The item is selected. 
[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The 'place' button is clicked on/P is pushed on keyboard. 
[i][b]-----[/b][/i]:- The item is [b]not[/b] rotated (to keep number of actions at the minimum). 
[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The item is placed.  

Seems fairly simple, 3 clicks minimum and you have an item placed. But let's assume you want to furnish your retail store with a row of 5 counters for the checkout tills - the clicks required change since you now need to add 1 more:

:: After placing the first counter:

[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The Hand Truck is clicked. 
[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The counter is selected. 
[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The 'place' button is clicked on/P is pushed on keyboard. 
[i][b]-----[/b][/i]:- The item is [b]not[/b] rotated (to keep number of actions at the minimum). 
[i][b]click[/b][/i]:- The item is placed.   

You now have 4 clicks, minimum, per item you want to place if it is more than 1 (which it almost always is). 

Let's use an actual situation you will encounter to show the tedious system at it's best:

I rent a warehouse, I order 18 shelves (the limit per delivery). 

The next day they arrive, and I load them up on the Hand Truck (I am going to skip the clicks required to enter and exit the building and to load up the hand truck - this alone is 5 trips with 6-7 clicks per trip):

First shelf is 3 clicks, each of the 17 remaining is 4 (without rotations), totalling a fun-killing [b]71[/b] minimum actions required to place down 18 shelves in a warehouse (you need more than 18, much more, and more than 1 warehouse). This is excluding the horrible necessity of moving the camera every single time you want to place another item.  

Want to build a large capacity restaurant with 16 tables, 4 chairs per table, 8 storage shelves, 6 checkout tills, 18 counters, 4 hotdog grills, 4 burger grills, 4 pizza ovens, 4 friers, 4 salad bars, 6 drink fridges, a cleaning station, plants, speakers, pictures, tv... Can you see the issue with the item placement system? If you haven't played the game or seen it being played it is understandably hard to imagine why the system is such a pain, but trust me and my 30+ hours, it is a pain. 

Now, if there was a system where we could order furniture, have it delivered and then access it in a building-specific inventory to make multi-selection/placement easier, great! But right now there isn't. Hell, I don't even mind the Hand Truck loading, that bit is actually fun, but individual item selection and placement is not.  

----------------
---------------- 

That said, this is a great game that you should definitely play if you enjoy business-type games with a little life sim thrown in for good measure (you can turn hunger and energy off in custom games), if you can handle the Early Access tag and all that goes with it. 

----------------
---------------- 

Speaking of Early Access: [b]BUGS[/b]:

So far I have only encountered 3, and they are not really game breaking - in fact, they are of so little consequence I will not bother wasting any more of your precious time. Although, if you have read through the stuff above then perhaps you don't really value your time or you just have too much of it. Or, maybe you like to be thorough before purchasing a game... Are you though? If you can sit through my repetitive review, nit-picking a single system (albeit an annoying system), and you are STILL reading, then you are more than capable of dealing with the item placement system and should absolutely get this game. If you're still reading, I would like to thank you for being you, and would like to wish you only the best in life. Still here? Buy the game and **** off already. <3

To start with, I should be clear that I hardly ever write reviews for games. But I had to for this one.

I loved Startup Company, and have been following the development of this game for a long time.

Initial impressions are great, it's an early access game so I'm looking forward to what the future of this game will bring.

Here is my issue with it: The fact you play a single person in the game is at detriment to what the game could be without it, after only a few hours of play, I found myself just stacking up meals, and literally skipping days in order to generate enough income to do the next thing. In my opinion, you should have the ability to play as more than one character, but also, have those characters automatically managed (auto purchase food etc) so that you can skip forward a few days without it feeling so painfully slow.

You should be able to play as the delivery driver,  the programmer etc, or chose for those people to be automatically managed.

I guess I'm sort of asking for Startup Company but at the big ambitions scale...

I'm honestly looking forward to the future for this game, the core game is clearly there, it just needs expanding on.

Wow..
Absolutely incredible game!
You get to be a part of every single parts of an entrepreneur's life! There is a true sense of satifaction starting from nothing, creating businesses, optimising them, creating supply lines, and making them truly autonomous in a large detailed lifelike city! I would say quite realistic too! Gives a great insight into the world of business! 

Obviously this game is is brand new to early access. But that doesn't mean its lacking in content. There's already more here than a lot of newly fully released games. At the moment the game falls off once you get to the point of opening businesses and being able to recruit and buy all staff, furniture and appliances all at once. There are currently limits on how many you can recruit and buy at once. And you still have to micromanage business schedules and bring in new furniture manually.

Once these barriers are broken, the later parts of the game will become a lot more fun.
- I would imagine being able to hire business managers that work with HR managers to deal with staff schedules, would deal with micromanaging schedules.
- Being able to task your delivery drivers to bring new furniture into a building, not just leaving it outside. That would make setting up offices much easier. As well as adding office blueprints / templates. 

I'm so excited for where this game could go, and that's not even including the possibility of modding support! As it stands this is the best business simulator out there. And it can go sooo much further.

A 100% must buy!!
Incredible game, with incredible devs. Roadmap is clear, and the potential is there to be one of the GOATs

Zero challenge and depth. You'll start a business, hire workers, drive around the city, after a while you start another business, hire workers and drive around the city. Impossible to fail, the game is really easy. 

The driving around part is well made, and the map looks nice.
 
But I like deep business sims that offer challenge to the point that you can even go bankrupt. Gear City and Mad Games Tycoon 2 are good examples of challenging and really deep business sims. 


The game is missing concepts like brands & brand popularity, competition, customer loyalty, rivalry, negative events (now sometimes a worker gets sick but really it doesn't matter), worker relations, overtime extra, etc. There even could be a health bar, so crashing full speed could put you into a hospital for a while. 

You can abuse the system easily. For example, you can have a single part time worker clean your 24/7 business every 7 hours to keep the cleanliness at 100%.  In reality no one would do that, because it would mean less than 6 hour continuous sleep. 


I hope the devs will work to add some challenge in the game.

Few Thoughts and wishes after  15+ hours in.

Customisation is very bland from custom character to Employee outfits. (Please add separate work outfits from main character in later updates)

Intense Frame drops at Night time. i go from 144FPS (Locked) during the day to 40-60 FPS at night.

Please add in a Blue Print System/Online Delivery system later in the game story. When you reach a point where you can open up numerous Businesses it becomes so tedious driving to one store grabbing 4 items loading it up over and over again, drive across the map and then unloading it over and over again per new business. There has to be a better system in play, because this system right now is driving me up the walls. 

I've noticed my Employee section getting insanely long. Please categorise all the employees a job tab their working at so i can manage them a bit easier.

It's nearly impossible to park the Semi on the road let alone find a space to park it near your business. Roads need to be slightly bigger as well a slight reduction on parked cars near businesses.

There's just not enough Businesses to open. Let alone shortly my businesses are going to be competing at each other. I'd love to see some huge Expansions to businesses as well. Possibly opening up various Game studios, Developing games and owning MMO's that generate income overtime or stepping into the Industrial side of things. i'd love all the businesses to expand in that sense. give us some more playing room and things to do within each business.

Please incorporate a Business Chain system where i can open up the same Business across New York. Got a few coffee shops with the same name with numbers in front of them. Would be cool to link them altogether for warehouse drop offs.

After another 15 hours ill edit this again, but I can't wait to see where this game goes. So Far it's a 6/10 in my books and i imagine it will expand beyond that after a few good updates. Thank you for creating this Game!

Game is good and I enjoy it. There are definitely some irritating things about everything that I would really like to have in the game. One of them being the fact that I should be able to sell items that I bought for my store. At the moment, as far as I know, if I buy a $10,000 fryer for my fast food restaurant, and if I decide that I do not want that restaurant anymore and I want to close it down, I cannot sell that fryer for any amount back. The only thing I can do it discard it and just completely waste that 10 grand. Another thing is that I should be able to sell my businesses. Valuation of each individual business should be input into the game so if I ever do not want a certain business anymore, I can just sell it for the valuated amount based on the income of it instead of just "shutting the business down" with no compensation. 

Little things like that get to me and at points prevent me from enjoying the game. For now I'm putting it down until these things are looked at and fixed.

The first real competitor to The Sims in history. It's a life sim, business management sim, sandbox game where you start by working in a supermarket, open your own store and eventually develop an entire empire so that you can live your life of luxury.

It's not quite as goofy as The Sims, which I liked, and it also has mostly any form of meaningless but fun recreation that The Sims do. The economy (prices and wages) are much more realistic and you will quickly find yourself micromanaging your employees and evading taxes with strategic stock investments, all just for another night on that casino boat.

This game convinced me to finally take an interest in stocks and potentially funding businesses. Recommended if you want to have fun and be inspired to live better.

You've never played anything like Big Ambitions. This business tycoon/life simulator keeps you thinking as you plan out your next business to open, hire new staff, improve your warehouse logistics, and figure out ways to grow your profits and your empire. A sprawling, detailed, and lively New York-inspired city makes each day feel unique as you race through city traffic (or commute via subway) to travel between grocery stores to stock your fridge, furniture stores to decorate your apartments and shops, wholesalers to restock your business inventories, car dealerships to expand on your delivery vehicle fleet or treat yourself to a shiny new ride, offices that house your headquarters, and more locations. 

Even in early access, there's plenty here to keep you hooked, planning, and hungry for more!

It's a fun sim game with plenty of content already. In the beginning you open a small shop and manually stock it by driving around, carrying each individual box painstakingly to its destination. You then progress, hire employees, set up automatic deliveries to buying your own warehouses with your own trucks and drivers and automatic deliveries. The progression is quite nice. 

There isn't much late game, once you have a few shops that are profitable money just rolls in automatically without having to do anything. And you can spend it on yet more stores, but to what end? The employee system is very barebones, each one is only a slider with no personality. Cashiers will stand behind the counter and that's it. You don't see cleaners, they are just passive attribute. You have part time workers and full time workers but it only has an impact once you have multiple stores, as early game a part timer will easily and willingly work 70+ hour weeks if you just change their schedule every now and then. 

The stores themselves don't take layout into account, so whether you lay out your restaurant efficiently with short ways for the employee, or rather dump everything down brainlessly makes no difference. In fact, being present in any of your stores will drastically reduce your store income due to how customers are spawned and counted. 

Overall, it's fun but also has a good amount of shortcomings that I hope will get addressed during this Early Access phase.

[h1]The whole picture of the sad state of modern "tycoon" genre[/h1]

[i]Big Ambitions[/i], upon first look, seems to reach out and touch the empty place that demise of 90's business management games, such as Pizza Tycoon or Transport Tycoon left in modern gaming landscape.

You have a whole city, you have properties to rent or buy, you can start a business, you can set up a logistics chain to supply the business, so forth. Sounds epic, right?

But it's 2023. Developers have no effin' idea what they're doing. Modern Business management games think that business is about sweeping floors, picking out wallpapers and moving furniture (also see: Gas Station Simulator, Chef, etc), instead of min-maxing expenses and revenue and living a story. Such is the sad case here, as well. The focus and effort went everywhere, but none of it into actually simulating a business.

Thus, you end up running around the city with a handcart, trying to commute and maneuver godawful traffic model in super narrow streets -- where everything, from other cars to simple trash cans -- each weigh as much as a freight ship and thus, stop you car instantly. You keep sleeping on benches, while looking at a clock, because opening and closing time of supply stores was [i]for some unknown, never gave-a-thought-about-it, player-unfriendly reason[/i] fully simulated.... basically 99% of the time you do everything than manage business. Big Ambitions works better as a super annoying parallel parking simulator than an actual business simulator. 

Once again, it's just insane, non-excusable waste of time. The city didn't need free roaming at all. Yes, it's nice to be able to walk around, but it's [b]not what the game should be about[/b]. What should have been just a cool feature, turns out to be absolute majority of the actual game loop.

The actual "business simulator" is so bare-bones, pathetic and boring as anything can be: you buy a shelf, and some other pieces of furniture (via painful and dumb logistics task), fill them, get an employee and wait. That's it. That's all. Until stock runs dry, so you get to exercise frustration in navigating the city again. And yes, you can do some of those things via phone, some sort of shortcuts exist, but they feel like a band-aid on what was terrible game design decision to begin with.

Sure, "it's Early Access," you say. "Things will come." 

Looking at a roadmap, I don't see "turning the game an actual business simulator with actually simulated customers, market changes, variety of product types, accounting and such" anywhere. Just more cosmetics. Electric scooters, whoo! That's what's missing, right?

Not the workers getting sick or stealing, not the rivals and opponents, not the actual simulation of customers (which modern computers can now do) so you'd really fight for each and every one, not any of the things that would actually make a business management interesting.

Why. Just why? What a waste of effort.

But "wait" you say. "One shouldn't review a game based on what it's not or one wished it would be".

Okay, but what's Big Ambitions then, at current stage?

A crappy GTA clone with fetch quests and a bit of random The Sims business expansion pack peppered in. Sad.
king of retail meets grand theft auto meets my summer car meets

It's a fun game. I do with there was something to protect from save scumming at the casino cruise however. It's too easy to turn 10k into 2 mil in just a few bets. Best way I could think to fix that, would be a maximum bet of your largest daily income. It would still be too easy to save scum, but you wouldn't ruin the grind. and honestly, the grind itself is a big part of the game.

That said, It scratches the itch, which is a BIG point in its favor. I had an itch for a business management game, and this game handed me that on a gold encrusted platter.

WOW!

I am genuinely blown away by Big Ambitions, having played previous games like Startup Company by the same team, I knew roughly what I was getting into and what to expect but I am amazed by the level of depth from such a small team.

The level of depth and intricacy for each business type as well as the delivery & import setup is great and adds multiple levels of micro management while giving the option to add more autonomy as you become successful.

I'm very conscious the game is still in beta and only just released to the public so I'm reluctant to criticise but there are some thoughts or ideas I'd like to share:

Hotkeys/Shortcuts for the UI - It's not a big deal but it'd just make the game feel smoother and a little less clunky if I could have a shortcut for phone contacts or BizMan for example.

Favourite orders - Let me 'save' an order for repeat purchasing, for example every time I want to add an employee I have to add a desk, PC and chair separately which can get tedious after 100-200 employees! Let me save my order of 1 x desk 1 x chair 1 x computer and quickly reorder it as/when needed.

I am only approx. 15 hours into the game at the moment but feel like I'm progressing well, I don't want to say too much more on the game until I've seen 'end-game' but I am overwhelmingly impressed so far. Keep up the great work.

I really enjoy this game. I love being able to go around town and recreate the life of a small business owner, because that's really what you're doing. You are a sole proprietor, creating a shop with a tiny amount of cash and a dream, while keeping yourself fed and relatively happy. If your boss is ever upset with you, that might be why. However, I think that the game desperately needs modding support, and that should be a much higher priority on the development roadmap. Without it, the game will never feel fully fleshed out, because you can tell that it is in beta. Also, I hope that the devs will refrain from adding new cities to the game, because that just sounds like a time sink. Maybe they could new neighbourhoods to NYC, instead. 

Modding will unlock the game's true potential. It is essential and should be priority no. 1.

You had better have some real ambition to make it in this eco sim.
This game has a pretty long period of being a low level store manager style game which isn't that fun but as soon as you get a logistics train setup for you business empire it immediately switches to more high level management which is way more fun.
All the while still having the interesting feature of having to control a character who is managing the whole thing, daylight hours are precious, early on you would scoff at paying $250 to deliver furniture to one of your properties, instead driving it yourself, but no real CEO has time to be a delivery boy. Similarly if one of your employees calls in sick early on you'd just cover the shift, like any small business owner, but a true executive has HR managers to hire temp workers for that, you're busy talking to the bank to get another loan or setting up your next burger joint.

One major criticism  is driving around the city, following traffic laws just doesn't work given the time constraints of the gameplay loop, but the AI vehicles are very erratic in their driving and every bump and scrape on your vehicle is money and time going down the drain while you get it fixed.

Several features are unavailable or don't work (read dev blogs) but its EA and they will (hopefully) be implemented at a later date.

Another case where I wish there was an option other than Yes or No.

There is the germ of a truly outstanding game here, and I definitely enjoyed my time with it. So, on that basis, yes, I recommend it.

However, if you're here for a classic Tycoon game, I'm afraid you'll be disappointed, a few hours of scratching the surface will reveal that there is very little underneath, it lacks dynamism and simulation in most aspects and the longevity suffers as a result.

It is possible to set up a successful business and never have to touch it again, while watching the money roll in. As a critique of capitalism, it works really well, as once you get beyond a certain size there is nothing to do but waste your money on trinkets and status symbols.

Some fundamentals of retail simulation are missing:
There is no modelling of staff needs - while the player needs food, rest, and happiness, staff are automata, and a full-time staff member will work 50 solid hours in a row without complaint.

While staff have a preference for how many weekly hours they are scheduled, this only serves to turn scheduling into a sliding box puzzle, and as the game doesn't keep track of how many hours someone has worked in a given period, you can shuffle the board to keep them happy without penalty.

Once you've set up a schedule that works, no matter how unrealistic, it stays working.
And no, having random absences doesn't address this.

There is no simulation of customer behavior, the maximum number of customers per hour is the result of a formula, and this formula does a poor job of modelling the realities of the store.

This can be demonstrated by comparing the number of customers per hour your business serves when you're in the store with when you're not.

The game doesn't keep track of how many customers are in the store, nor how long an order takes to fulfill, and if you walk in and out of the store all your customers for that hour will disappear and take their revenue for that hour with them.

Finally, competitors appear to be static. Rival businesses will open and close, but this seems like randomness for randomness' sake, to alter demand for products, rather than as a reaction to anything the player has done.

Their businesses don't appear to have their own revenue, staffing, or stock requirements. Maybe they are modeled under the hood, but given how few of the game's mechanics are systems-driven, I doubt it.

Thankfully, it's just launched in Early Access so there's plenty of time to improve it, and the road-map addresses a few (but not all) of the issues I have.
The developer seems really open to suggestions and keen to make it the best they can, and I truly hope they succeed.

Considering how polished and good this game plays so early into Early Access, I can't wait to see what the future holds. My only complaints about it are small QoL things, the core essence of the game is great
- Change delivery schedules (once, every 3 days, every week) to a day slider 
- Driving mechanics are maybe too fleshed out to be fun (legally parking, getting gas for, and repairing my car is realistic, but not fun)
- Like above, item carry limit (for both character and car) becomes tedious when you need to transport things en masse. Making several trips to the furniture store to future-proof a HQ isn't fun, nor is spending 10 minutes stocking up on food over many trips
- The whole furniture buying experience could (and imo should) be done away with and absorbed into the "Interior Designer" tab. Add the chairs, desks, etc into that tab and add a delivery fee. Appliances should remain in-person purchase only though

These complaints may seem scathing but again, I'm loving this game. Don't be offput by the Early Access label, this game is gonna go the distance
