I recently started playing 'Big Ambitions' and I have to say, I'm hooked! The game provides a great simulation of what it's like to start from scratch and build a successful business empire in New York City. The game is complex but easy to get into, and there's a lot of freedom in how you approach building your businesses.

I love how the game allows you to start small and gradually work your way up to owning multiple businesses, including supermarkets, law firms, coffee shops, and more. The real estate investment aspect of the game is also a nice touch, and it's satisfying to watch your empire grow as you buy more buildings and expand your operations.

One thing I would like to see in the game is the ability to own and manage hotels. It would add a new dimension to the game and provide more opportunities for players to diversify their businesses. It would also be great to have the option to own a car dealership, as well as more customization options for signs and homes.

Additionally, I think it would be cool if there were more things to do at the owned apartment, such as inviting guests over for social events or throwing parties.

 Overall, I'm really enjoying this game and I think it has a lot of potential for even more immersive gameplay with some of these new ideas. I highly recommend that everyone give 'Big Ambitions' a try, as I believe it's awesome new experience and  its only going to get better. They are still in early access!

Solid early access foundation here, but definitely feels like early access, looking forward to more expansions and improvements over time! :) You should confirm how the current cons are doing if this review is more than a month or so old when you see it, as I expect there's new progress coming in the future.

Overall an amazing base for future development and I think even if the core systems aren't drastically improved and made more obvious/intuitive to the user, (I expect they will be in many areas however) even just expanding what's already here would be a good value proposition for the game. Already happy I invested in its future development, and I'm probably still reasonably early on in the game, with more concepts to be introduced.

The pros:
* Excellent scheduling system for management of opening hours & designing employee shifts
* You can customize uniforms and logos for each business, and there's already a reasonable bare bones level of logos and clothes types available
* Managing employee needs already has bonuses and penalties, and can cause employees to quit. This feels like it might be reasonably expanded further in the future, too.
* Logistic support integrated, or early on you can drive supplies around, and this mostly feels like an engaging part of the simulation.
* Many systems are immersed in the game world through actual businesses, so while you have a lot of control you could conceivably exercise through your phone available in menus, you still have to physically visit areas to set up relationships with other businesses, make orders, etc, which makes it feel very grounded in the world and enhances a sense of place- the game very clearly IS New York, it's not just hypothetically set there.
* The licensed soundtrack is already really good and feeds into the sense of place, it has track fast forward, and it actually plays through speakers you place down or your car radio, excellent use of gameplay mechanics. Could possibly do with pause and track rewind/fast forward too at some stage, but it's already really good as-is.
* All tasks involving waiting can be fast-forwarded or time-warped through, whether it's working a shift, playing games in your game, getting a proper sleep ingame, or snoozing on a bench while you wait for a store to open.

Mixed/improves with gameplay:
* The car driving system feels very clunky at first, but this is mostly because more expensive cars are more responsive. This is a good reward for succeeding in business so should stay, but it would be good if there was some minor auto-assist on keeping straight in a lane to stop you from constantly having to fine adjust, and if there were audio cues on traffic lights, as driving and walking are big parts of the game. There's a trade-off between sticking with the very cheap vehicle while you learn how to drive and upgrading to a very expensive one where you'll find it easier to avoid bumps and crashes. I absolutely recommend trying a middle-range car before dunking on the driving controls.
* The sense of integration of place makes you feel like you're in a top-down driving simulator sometimes, but this may ease as apparently there are dev plans to add a chauffeur mode? (You can also flag a taxi if you don't need to pick up large amounts of goods at your destination and just need to talk to someone on the other side of the city, which fast-forwards the driving)
* Some mechanics feel very story mode only, like taking courses in business school. I'd like to see that actually do things that affect your character in game in the future.
* Service businesses (offices) don't offer anything to the player at the moment. It would be cool and enhance that integration of sense of place if you could self-market to a degree with web design, that you might want lawyers for negotiating contracts and dealing with your competitors attemts to undermine your business, dealing with HR disputes, etc...
* A lot of places are parked out at various times making it very hard not to damage your vehicle, which is good as it means you can't always expect to park right outside your destination and may need to weigh up large volume of purchases against ferrying items to your car by hand truck, but it would be nice if there was a bit more scope for coming back later if you want to park a particular car in a particular place. Often once a car is parked in an area it stays for the whole day. Very commercial areas should empty out late at night, and residentials ones during work hours. It would also be good if some rental or purchased apartments came with a reserved park.
* Some of the mechanics are not yet well tutorialized, such as walking in the park, so this needs further work. (which also in reality is also more like "sleeping on park benches to get happy," haha! I'd like to see the counter actually increment faster if you walk rather than sleep so that there's more of a tension between energy and happiness, rather than going to a park bench for both)

The cons:
* The UI is a huge mixed bag. Some elements are great, others are hidden in particular businesses' menus and extremely unintuive to access even if they work well while you're there, hopefully more things get top level menus in the future.
* Banks are completely separate and don't impact on each other- would like to see a greater loan cap at any one bank, but that they take into account your loans with other banks before agreeing. Right now each bank can give you $40k if you qualify.
* Full time and part time employees are strict desires and you can't advertise your expectations of a full-time or part-time role when making a vacancy available at all, you just get randomly surprised with them. This should happen to a degree but it's too far out of your control at the moment.
* The happiness mechanic doesn't seem fully implemented yet, as there's no way to max it out day-to-day, only by hitting side-goals and story goals simultaneously. It feels like there's one more method to increase happiness still under development or in the to-do list.
* It can be hard to see where you need to clean when doing it manually, it'd be great if we could have an overlay that made it a bit more obvious where the dirt is after picking up a mop.
* Loans feel way too powerful and should probably be more of a double-edged sword, at least in the early game.
* Products and businesses currently feel very bare bones and samey after you set up your unique equipment for each business, so will likely benefit hugely from further development and small mechanical differences being implemented for more businesses. This may also be because a lot of the actual variation that's there is too subtle and not obvious to the player- for instance some businesses are much more impacted by employee skills like customer service, but unlike with not employing enough sales staff or not supplying enough interior items, customers won't yet complain that the staff member wasn't skilled enough as far as I can see, hopefully this is in a future patch.

I bought this game expecting an Early Access Game. The game feels finished. Of course it could use with more stuff, which I'll list below the ones I'd like to see in the near future:

-More businesses types, 
-More models for cars and characters, 
-Nicer furnitures should give a bonus to happiness (that way we would need to decorate our apartment not just for cosmetics - and this should be true for businesses as well, especially offices!),
-Interactions with NPCs - New York feels empty and shallow, people only appear in stores when you go in, if you leave and go back in, it will be empty again. 
-More places to visit and spend money, like Dance Clubs, Country Clubs, and if we are able to interact with NPCs, maybe add a few unique NPCs which we can befriend/romance, and a few rivals as well,
-And if we do get more stuff to do on our free time, we need a slower timescale. Sure, the timescale is fine right now, but once we get more things to do, it's going to be a struggle to do everything we want in a day.

And even with all those 'flaws' and suggestions... The games already feels good to play, it's hard to stop, I'm always like "Just one more day so I can do this last thing". I've played 10h on the same savegame, and I feel like I'm so far away from owning a big yacht (which are in the game by the way, though I don't know how they function, since I'm too poor lmao). And I mean it, a yacht costs millions of dollars, and I'm making like 13k a day (and spending a lot restocking my warehouse).

If you like tycoon games, you'll definitely love this, especially if you also enjoy life sims. Granted, you only need to eat and sleep, and like I said, there's no interactions with NPCs, except with store clerks, but the tycoon part of the game, managing your businesses and making sure your warehouse is always filled with enough products to deliver to your stores is pretty damn fun.

I'll leave their roadmap here: https://www.bigambitionsgame.com/roadmap

This game is highly additive, fun and challenging as you grow your business empire from humble beginnings. You start out as a 18 year old who has a helpful uncle who will guide you in your journey. You start out as a humble gift shop owner were you are doing all the work required to get your struggling business off the ground.  As you continue in the game and expand the number of businesses you create companies that will manage your business as you expand looking for other businesses to setup. 
Considering how inexpensive this game is it truly is remarkable.

Don't forget that this is EA game and there will be some bugs.

Did not get any crash, that's a big plus for EA game. Storymode was nice, but started hard custom game afterwards. Much harder than storymode, but when playing with head it is worth it.

At some points you want to skip for few days and content still lacks some features, like, when placing object in shop or caffe, it would be nice to be able to choose color etc. But I really hope that they will come and there will be more variety of content and actions to do, when you have settled business and wait to get autoordering of goods in place.

I really would like to configure some triggers, like in caffe there is less than x donuts or something like that, that would allow me not to micromanage things even when purchase agents and logistics managers are getting autoorders. HR schedule autofill does not work. it does not take into account things like peak hours etc, which would be nice if, let's say 80+ experience HR would do better than HR with less experience. for now it is just mathematical calculations and in most cases sundays are without workforce :)

But yes recommend and now it is a waiting game for next patches :)

The possibilities are endless in the world of business!

The concept of the game is very interesting, but it still has a very long way to go. As is normal for an early access game, there are a lot of crashes (played 2.5 hours and got 13 crashes). But there is definitely potential and you should keep an eye on the game.

This game is a pretty unique business sim. You drive a pretty good selection of vehicles in a open world setting very GTA like. It'll remind you of The Sims 4 expansions where you can rent or purchase buildings with more of a focus on the businesses and less on personal needs, although there's some of that too. The game is based on real life NYC, Manhattan specifically, but smaller in scale. Yet the map is big enough to get that big city feel.  I wish there was some building customization, or a way to build from an empty lot, but there's is plenty of ways to personalize every space, from the apartment you live it, the office spaces you have you operation staff working at, warehouses you ship goods to your stores from, and said stores and restaurants you make point of sales.  You hire and fire your staff and you can run many businesses at once, from store to even law firms.  The game is still early but there's so much to do.  You can't beat it for the price if you love sim games and its open world on top!

Embrace the sigma grindset. Below is my initial impressions in the first 2 hours:

Big Ambitions expertly fuses the engrossing gameplay of Grand Theft Auto, minus the crime, with the streamlined life management reminiscent of The Sims series. The game's business mechanics closely mirror my most favourite expansion pack to The Sims, Open for Business. Set in a faithfully recreated New York, Big Ambitions offers enthralling day-to-day challenges for fans of business simulation games.

There's immense promise here, but there are areas that could use improvement based on my initial gameplay experience. The addition of WASD movement support for character navigation would greatly enhance playability. While the focus on running a business is engaging, the game could benefit from more diverse activities to fully utilize its beautiful rendition of New York. Expanding the options for exploration and leisure, allowing players to become virtual tourists, would truly elevate the experience.

This is the absolute best sim/management/tycoon game in existance. With some of the best devs in all of simulation games, this game is sims on crack already, let alone if they have more money to work on the game. Just buy it, I promise you will get way more than your moneys worth.

Freaking awesome jobs, very thorough, with a GREAT tutorial, might need a little more explanation for employees and delivery drivers but all in all-- I'll be stuck on this one a while. .. I can't wait to see what's next (I'm FINALLY about to go to the casino-- wish me luck at the tables!!) <3

They say... "Big Ambitions is a revolutionary role-playing business sim. Go from nothing to the biggest entrepreneur in New York by opening small businesses or slowly building huge corporations any way you like." I say... This game is really entertaining and addictive! As a business building sim, you get a lot of management tools and AI workers to help you start and build up your businesses.

My NGR (New Game Release) (after playing over 20 hours), review is during early access at 2023 03 17 (build 1714), and I think things can only get better from here on in. The game has already surpassed my expectations with its complex and in-depth gameplay. You have a lot of control over your businesses and can make strategic decisions to maximize your profits and grow your empire.

The game has a beautiful cartoon-esk cityscape that creates a sense of immersion and charm. The soundtrack is also fantastic, providing a calming and atmospheric backdrop to the gameplay. Additionally, the music is specially written for the game and is DMCA (Digital Millennium Copyright Act) free of copyright, so Youtubers and streamers can leave the in-game radio music on if they wish! Double-check this before you use the music though!

One of the things I really like about 'Big Ambitions' is the small variety of business types already available, and I'm sure there will be more to come. You can upgrade your buildings, hire more workers, and expand your reach into new territories. The possibilities are endless, it's fun to do some experimentation and creative problem-solving in the game.

Overall, 'Big Ambitions' is an excellent game that's well worth your time and money. Whether you're a fan of business sims or just looking for a fun and engaging game to play, this one definitely delivers. I can't wait to see what the developers have in store for future updates!

At NGR I’m not trying to cover all the New Game Releases for every new game released, just the ones I like to play. If you get to know me and trust my opinions, I’m sure you’ll love to hear what I have to say about the next game you are thinking of buying, when you’re reading the review of it below the game. I only review a game if I like it, so it's mostly going to be a positive review, and only after I’ve played either the whole prologue or demo or sunk at least 10 hours into the game.  NGR.

My favorite aspects of the game:
- You can rent an apartment
- You can own AND DRIVE all types of cars!!!
- Driving is tedious but fun! and you want to drive safely as your car has a health bar that lowers when you crash into things, but it gets you places faster, lets you load up more supplies and furniture, and you can buy really nice ones. You have to be careful where, and how, you park because there are legal and illegal ways
- You can pick out your business building
- You have to go to different stores to buy products and furniture for each specific business. My favorite part about this is you have to go into the store, pick out what you want and go up to the cashier to buy it
- You can name your business, design your logo, design our sign, and set your prices
- Hiring employees and scheduling them is detailed and strategic
- You can design the interior of your business and apartment
- You have to clean your business (you can hire employees for this)

I'm just getting into the game so far, I've only put 4 hours into it but it's highly addictive. The gameplay loop is satisfying and I appreciate all the details. I really hope more content is added in the future, especially different furniture customizations, decor, and wall and floor designs.

[h1]Good game, kinda janky but tons of potential[/h1]

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+ A lot of realistic things are simulated very well in this. Notably, warehouse management and minimum orders are very life-like, though some would say that's an inconvenience. Customer service at retail vs F&B places is also realistically different in efficiency, which is a nice touch.

+ Performance is decent, I won't say it's amazing, cause I had to turn settings down a little on my 3070 and i7 2.3GHz, but it runs just fine.

+ Content is at a good level, for early access. Most early access titles suck at delivering enough content so by simply being decent, it gets my seal of approval.

+ Overall you got a lot of tools to play around with. Automation of supply chain, customizing of homes and business interiors, vehicles, even custom games with preferred settings.

+ Gameplay loop isn't boring, unless you're a sweaty gamer and are just trying to earn fat stacks by day 100.

+ You can pretty much buy any building or business in the map currently with the exception of the IRS. If you're a completionist like me and wanna take over every business and property, this is great news.

+ Tutorial is good, and is played out like your hip uncle helping you get on your feet. Also good voice acting there, which is a nice bonus.

+ Things about the world change as you operate. Putting up billboard ads for a business actually shows your business logo on billboards across the city.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
- The game map is a little small right now. When they state "New York", it's really only like half of Manhattan at best.

- Balance in this game is kinda wack. F&B gets dunked on by every other type of business, and there seems to be no way around this due to how sales work in this game. Inversely, you could say that clothing stores and law firms are ridiculously efficient, seemingly being unrealistically so.

- Driving makes me want to eat drywall and acquire extra chromosomes. It is just so poorly implemented. Cars handle like crap with no smooth turning, and your camera is locked facing forward even though you don't use your mouse to do anything while in a vehicle. You gotta constantly tap left and right in order to go straight due to how jerky the turns are. Last but not least, PARKING. Attempting to parallel park on a busy road is the primary reason why I bring my vehicle for repairs once a week. The veterans out there will say "buy a car with auto-park", but auto-park literally doesn't register a parking spot as valid if it is TOO BIG. Auto-park only allows you to park squeezing between two cars that you'd not be able to realistically parallel park between.

- AI drivers in this game are programmed to destroy your vehicle with killing intent. They do not give you any room to manoeuvre, and constantly inch forward until they are like half a meter behind you. Why is this a problem? Because if you get stuck, or are in the middle of parallel parking, they're gonna box you in, up till the point where you got no choice left but to trade paint with them. They also have no idea how to move around obstructions, or even reverse. I tested this by blocking every lane of a major highway with a line of pushcarts and yep. I created a traffic jam that went on for like 5 city blocks.

- Highways do not disappear when you drive under them. Which means you have a 50-50 chance of crashing your car everytime you pass under one.

- You have the option to travel on foot with WASD, but it treats it like you're using a controller, rather than a keyboard, so it begins highlighting everything as you walk past it. It got so annoying that I went back to point-and-click movement. So basically, you cannot move using WASD, end of story. 

- I honestly don't know why they even give you an option to walk, but it creates a bug where after I finish working a shift, I'm walking again and have to reset my default run speed.

- A lot of mechanics are very esoteric and have little to no explanations given in the F1 menu. Things like minimum order are not explained clearly at all, and it took me like 30 minutes of creating and cancelling orders to figure out why it wasn't working.

[h1]Suggestions[/h1]
- There's not much for you to do on foot. I know it's a big part of the game, that you have to go do stuff yourself but it's all just chores and other insignificant tasks. I'd rather it just be removed from the game and we play it like a city builder instead with no player character instead. Managing things like hunger and happiness feel kinda boring and very few players would actually bother with those mechanics, since there is no incentive to stay at 100% happiness. All you do is stay above 0%.

- You can only have 18 packages delivered to your building at any one time, including from multiple stores. This makes no sense, since there's tons of pavement. Why can't we just fit more pallets? There's hardly any pedestrians using the roads anyway.

- There is currently no way to change Foot Traffic on properties. I feel like there should be a way to do so, especially since hotspots change all the time depending on what's going on in the area. The inability to affect foot traffic is like 50% of the reason why F&B sucks in this game, and every other business type dominates it.

- We need more business types in the game. There's not enough business types right now, to the point where if your goal is to take over every business and property in the map, you'll have like 5-6 of your own businesses competing with one another in every district.

- Investments grow too slowly. Honestly, it's so slow it barely even feels worth putting any money in. I'm currently trying to grow $50m which in real life would be a massive investment, and I'm doing it on the highest volatility plan. In the 120 days since I first invested, it has moved 0.02%. And that's not going up and down, it's been going up steadily the whole time, day by day. Pitiful.

- There is no taxi company, so you can't call a cab. While you can find cabs everywhere in the Garment District, there are like 0 taxis in the Midtown area, so you're kinda stuck. Give us a taxi company.

- There should be more options when putting out recruitment campaigns. If I don't want anybody with miscellaneous requirements like "No evening shifts" or "Clean work environment", or I just don't want part-timers, I should be allowed to specify that. After all, people already do this in real life.

- There needs to be more specialty buildings spread out across town. I want to move to a nicer apartment, but refuse to because the starting apartment in the Garment District is the closest to the Gas Station, Ika Bohang (IKEA), Square Appliances, wholesalers, and AJ Pedersons. I have literally no reason to rent another house except for the questline telling me to do so. On that note, that is only ONE Ika Bohang, and ONE Gas Station in the whole map. That is a huge problem.

- There needs to be a way to tell how many vehicle bays a warehouse has before buying it. This is critical information.

- After buying out two businesses, I'm no longer sure I want to buy any more. Paying $1.6m for a business that's only generating $2'000 in revenue daily is pathetic. Can we please get a rebalance on this

- I'd like the option to move furniture that is being used by one of my employees. I understand not being able to disassemble the set, but surely I should be able to just move the whole thing wholesale?

- A phonebook. We have gaming PCs and google maps, but we can't get the number of a business unless we physically drive down and talk to the manager. This is pretty dumb honestly, and it's clearly just there cause the devs wanted to squeeze gameplay out of it.

[h1]Overall: 7/10[/h1]
A good game, tons of promise. Don't let the length of the negatives deter you, I just love ranting. The thing about this game, is that the entrepreneur stuff is actually quite good. It's everything else that holds it back.

So far so good I'll update my thoughts more when I get more hours in.  So far:

As of this review its in extremely early access
Good Stuff
-Cool freedom, easy to get addicted... i mean... "immersed in the gameplay loop" :)
-Sights and sounds are good enough
-Business sim side isnt too micromangement heavy at all!  It may be a little TOO simplistic for some but for me the porridge is just right
-Tutorial is deep enough and offers lots of helpful tips. Definitely not a waste as some tutorials are!

Bad stuff
-Driving (moving in general) is annoying
-On this issue... dont see a way to fast travel either (but most of what you need is pretty close to you!)
-On that issue... the city is a bit empty (but it will likely fill out as early access develops!)
-The many different business options that seemed so numerous that it was too good to be true... maybe a little so far.  As I said running a business is pretty light in this game.
-The "life sim" aspect is extremely light.  May not be a bad thing based on your tastes... but it WAS pushed fairly hard on the Steam page with words like "incredibly in depth" and "life sim on steroids" being used.  I wont lie... the idea of playing The Sims with a much deeper business side was running thru my mind but that is not a reasonable expectation at this time. 
 That aspect needs a lot of work for those phrases to take hold and be true.  I'd say more personal relationships, entertainment, and skill based activities would be a great start, In fact any way to spend money and time in between work and sleep would be crucial but I'd be shocked if these changes are not planned.  

I've still got a lot to see and learn but I wanted to let those on the fence know its a solid start! EA is a risk so if running a light life-sim/modern business sim sounds fun to you... yea its worth a shot if you have patience with it's shortcommings!

The game is incredibly fun in my opinion. There's a pretty decent balance between management and freedom of choice on how you run your businesses and where. There's a good diversity of the types of businesses you can run.

Few downsides to me:
One is that you just run out of stuff to do after a while. You eventually find a rhythm and can open store after store fairly quickly, and from there you're just stuck in this constant loop of opening stores with no end goal. 

A small thing would also be the management of workers. If I am in early game I want to train my workers customer service experience, I have to un-assign them from a business, then reassign them and their hours again manually. Also on the note of employees, after you begin to have a lot of employees, your MyEmployees app just shows you a large list of your workers with no easy way of filtering them, meaning you have to scroll through multiple employees to find the ones you want to manage. Perhaps there should be some kind of 'filter by business' option?

The next one is probably logistics. It gets real tiring having to micromanage what I purchase from partners when certain stuff gets low in just one store. I find that the stuff that sells quickly is cheap, so I have to fill my orders with random junk to meet the minimum spent to ship to my warehouses. Also, if I am paying somebody to do logistics and another to purchase stuff, why can't they understand when one of my businesses is running low on something, to just automatically buy more? Yes, there exists the setting to auto order stuff after 1, 3 or 7 days, but again, you will just fill your warehouses with stuff that doesn't sell as quickly as other products.

My last thing would be a little quality of life improvement. I want to be able to filter by full-time or part-time employees when hiring them. Do I seriously want to hire a full-time cleaner? or have to manage two part-time workers and one full-time worker for a store that I want to be open for weekends, evenings etc without having to hire an abundance of workers.

Other than that, the game is incredibly fun and I would highly recommend people give it a go. It's not too easy and it is a little tedious, but hey, this game more than makes up for it.

In the story mode I recommend waiting until AFTER opening a few more retail businesses to start doing the logistics quests. It happens way too early IMO and you won't be making enough to afford having to rent a warehouse and HQ space, hire a purchasing manager and delivery driver, buy a truck, buy pallet and storage shelves, and most importantly buying stock. For some reason it makes you do ALL OF THIS only after opening a gift shop and fast food restaurant. At this point in the game it's way too early to worry about it and it's still manageable to stock your businesses and run them more hands-on anyway. 

TL;DR when Uncle Fred tells you to open a HQ; STOP! Don't follow the story any further until you open at least a few more businesses.
The game is good I like it but still not much content not much things to do at this point. It would be better if the dev put more things to spend all those money made from the businesses.

I don't often take the time to review games, but this one is special. There's something magnetic about this game that makes me, a native New Yorker, really get hooked. The city is quite realistic, at least Columbus Circle. I haven't gotten further than that yet but it looks as if I will be dumping quite some time into this gem.

I don't know if it is running red lights because my self-importance dictates that I can't be bothered to wait (time is money after all). Maybe it is constantly improving my businesses in order to nickel and dime my customers to the max, a very likely and realistic possibility. Perhaps it's keeping my burger patties in the hot trunk of my car in order to save on refrigeration expenses (that freezer is costly). 

This developer is onto something here, and if you like simulations like business tycoon, you simply must try this.

I was disappointed to find my keen interest dropping off within about ten minutes of starting the tutorial game.  I'd acquired my first business after discovering the severe limitations to what you can do in your apartment and around town, and working my first job in an experience that felt a little like a mobile game (watch as you just stand there while customers move past your till, or click a button to speed to the end of the shift - fortunately without some cost for doing so).  

I got my first car and did not enjoy the experience of driving to the store to furnish my business.  It was strangely difficult to get the car to go straight and the inevitable accident I got into did nothing.  When I got to the appliance store I was disappointed to see I had to buy each item on my list one at a time, heading to the cashier and then out to my car for each thing.  This was in spite of a UI that seemed designed to handle multiple items.  I might have missed the method for doing that, but I clicked on each item I wanted only to arrive at the cash with one and one only.  When I went out to my car to put the counter I bought in the trunk the store closed for the day before I could go back in for item #2.  Oops.  Time to go home and sleep for 15 hours until the store opens again, because I have nothing else to do in my free time except buy the single grocery item or grab a hot dog.

I explored the town on foot a bit.  Central Park is inaccessible and there are "road closed" barriers at the map edges.  Again, understandable.  There's little enough in the playing area as it is, so furnishing all of Manhattan would be pointless until the game has more content.

I feel like the game is the bones for something that will be fun and deep down the road.  I'll keep an eye on it and maybe return to it some day, but for now I don't recommend it unless you really want to support the devs.

Well done Howgaard. You have my attention. I cannot wait to see what you have in store for us in the future.

So I'll start with the bad news, because there isn't much, and I don't feel it's a big deal but it's the most important to hear:

As of right now, there isn't that much to the game. There is not a lot of content or depth to the game, and other reviews reflect this as well as elaborate on this a bit more, so I would encourage you to read those reviews to get a better sense of that aspect.

That being said?

What is there, it's phenomenally well done. The game is engaging, fun, and addictive. No part seems particularly "draggy", everything seems to have the right amount of drag and grind to keep it fun. I enjoyed my time playing it so far, and I do EAGERLY await to see what more Hovgaard Games has in the works for this title. 

My own personal hope is for Workshop support to come out in the near future. What this game lacks in depth and content, I feel could be fixed with further development by Hovgaard, but made even better by a dedicated community of modders. Considering it has only been out for 5 days at the time of writing this review, and it has over 1500 overwhelmingly positive reviews, I think the future is look bright for Big Ambitions.

The incentive I create for myself is that I want to own everythinggg, but I am sure more reasons to get bigger will come. This is only an ea game and the dev has already largely nailed a concept which hasnt really been explored before. Excited to see what comes of this

For an "Early Access" title, this is an excellent start. A very niche concept that scratches a management itch that I haven't seen from any other titles. I've been let down too many times by "Early Access" games and had sworn off of them for some time. I took a chance on Big Ambitions and was not disappointed! *** Hardcore Gamer Warning *** it may feel a little content light or repetitive after 10 hours or so for some, but updates seem to be coming fast and furious. 15 hours in myself and I'm still hooked.

For the time I've been playing, I've generally enjoyed the time spend.
The story version of the game does a good job at teaching the basics, but can feel a little forced and pushy at times, but generally it does a good job at teaching.
I still enjoy the game very much, and looking forward to what comes next.

It has the [b]potential[/b] to be THE Tycoon game. As for the early stage the game is, it's surprisingly well made and provides surprising amount of fun.

However, this game offers little to no dynamics/depth further down the line and quickly runs out of content and falls into a simple gameplay loop of setting up store, delivieries, making sure it works well and going onto setting up another store.
To be truly successful this game needs more challenge, dynamics, depth, content and quality of life changes. 
Assuming devs do everything right, this game has really great potential.

I give this game a thumbs up because despite it being early access and seeming like early beta / late alpha, I have a lot of fun with it. 
However, if you expect polished and in-depth Tycoon game, right now this game is not it. 

[h1]List of changes I would like to see in the game relatively soon:[/h1]
1. Option to progress longer periods of time without micro-managing buying groceries and eating food. For example, going on a weekend/week/2 weeks/monthly vacations or whatever
2. More statistics and "issue feedback" (for example, don't tell me there is no product in shop. Tell my why it's not delivered from warehouse!)
3. Filtering employees and businesses
4. Separate threads in contacts for recruitment per each store; alternatively overhauling entire recruitment process
5. More analytics (could be implemented as in-game paid service or hireable worker) on demand, optimal prices etc. Also more clarity when set prices are too low/too high
6. When prices are too low, volume sold doesn't seem to increase. It should
7. Store managers to automate managing stores

Thread with my feedback/requests in more details: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1331550/discussions/0/3790381090380306409/

Its 'sort of' like the sims as in you can furnish a home and have very basic needs but the real focus is around renting/buying buildings and setting up stores to run independently while you rake in the profit to set up ever more profitable businesses. 

Setting up the stores requires finding a place to rent or buy, buying and transporting all the things you'll need like desks and computers for an office and then maintaining the business by adding nicer things to your store and getting a warehouse/delivery truck set up to automatically supply the business with product.

Everything from hiring employees to stocking the shelves or even working the shifts can be done by the player but it quickly becomes worthwhile having workers to do everything.  

All the features in the game are extremely well realized but the game play is currently a bit shallow and repetitive after just a few hours.

A game that I have been yearning for, for forever! This is "The Sims" on crack! (Not that I would know what it feels like to take crack, but, I digress). Anyway, Your uncle spots you some cash for you to become an entrepreneur by getting a job, saving some cash and opening a business. Once you do this, your options are ENDLESS! Not a whole lot of self customization, yet, still in early access (at least I hope it's limited), just your basic dude or chick, few other choices, nothing major, very limited but that's where the limits stop. Once you open your business, your uncle gifts you a car, nothing fancy like a Ford Pinto, but hey, at least it's something, a "Honza" I think it is. You must purchase items for your store, Cash register, shelves, pop (soda, depending on where you are, hell, maybe even Coke). You then have to take your newly purchased items to your business, unload it. From there you need products to sell, it's very basic items for the time being, since you are just getting started. Now that you have your business up and running, you can set the hours, what days you're open, the name and logo not to mention the colors of your new shop. Oh, hell, I almost forgot, you have an apartment that you must furnish, buy groceries, go to business school, a bank for a loan, a recruitment agency to hire workers for your new store...AGGGGGHHHHH! Too much to type but you get the idea, buy the game and enjoy the hell out of it or don't but you'll be missing out on one of the finest sims out there that's not named, "The Sims"! Enjoy....

I'm honestly shocked at how good this game is. It's only just gone into early access, but the developer has had playable Beta builds for some time now (I don't know the specifics, I only just learned about the game). 

For $23 bucks, the game is worth it if you're into a "The SIms-Lite" Capitalism simulator. The city feels alive, which is shocking, with only minor complaints (ie When you leave a store that's full of people then walk back in, it's completely empty and people start streaming in). But all of it is either something that isn't a big enough deal to matter, or could possibly be fixed later on in development. 

I'm going to play a lot more of this game, no question, but I also wanted to give a quick shout out to the quality of the radio in the game (Not a TON of songs but at least they are actually songs) and also: Whoever did the voice over for your uncle in story mode was not paid enough, he is an incredible voice actor! He really, really nailed it!

This game is very solid to start but it has a lot of end-game functionality to iron out. 

This game is great until you get far enough in. Setting up a large shop once is all I could stand. I opted for a super large clothing store. This meant I ended up needing 48 clothing racks. That alone was a lot. There is no way to mass move items to the new store and orders from the appliance store only go up to 18 total boxes. I wasnt about to wait 3 days to get everything inside, not counting the other stuff like speaker, registers, storage shelves, etc. 

This forced me to buy the largest truck I could find and I didnt want to move things 4 at a time, so I took a hand cart from IKEA so I could move 6 things at a time. 

Only being able to hand truck 4 things at a time is a massive hassle. There's no system in place currently that would move everything off the street and into the building. It's even worse if its an office building and there is no hand cart to move boxes inside. You have to go to a nearby retail shop and steal one.

Purchasing agents dont seem to auto purchase for you either. I tried each interval for purchase but I always ran out and when an order was placed for me, it only came from a single purchasing agent, maybe two. 

Id still put this game as a buy for the early game up to when you get into law offices and web design firms. 

I'm not sure where this game is headed in the future. I just hope it includes an inventory for office furniture and improved purchasing agents. Place an order and it all gets put into the store inventory. Then you can enter a system like interior decorator mode, but for furniture placement.

I am a die hard The Sims fan. One of my favorite expansions was The Sims 3 Open for Business. That is the vibe I get from this game! I love that it is like a Life Sim Lite. You only have a few needs, sleep, food, and happiness. But you get to go to the grocery, pick up a basket, fill it, check out in line, put it in your car, take it home, and put it in your fridge! This game is incredibly addictive. I used to live playing an old game called "Tycoon City: New York", which I believe was a product sponsored by Atari and DeepRed Games and was from the mid-2000's. In that game you played from a top-down view and worked to rebuild Manhattan block by block, neighborhood by neighborhood by constructing and upgrading various business ventures and generating profits. The game was ridiculously easy, though, and the variety of business options and architectural aesthetics were both severely lacking. 

Flash-forwarding into 2023 and I am so glad I found this game! As a micromanager at heart I am having so much fun designing customized uniforms for my employees to wear, catering to my employees' desires/needs, keeping tabs on cleanliness and supply levels, etc. I also enjoy that you need to work to keep your character fed, rested, and happy. There is also a driving element to the game (optional). This game is much more challenging and MUCH more detailed than Tycoon City: New York. I highly recommend it if you like management simulation games.

If you're a fan of management and simulation games, you might be interested in this game that has recently launched in Early Access. While there are some flaws in the game, there's also a lot to like about it.

First off, the game offers a lot of fun and engaging gameplay. You get to run multiple businesses and make all sorts of decisions, from importing burgers to hiring lawyers. It's a real challenge to balance everything and make a profit, but it's also very satisfying when you succeed.

However, if you're looking for a classic Tycoon game, you might be a bit disappointed. There are some missing fundamentals of retail simulation, such as running an HQ from an office instead of running around and customer behavior. And while the competition does open and close, it seems to be more random than based on anything you've done.

That being said, the game still has a lot of potential. The developer is very open to feedback and has already addressed some of the issues players have brought up. And since it's in Early Access, there's plenty of time to make improvements and refine the game.

So if you're looking for a fun and challenging management game, this might be worth checking out. It's not perfect, but there's definitely the germ of a truly outstanding game here, and I had a great time playing it.

I don't know why some people are eulogising about this like it's the second coming of Christ because, well, at the moment it's not. Certainly it's quite addicting but i don't see the challenge yet. It's a fairly straightforward mix of earn money, buy upgrades, make more money, with nothing really getting in the way or provoking real thought. Yes there are zones, and they're all slightly different, foot fall etc but hey, pretty simple stuff.

Now i'll qualify this by saying i did so much of the tutorial before i got pi$$ed with being told what to do time and again but it's important to learn the mechanics and the tutorial is good for that. I then started a new game, on my own, starting from scratch and am building up. Therefore you should know there is a lot more content in the game that i've not touched yet - supply chains etc - and for an EA game there is much more content that other EA games out there. which is why it's more of a positive review than negative.

There are a few annoyances such as the way shops are populated with insane numbers of people spawned in at the very moment you enter, and always immediately getting ahead of you in queues etc. Quite immersion breaking as well but hey, it's EA and i expect to see crap like that polished up in time so it is what it is. It's not  perceived annoyances such as this which form the basis of the review though - it really just seems like a very easy game based on the core mechanics, which is troublesome to see how that can improve over time but maybe it will.

Given the price though it's about right. I wouldn't want to pay much more than this otherwise i'd feel cheated so kudos for that devs.

There is the germ of a truly outstanding game here, and I definitely enjoyed my time with it. So, on that basis, yes, I recommend it.

However, if you're here for a classic Tycoon game, I'm afraid you'll be disappointed, a few hours of scratching the surface will reveal that there is very little underneath, it lacks dynamism and simulation in most aspects and the longevity suffers as a result.

It is possible to set up a successful business and never have to touch it again, while watching the money roll in. As a critique of capitalism, it works really well, as once you get beyond a certain size there is nothing to do but waste your money on trinkets and status symbols.

Some fundamentals of retail simulation are missing:
[list]
[*]There is no modelling of staff needs - while the player needs food, rest, and happiness, staff are automata, and a full-time staff member will work 50 solid hours in a row without complaint.

While staff have a preference for how many weekly hours they are scheduled, this only serves to turn scheduling into a sliding box puzzle, and as the game doesn't keep track of how many hours someone has worked in a given period, you can shuffle the board to keep them happy without penalty.

Once you've set up a schedule that works, no matter how unrealistic, it stays working.
And no, having random absences doesn't address this.

[*]There is no simulation of customer behaviour, the maximum number of customers per hour is the result of a formula, and this formula does a poor job of modelling the realities of the store.

This can be demonstrated by comparing the number of customers per hour your business serves when you're in the store with when you're not.

The game doesn't keep track of how many customers are in the store, nor how long an order takes to fulfil, and if you walk in and out of the store all your customers for that hour will disappear and take their revenue for that hour with them.

Spoiler: [spoiler]Your business does far better when you're not there, which kills the fun and challenge of laying out your store to maximise throughput.[/spoiler]

[*]Finally, competitors appear to be static. Rival businesses will open and close, but this seems like randomness for randomness' sake, to alter demand for products, rather than as a reaction to anything the player has done.

Their businesses don't appear to have their own revenue, staffing, or stock requirements. Maybe they are modelled under the hood, but given how few of the game's mechanics are systems-driven, I doubt it.
[/list]

Thankfully, it's just launched in Early Access so there's plenty of time to improve it, and the roadmap addresses a few (but not all) of the issues I have.
The developer seems really open to suggestions and keen to make it the best they can, and I truly hope they succeed.

Big Ambitions is a fun and engaging time management game that challenges players to build and manage their own business empire.this game combines elements of strategy, simulation, and time management into a cohesive and enjoyable experience.

The game starts with players taking on the role of an ambitious entrepreneur, starting with a small business and working their way up to become a tycoon. The gameplay revolves around managing resources, hiring employees, setting prices, and expanding the business into new territories.

One of the standout features of Big Ambitions is the attention to detail in the game world. The graphics are colorful and well-designed, with each location having its own unique look and feel. The game also features a robust tutorial system that helps new players learn the ropes and get started quickly.

As players progress through the game, they will encounter various challenges and obstacles that require careful planning and strategy.

Overall, Big Ambitions is a great game for fans of time management and simulation games. The gameplay is addictive and challenging, and the attention to detail in the game world is impressive. If you enjoy games that require careful planning and strategy, then Big Ambitions is definitely worth checking out.
Wow the biggest challange on this game are the loadtimes. I have played it for 20 minutes and yet to complete one.

Big Potential for Big Ambitions, and I seriously cannot wait for this game to expand in size and scope. BA has a great foundation and, performance wise, runs great at 4k max settings. The set-up is pretty basic as far as the story goes, but the management and quasi-life-sim gameplay loop works well, and has an addictive quality to it. Though, many areas are quite shallow in depth, even if one could spend tens of hours in the game already: character customization, building customization, business variety and product variety are all very limited in choice, which is something I really hope the developer expands on in each update. However, even though parts of the game are extremely limited, the gameplay mechanics, as well as gameplay loop, are tight and fun in its current rendition. Thus, BA gets a score of 10/10 for how well it executes a life-sim / tycoon management blend that works wonderfully in such an early stage in development. I have really high hopes for this game and suggest one picks this up at full-price or on-sale for a wonderful time and wants to support what could become a classic in the making.

I was going to give this game a 9.5, but I just noticed the office supply shop is named Mr. Scott's, so I think that's worth an extra 0.5 points. 10/10! I'm basing this score on it being EA. I really do believe that in a few years, this game will be something truly special. The developers clearly have a plan and are amazing at what they do. I, like many here, am leaving a review for the first time despite having played many games. The fact that so many players are doing this speaks volumes. Honestly, I think the game is underpriced, but the fact they have set such a good price and delivered an amazing early access game will no doubt encourage people to support them with future DLC, etc. PS: I think Rockstar Games could use some lessons from these guys about how AI traffic is meant to behave.

I was suspicious of this game before buying it due to its overwhelmingly positive review score and most reviews reading like a bot written text (hey, maybe mine is like that too). But playing it, I realized that this game deserves the positive reviews. I managed to play over 14 hours within 2 sessions, which is big for me. Game is actually good. You go from working 8 hours at a supermarket to raking in over 10k daily by doing nothing and you actually feel the progress you're making throughout the game. At first you're painstakingly driving to wholesalers to buy goods from them and stock your store yourself while manning the counter; after a while you hire a HR manager for your headquarters and you let them take care of employee training and scheduling, you hire a purchasing agent to import goods for your warehouses and a logistics manager to stock your stores as well as handling warehouse drivers. There are expensive vehicles, property and furniture to spend your hard earned money which is quite enough for the current EA state.

Now as for cons, my earliest frustration was due to UI and camera. Camera can be unpredictable and you might end up misclicking on another building. The fixed camera you get while driving a car also causes you to crash into cars that you are simply unable to see. As for the UI, the mini window that appears when you hover over a building might stick around for a while and block you from clicking the building you were intending to click on. There are also some bugs, the biggest is when you are placing furniture, you might suddenly be unable to move. I got around it by entering and exiting interior designer or grabbing/packing a furniture. Another nitpick of mine would be is that there aren't enough pedestrians in the streets and the city is too quiet.

However, my biggest disappointment with this game is that there are some clearly good and bad choices for the types of businesses. Fast food restaurants and coffee shops had tiny profit margins for me. I opened them in districts with high demands for their items, diversified the available items they sold, rented shops with high foot traffic, maxed out advertisement, decorated the store, trained workers etc. Nothing worked. Whereas with an undecorated gift store that had 11% foot traffic, I was clearing 1-2k profit daily thanks to expensive gifts. I also listened to a comment I saw on discussions and opened a medium sized florist shop in a rich district with decent demand for the flowers and after maxing out my workers and decorating it nicely, I was earning over 10k daily from it. I didn't look into them heavily, but office businesses aren't that profitable either yet they do better than most retail businesses

Having to pay taxes to IRS, constantly parallel parking and not caring about 125$ parking tickets after you get rich is a nice experience. Try not to savescum in the casino ship.

Entertaining business/life sim, quite addictive for an early access game. The framework is good, the UI needs improvement, but I love the population simulation. Looking forward to see the development progress!
Love the game.. so addictive.

Great game, but marred by a few issues. There is WAY too much UI in this game, imo. I know it's necessary to carry out commands like restocking your shelves, etc., but it gets in the way a LOT. And it doesn't always clear from the screen properly. There is a lot of depth to this game that allows you to interact with objects, etc., and the UI just gets in the way. Even if you look at your shelf from a certain distance, there is a fly out that comes out that covers a good portion of the screen. However, these are all things they can figure out, and I feel will get better with time. I'd also like to be able to move the camera while driving the car. Just like when you're running. Overall I give this game a thumbs up, but it definitely suffers from typical frustrating isometric game control issues. I feel that I fight with the camera a LOT. I'd honestly prefer just a regular 3rd or 1st person view, but it's their game. I also heard they're redoing the controller support soon, which will make it 100% better.

Uncle Fred is my Sugar Daddy. He is the best.

I love business sims and enjoyed Startup Company so I was excited for this game. However I would describe this game as being 90% a walking/driving simulator and 10% actual business simulation. You have to drive/walk around to do basically everything in-game. It's so tedious to have to spend all day going from one shop/agency to another to buy your stock, furniture, and to hire staff. If you forget something from one shop that's essential to run your business, you'll have to spend 2-3 minutes (actual minutes, not in-game) going all the way back, picking it up, checking it out, etc - very frustrating and not at all fun. In 2.5 hours of play I have still only barely scratched the surface of the actual simulation (namely, hiring two locations, with an extremely basic setup of one shelf, one product type, and one staff member each) because so much time is wasted just getting around.

Having a car to run around town does help BUT you are massively disincentivised from using it as each little bash into another car/bollard etc reduces its condition, and it will presumably eventually break completely. After one hour in-game my car is down to 30% condition! So I end up doing as much as possible on foot which takes AGES.

I'm hoping that after another several hours, you don't have to spend the entire time just running/driving around, but honestly I don't have the patience to persevere with the game to find out.

I have some other relatively minor gripes:
1) there's no WASD support when you are on foot, so you have to click and hold down in the direction you want to move in. Mildly annoying for most people, but for people with arthritis like me (yes people under 30 can have arthritis too) it's actually physically painful to play this game.
2) the female protagonist looks like she's been designed by somebody with no knowledge of female human anatomy. Enormous bolt-on breasts much too high on the chest, on a physique that would otherwise belong to a man. And the only clothes available all look like men's clothes.

Big Ambitions is very promising, and scratches the life-sim tycoon hybrid itch very well. Bit addictive if you enjoy making numbers go brrr. Developers seem passionate.

It appears to be a game that could foster a thriving modding community and become an absolute classic, a mainstay of the genre.

Great EA release with a good roadmap.

You get to run businesses, multiple at once. You import burgers from China, to sit in an non-refrigerated warehouse for months then going to a non-refrigerated backroom. Once there employees use telekinesis to move them to the front before selling each customer 4 burgers, 2 salads, 3 hotdogs, and a pizza, costing more than your employees pay per hour. You continue this until you make enough money to hire a lawyer, who you pay $40 an hour, but charge your customers $800 an hour for the privilege to talk to these 100% Lawyer Gods. Once you make enough money, you can then park your half a million dollar sports car in the middle of the road because the traffic fines barely show up in your expense report. The privileges of the rich. Now if you excuse me, I need to go work on my golf swing.

Also, a steam workshop would be nice.
10 non-refrigerated burgers out of 10

I like the game and have been following Colonel Failure's current series.  However, there are a few quirks in the game that make it an annoying trudge such that I  can't recommend buying it at this time.  The biggest annoyances are the total lack of camera control and an impossibly woeful lack of zoom control.  The player is stuck with a fixed top down POV that has a bizarre field of view.  The FOV is so narrow that the player can only see what's going on in an approximate 10 meter radius. He can't look left of right without turninghis body 90 degrees.  You can't move the camera down for a more horizontal POV.  The game is supposed to be challenging but  poorly designed camera control is not a feature, it is a bug or just bad coding.  I'm leaning toward the latter because character tracking is also a mess.  The character is either permanently drunk or walking, running or driving a vehicle in a straight line is not possible.  The character yaws to the right when using the "W" key to move "straight" ahead.  If it were an aircraft I'd say the yaw damper has failed.

If the Dev fixes these issues I will revisit the review.  For now I'll thank Col. Failure for a humorous and entertaining series featuring the game but as for buying it - no.  I can't recommend buying the game unless the buyer enjoys poor execution of a game with a very interesting premise as a form of entertainment.

I decided to open a law firm, or more accurately, I HAD to because the main character's average-Joe uncle who thinks he's a Harvard MBA graduate ordered me to. The tutorial, called "story mode," takes dozens of hours and offers little freedom.

In order for my office to function fully, I need 50 working desks and at least 50 lawyers. For one "working" desk, I need a desk, a chair, and a computer, which I have to buy from a furniture mall (like IKEA). There are two ways to purchase items: offline or online.

The offline way requires me to physically walk around the mall, grab the items (I can only buy 8 items at a time), load them into my car (which can hold a maximum of 20 items), drive to my office, manually pull them out of the trunk one by one, and then place them in the office. This one procedure takes about 10 minutes to get 20 items, resulting in 6 working desks.

The online way is a bit simpler, but the user interface for purchasing items is terrible, and I can only purchase 18 items a day. The items are delivered in front of my office, but I still have to move them on foot and manually place them one by one.

As a result, it took me well over an hour to fill my office with the required 50 desks, 50 computers, and 50 chairs.

Now, let's talk about the 50 lawyers. I can only look for new employees 10 at a time, and I cannot decide whether they work full-time or part-time, so I have to call my headhunter office more than 10 times since I want only full-time lawyers. The user interface for accepting/declining new employees is also terrible.

Next, I want to train my lawyers a few times. As you may have guessed, I have to manually click the check boxes of each lawyer to train them. There is a "check all" button, but it's virtually useless unless I want to train literally ALL employees, including the cleaning guy or the clerk at the hamburger place.

Lastly, I have to drag each lawyer to the working hour charts to set their working hours. There is no option to set all employees to work the same hours, so I have to manually drag them 50 times. There is an auto-assign feature, but it usually leads to mass resignation since your employees have demands and it is not smart enough to fulfill all the demands.

After all of this, I finally opened my law firm. But what was the cost? Two hours of useless chores. By the way, there is no real challenge or depth to the game. If you understand basic concepts of the game, and do as I said, you will 100% make 5 to 6 figures a day.

1) Be born to a wealthy family: ☑️
2) Be given money from said wealthy family: ☑️
3) Quit menial labor after just 2 days to "start business": ☑️
4) Use banking connections to get a loan without any business experience because of family connections: ☑️
5) Have a Larry at the bank that makes your loan payments all but non-existent: ☑️

If you want a completely realistic business simulator, and can ☑️ all the boxes, buy Big Ambitions and spin your story as you being "self-made" like the rest of 'em!

Yes! Just yes! First day of early access, it's already excellent. It plays great, has a great atmosphere (with a hint of GTA feel -- I almost want to be able to run over the pedestrians :P), and the tools for scaling your overall business endeavour are more mature than most games see in their lifetime. I'm blown away. Even where I had a concern or two, they were calmed as a natural part of the gameplay progression. In other words, just ignorance on my part. The only nitpick is that interaction with and placement of items can be a bit fiddly and semi-frustrating, but it detracts very little from the overall experience.

I was going to wait until I've seen more of the game to write a review (currently managing warehouses and setting up goods distribution to my shops). But I just had a moment where, just nope, I've seen enough. This is fantastic. Everything just makes sense, and everything I think should be there, is there (barring a couple of quality of life things -- but you have to give them something to work on during early access!).

Wholeheartedly recommend if this type of game even slightly tickles your fancy. Stop reading and just get it.

Highly recommend this game to anybody that wants to feel like a successful entrepreneur without risking your own cash on it. Can't wait to sink a lot more time in to it going forward.

I saw all these reviews of people saying this is the best thing since sliced bread, and was pretty curious.  This game is totally addicting. I'm absolutely loving it, and already looking forward to my next playthrough because I want to try to do things differently.  Also enjoying the soundtrack.

4 Hours:
Good ol Hovgaard delivers again!
As a huge fan of previous work "Startup Company" this purchase was a no-brainer. I will continue to support Hovgaard through development of any past/current/future products.

For Big Ambitions though, I will summarize this game briefly for anyone who may be considering purchasing this title until I progress further:

"Arcade-sim life tycoon"
-Game elements consist of buying/renting property and turning that into capital income. 
-Core game-play is solid.
-4 hours in, no bugs found.
-Soundtrack appears to be from royalty free websites (correct me if wrong in the comments) yet still good but needs more variety.
-Strangely reminiscent to the old "Game Dev Tycoon" days. (GDT the game fyi)
-Point and click movement is not my preferred control choice. I didn't find a WASD option in the menu that worked. But that is diffidently not a deal breaker.
-Car movement can be wonky. Sudden oversteers into parked cars when taking a too-fast-turn. Possibly happens during autosaves to cause the issue?
-Map is GREAT. Very detailed, easy to use/read.



I will further update this review in the near future. (Ran out of time)

I have been waiting for a game like this for a while. Whatever kind of business you want, it is capable. Other businesses are planned and seem hopeful. The layout for the city makes sense as well. Other businesses that fulfill your needs are usually not too far. The tutorial system is good enough to get you through and learn the basics, probably needs just a few tweaks though. Its probably planned already, but I am not sure how to sell things you do not need anymore. Be ready to grind at the beginning, there will be a lot of driving back and forth to buy products to sell. Once you get a warehouse and truck for deliveries it is a little easier. For an early release, this game shows more potential than I have seen in a long time for an early release game. If the graphics and some of the mechanics get tightened up with possibly a few DLCs, this game could easily be one of the top ten business simulation games of all time.

I haven't played the game all that much yet, but so far, its pretty decent. Gotta really pay attention to the demand to make bigger profits. There's a few bumps, but for an early access game, it feels really good, compared to 90% of "Early access" games that are on Steam.

Definitely a sleeper game, unexpectedly addictive.

After 31 hours I think I got a pretty good handle on the game. The tutorial truly teaches you how to play the game and gives you a story to play by.

Recent downsides are the fact you can't build dry walls to make offices/individual rooms(I have resorted to using wardrobes to make a wall..), there's no doors between rooms that open/close, the only doors that function are the ones you enter/exit the building from. There's no upper level/lower level function making the size of buildings a little disappointing, on that note the size and shape of buildings is pre-defined and there is no quick preview button, you have to navigate a couple menus before you get there making a quick look to find the perfect building tedious. Greater control over the building part, including the exterior, would be ideal, maybe acquiring the neighbouring building would allow you to merge them together to make a larger one.

Another thing I'd like to see is more functions to 'man the fort' say from your office you could sit at your desk and have something more to do yourself (you can't go to law school and be one of the lawyers at your firm, or a programmer, or as mentioned an HQ member), I struggle to have multiple cars cause there's not many car parks that we can safely store our cars at.

I have only been able to get a job at the supermarket.. would be interesting to get to the point you can work for someone else say a programmer firm.

so overall, more building options, some interface improvements, more interior variations, more work options please

But I do love the game! You can manage so much and do so many things already, what a great start!

Oh, you wanted to look at some negative reviews?   Too bad, this game is pretty awesome.

It is a fun game so far. Knowing their other game, Startup Company, this could be just as entertaining and complex. I look forward to that.

For now, it comes across as more of a grind game, which is what you do in these kind of games, I know. 
I think, and hope, that the controls for movement and the camera functionality will be improved much more. For now it is a basic turn system with Q and E, press once and it turns to set positions. In the car it is fixed on the back of the car.
Walking around is with mouse, keep pressing the mouse button to where you want to go, or keep clicking a thousand times on the map till you are where you need to be.
When you have a car, which is pretty soon, you drive with WASD. 
Camera is also resetting when you enter or leave buildings, which made me walk in circles. 
Popup's are sometimes in the way for your purpose, like getting in the car by muoseclick but then there is the popup for managing the inventory for the car. I had multiple times the issue that I clicked to fast and entered the inventory instead of the car. 
It is silly things like that, which are slightly annoying but the game is very playable. 

The game itself is more of a repeating factor. You open a business, put together the inventory, earn money, hire people, earn more money and open a second business. If you keep an eye on your profits and inventory, you will do well very fast into the game. I've played for 6,4 hours when writing this review. 
I have my giftshop setup with 2 registers, 5 customer service employees and 3 cleaning employees. I have a fast food restaurant with 2 registers, 6 customer service employees and 5 cleaning employees. Both business are open 10 hours a day 7 days a week. I have a contract for my restaurant so the deliver goods (20 boxes). The restaurant has everything exept for the pizzaoven. Full storage and I still make between 2000 and 6000 profit per week (depending on me buying things). 
Still live in my first appartment and drive in the first car. It is an easy grinding game which I hope will be improved in complexity. 

I do recommend to buy it now or soon. The learning curve will probably become bigger after more development and updates come.

I never write reviews. I have hundreds of games, all which I have enjoyed in varying degrees, but none warranted a review. 

So why am I reviewing this title then? Because it is a concept of a game that I have always envisioned. Here me out. 

If you are like me, a console gamer and a pc gamer, who appreciated PC gaming due to the variety of games not found on console, mostly simulation and strategy, then this game is for you. 

This is what I feel like The Sims would have evolved into, if not bought by EA. I know, that's a gigantic claim to be made, but it's true. 

It doesn't have all the social needs that make up the Sims, but it's got the freedom and role playing down pat. I'd argue that the world even feels more alive. From the traffic that's backed up on the street, blocking you from a convenient parking spot near your business, to the buildings looking alive so to speak, being able to peer into their windows. 

It's the classic game where you think to yourself, I'll play just one more day, but find yourself an hour later, convincing yourself you need to go to bed. 
I found myself like this last night. I was only a few steps away from opening my liquor store, and I wanted to see it through. 

The balancing act of running your businesses, while also trying to expand your empire, and fulfilling your own needs, are all well implemented. 

The fact that this is Early Access, blows my mind. I haven't even looked into their road map yet. 

I give this a solid 9/10. Why not a perfect 10? Well, because it's Early Access, which means it is hopefully only the beginning.

This game is absolutely incredible, and I enjoy how it forces you to think like a businessman. For instance, training your staff to advance along with you is a terrific idea.

Although you would actually need to travel to the store, buy the products you want, and then come install them in your home, this game enables you to be completely hands-on when it comes to stocking your stores and adding your own flair to their appearance. (Extra credit for this feature)

While the game is currently in V. Beta 9, the only thing I would suggest needs to be added is more character customisation. It would be fantastic if you could go shopping for clothes, then load your purchases into your cupboard, name your outfits and then you could do outfit changes.

Finally, it would be fantastic to have some shops you could go to on your days off, like a barber where you could alter your hairdo or a tattoo artist where you could get inked.

Still more I will definitely be putting in a lot more time to the game, and I can't wait for the upcoming updates.
