Big Ambitions is, what the name suggests. An Early Access title with an impressive roadmap. Is it there yet? Not quite, but then again, to be fair, what is there is what one usually gets from a manager game. So even this Early, BA isn't a bad buy.

Currently, story mode plays in two distinct phases (as far as I know after some 10 hours). Phase One is the game start, when your toon lacks the money and the skill to have an organization. So you have to do everything by hand. That means, to be very clear, micromanagement down to the point, where you have to mop up specific stains on the floor of your businesses with your cleaning kit. What makes this phase a little dicey is that your businesses grow fast and irregularly. In other words, things go wrong and it is hard to say, whether that is current lack of polish of the game or something isn't set up correctly.

Simple example: The F1 key is your friend. It tells you, what you need. Necessarily. What it doesn't tell you is, what you should have, though. For instance, fast food joints need a trash bin (contrary to the patch notes, those are in office supplies, not in furniture). Also, when putting some music in your venues, all you need is the speakers. As a rule of thumb, loiter in your businesses and take the time to actually read the customer feed back. Reacting to the latter makes a difference.

Another important tip, that may not be obvious at first. Currently, no two businesses offer the same service. There are two ad agencies, one offers billboards, one net coverage. There are two recruitment agencies, one for retail, one for offices. That gets a lot more complicated, when buying supplies and furniture. Remember, F1 is your friend. Most of the time.

A third life saver. I get it. We like credit. Why work, when all you need is to go to the bank and get the cash? Well, currently, you can't pay off a loan early, so each penny you borrow sticks to you like the venereal disease. Don't say, I didn't wanr you.

Phase Two is organization. It's a simple fact that you can only physically carry so much in form of supplies. Unless you start a headquarter, I don't see how you can support more than four or five businesses without a glitch. Luckily, the story mode leads you there. And while there is nothing wrong with passive income, ultimately here is where Early Access puts up the wall. So now what? Well, I guess, we'll see. Eventually. I hope that long term there will be different incentives to open yet another business than buying a posh car or a skyscraper.

I also hope that when theft gets implemented, "security" will not be the answer (as the roadmap currently suggests). In retail, prevention is the last ditch effort, not the first. Theft is a simple "cost of business" factor, which necessarily needs an equally simple tool to cover per item profit. Which would, at the same time, solve the game's current problem of only providing access to vapor information concerning margin in percentages. Why that is so vital? Because making 6 percent selling a skyscraper is a lot more lucrative than making 100 percent on a t-shirt.

What it all comes down to is, adding a Sims factor to a manager was a fantastic first step. If it was indeed the first step of many to come.

First review I have ever left. The reason I'm leaving one now, is because this game really is exactly something I had been looking for for quite a while. 

To me Big Ambitions feels somewhere in between Sims 4 + business expansion and Capitalism Lab. I love and dislike games for different reasons. In Sims, the life of the business owner takes the central stage, but the business mechanics are lacking. The economic systems that run Capitalism Lab are unmatched, but the human element is nearly if not completely absent.

Big Ambitions manages to create a good business simulator, while not forgetting the persons running the whole thing. The city feels real (which is an accomplishment on its own right) and you have the option to put individuality to your store.

 I'm looking forward to see what more this game has to offer, but I think it has quite some potential.

Je me suis lancé dans l'ouverture d'une boutique de donuts, mais j'ai vite réalisé que la concurrence était féroce dans ce domaine. Heureusement, j'ai pu pivoter et me lancer dans la fabrication de Bijoux Montre Rolex, ce qui s'est avéré être un choix judicieux !

I highly recommend this game, very fun game where you can create your business empire including fast food restaurants, coffee shops, gift shops, office headquarters and much more. I was expecting more features such as a crime system (drug and gun dealing), a grey area (gambling), an economic system (buying and selling stocks, buying companies), and global trade (not just limited to one city). There are some operations that are very complicated, such as having to go home (bench) to sleep every day, and I also need to click the mouse all the time to manipulate the character to walk around, which can be tedious. I have played a lot of management games and Big Ambitions is the one that appeals to me the most.

[h1]Big Ambitions: Early Access Review[/h1]

Big ambitions is a roleplay game, tycoon game, and simulation game where you take the role as an entrepreneur and start up your own businesses. You can start up various amount of businesses, you can open up a grocery store, fast food restaurant, law firm, there are so many options! Rent your own apartment, buy luxurious cars and exotic cats, hire employees and manage them!

At it's current state, in early access, I'm amazed with the amount of content and things to do in the game, it is very engaging and addicting and it is only in early access and will continue to get updated. 

The developers have done an amazing job developing the game and getting the littlest of details. If you're looking for a engaging life simulation, business sim, etc this game is for you I %100 recommend it, the game has so much potential and I'm looking forward to the future of this game. I will update my review when the game fully releases.

If you like business management games, with tons of stats, charts, buying and selling real estate, and inventory management then definitely get this. this game is VERY addicting, and will make the hours rush by!

I find the game very addicting.  On the face of it the game is simple, but when you start playing you discover there is a lot to the game. 
You really need to spend time each game day studying the various spread sheets it provides in the interface in order to make each of your businesses as profitable as possible.
You also need the strength to say goodbye to a business that is not pulling its weight financially.
I do find the interface a bit clunky but I am sure that will be ironed out in time. The main issues seem to be a difficulty clicking on the right business to enter and if you use point and click rather than the experimental WASD movement mode then it is difficult to get out of the big wholesaler. I must have re entered that store about 6 times before I gave up and changed to the WASD mode.
I find the driving difficult but all game based driving is hard. At least with this game it is surprisingly smooth aside from braking. I ended up hitting the rear end of many cars before I learned to slow before every corner just in case.
For the most part I find the interfaces intuitive and helpful. And as I said the game is a lot of fun. I played 10 hours straight on the first day.

I played this game for 8 hours straight after purchasing, still have many hours ahead. 

This is a phenomenal little sim game, don't be worried by the early access badge as there's plenty to do already.  Definitely deserves a thumbs-up, and I'm looking forward to whatever content they add in the future,

Note: If the game crashes for you, follow these steps: 
1.) Go to your task manager.
2.) Find the game's exe file in the details tab. 
3.) Rick click on the exe file and then click "set affinity".
4.) Unselect all and only click on CPU 0, CPU 1, CPU 2 (Game doesn't need all processors to function). Then, click OK.
Hope this helps. Highly recommend this game and excited for the future of it.

Honest EA Review:

This game is a hidden jewel. Even being in EA, it brings me the feeling i had when i was a kid playing GTA 2 (yes, the one where the perspective was top-bottom). I rember trying to own my bussiness in GTA but it always ended in multiple cops firing at my ass.

Here, you start as a simple unemployed 18yo struggling with life in NY city, your uncle gives you some money to pay the rent and the rest is up to you; working as a cashier in a supper market to earn enough money to put food on the table and start your own little business is just the start of this big adventure.

The PRO's & Con's:

Pro's:
+ You get "the sims" + GTA feeling (without the robery and stuff).
+ A lot of mechanics in place in a big city for you to grow your business.
+ You control your character directly (not in the usual management way) which i like.
+ The base mechanics are very well fleshed out even being in EA, havent found any bug yet.
+ Nice music and sound effects.
+ You can even furnish your home in "the sims" style.
+ You have an IKEA! Even with the light arrows to follow the aisles (Lol'ed hard at this one, loved it).

Cons:

- Personally i think "Big ambitions" it's not the best name for this game, as it really doesn't give a clue to what to expect from it, leading to an auto-self-harm marketing (it almost passed unnoticed to me because the thumnail and name).
- Controls are not very good (ie: mouse click instead wasd when walking but then suddenly wasd for designing, cleaning also is very janky).
- Housing, missing construction of walls, doors, remodelating, etc.
- Even if the city feels big, it still feels empty with very few people and meaningful interactions.
- You cannot sit at a restaurant and eat stuff (like the NPC's do).
- No many options to interact in your home other than eat - sleep - watch tv.
- Going to restaurants or coffee shops feels very similar, maybe adding more customizations to each ones would make it more diverse, also more interaction options.
- Lacks some indications, for example if you break your car, how can you fix it?

It's been a while since i saw an original idea like this one and it really is a "big ambitions" game with a solid foundation to build something incredible over the time. 
Devs, keep going with this one, market it a little more and evaluate a name change over time to attrack more people.

I give it a solid 8/10 as of now, but it could easily go up if they really work out their roadmap and keep evolving it.

Really looking forward to seeing where this goes.  The Devs have been great on the discussion forums answering questions and giving advice,  it’s good to see.  If you like resource management, business sims, lifestyle sim type games you’re gonna love it.  If you don’t like grindy games that have repetitive elements it’s probably one to say no to.  I’m happily in the former.

I watched Raptor play this on YouTube earlier today and decided to buy. This is the best business management game I have ever played. It is not only addicting, but one of a kind. As someone who is skeptical about early access games, I rarely take chances on any resource management-type games being good. 

Big Ambitions keeps the overall mechanics simple, yet detailed enough to keep your attention without being too top-heavy to push you away. I'm extremely impressed by the amount of content already available at the start of the game's release. It should be a standard for all early-access games. There are some graphical issues that occur that can get annoying, but the bones of the game are strong enough that I'm able to play on my Surface Pro 9 at 40fps (medium graphics, FXAA anti-aliasing).

I'm not one to buy early-access games so recently released that you can't even see the summary of the reviews, but I'm glad I took the chance and highly recommend others do the same,

Been watching Colonel Failure and some others play this game for a bit over a week now and stoked to finally be playing.

Game’s totally unique. It’s a life sim in which you run businesses. Any business in the city, any business in the game.

I’m about one in-game week in, worked about three days for the man, took a loan, rented a tiny retail space, slapped a cheap bed in my stock room so I could skip on an apartment and I’m now running a bodega. As someone who has spent over 100 hours playing the pre-release beta, I can confidently say that this game is truly outstanding. Set in the bustling city of New York, the game allows you to create and expand your own business empire, complete with various types of stores and even a logistics system.

What sets this game apart is the impressive attention to detail and the seamless integration of all its features. Everything from designing your stores to managing your employees is handled with great care and precision, making for a truly immersive experience.

One of the best things about this game is the level of support provided by the developers. Any issues or bugs you encounter can be easily reported and addressed by hitting F2, with the developers quickly investigating and fixing the problem.

Overall, if you're looking for a game that offers a deep, engaging simulation of the business world, this is definitely one to check out. With its impressive features and excellent support, it's a game that will keep you coming back for more.

Where to start.

First, buy the game. It's great. Now I can explain why. 

I have watched, as of the first day of issue, every video I can find of the gameplay. This includes Colonel Failure, Britto, Charlie Pryor, and Kanzalone and several others. About 30 hours' worth.

I have only played the game for about 3 hours, but this will increase rapidly over time. I love being retired!!

Game starts in New York City. You get a little seed money from your Uncle Fred, and you get an apartment, and a request to start a new business. This is in story mode. I'll address the sandbox mode here in a bit.

The story mode serves as an extended tutorial, and will last MANY years. Over time, you will get exposed, fairly slowly and with no time pressure to additional concepts and in-game requirements.

The game is great. Buy the game.

This game is a cross between the Sims, and an RPG, and an economic game like Capitalism 2 or C.E.O. There are about 20 different types of stores, and 50+ items you can purchase and stock in your stores. You set the price, store hours, and interior decorations.

Employee management is an entire mini-game. Training, taking care of their needs, assigning work hours, and managing the cost of hours is all a pretty hefty part of Big Ambitions.

Stock management is a MAJOR time sink, at the beginning, and is quite a challenge to get into a routine, to avoid running out of product when your store is open. You're given an old car, which you can upgrade to a much higher capacity panel van. There are various wholesalers to get your product from, as well as appliance stores, an IKEA-like store, and many others.

Personnel agencies, Marketing agencies, and Financial companies are all represented. You can absolutely borrow, and BORROW to set up your businesses. But..and this is useful, you can only borrow so much. Loans have to be paid back, and you can't cheese the borrowing process to overwhelm the game.

Buy this game. The game is great. As of this writing, the game as 100% positive reviews. For a reason. Peace. Out.
Finally a early access game that have a lot of stuff in it and is well optimized on launch. Congrats !

This game remembers me in part the Sims and GTA I, with the concept of administration as the base of the game. I'm really impressed that the game it's polished within early acces. This piece has enormous potential, I really hope they can continue improving and adding content.

This is wayyy better than i expected, most games today can be described as all style with no substance whereas this is kind of the opposite and even that would be unfair on it, the game has a LOT of meat on the bone, its dense with things to see and do. It seems some real care and attention has been put into the micro details... down to the smallest details like if you need to pay for parking on a certain street, in such a short amount of play time ive said to myself wow thats a cool detail so many times. How does a team of 4-6 people with a limited budget create such depth... if i was to complain about anything then perhaps the camera could receive a pass in the interest of QOL, its a little limited on range, id like to be able to zoom out more and have a little more adjustment to see further away when driving.

I wouldn't be afraid to say this is bad if it was but it just isn't, its a solid 8 thus far, well worth a buy.

Loving the game so far. Been following the game for a bit. The devs regularly update the game and provide youtube vids showcasing everything added in each update. The game is a little buggy and lacking in some areas, for instance currently, you can buy cigars from liquor stores, but you can't do anything with them, so there's no point.  The management sim is absolutely addictive, and although the game starts out really slow, it really picks up once you get one or two businesses under your belt.

Wow, this is what a RPG should be so, many RPGS forget the ROLE playing aspect, this game does make you feel like you're a business owner in a busy city. You have to set your business hours, buy stock, hire staff (or you can work yourself) train up and learn courses, there are also many businesses to interact with, coffee shops, wholesalers, car dealerships all with little set ups, products and stock to buy and consume. 

Shops have opening hours, so if closed you cant go in. You can see what is doing well, what is doing badly so you know what sort of business to open. IF you are in a shop you have to wait in the Q and the staff will go to the areas and get your burger/salad etc.

You can buy apartments, new cars etc and do them up sims style with like furniture, computers and tvs.

Yes it is a little rough around the edges and could do with some polish but I will defiantly be playing this more and hope it gets the attention it deserves.
